Text_ortho: Because e get stones, I have to wash it well using calabash.

Text_en: We use a calabash.
Text_ortho: Na calabash we dey use.

Text_en: Add water, two, shaking it till it's clean, pour it until when... twice or three times, like this.
Text_ortho: Put water two of dem, be shaking it clean, pour until wai twice, or three times like dis.

Text_en: You will see the stones, they will go down.
Text_ortho: You go see di stones o, de go con go down.

Text_en: It's only the acha, that will go to the other uh... dish.
Text_ortho: Na only di acha go go di oder ehn dish.

Text_en: Then you will pour it, do it again for about two or three times.
Text_ortho: Den you pour it, do it again about two three time.

Text_en: You should make sure that all the sand has come off.
Text_ortho: Make you make sure sey all di sand don comot.

Text_en: Finish that, then you will pour it.
Text_ortho: Finish dat one, den you pour it.

Text_en: Then you'll stir it.
Text_ortho: Den you go dey stir.

Text_en: You haven't added the leaves yet.
Text_ortho: You never add leaves o.

Text_en: You will be stirring it.
Text_ortho: You go dey stir.

Text_en: When it gets thick, then, you will take the spinach, and the other leaves which you have cut and kept aside, and add them.
Text_ortho: When it becomes thicken, den, you now carry di spinach, and di oder leaves wey you don cut before keep for side add.

Text_en: And then, you will stir it, cover it and leave it for... let's say five minutes, like this.
Text_ortho: And den, you stir, cover, leave it for say five minute like dis.

Text_en: It will be ready.
Text_ortho: E go don do.

Text_en: Don't keep it on the fire for too long because if it stays for too long, even the leaves, they will change color, uhuh... and maybe the nutritional value will get destroyed.
Text_ortho: Make e no overtay because if e tay too much, even di leaves, e go change colour ehen, and maybe di nutritional value go destroy.

Text_en: So, you have to leave it like that.
Text_ortho: So you have to leave it like dat.

Text_en: Bring it down.
Text_ortho: Bring it down.

Text_en: It is now ready.
Text_ortho: It is now ready.

Text_en: You can eat it.
Text_ortho: You fit eat am.

Text_en: And this gote, we like it so much because it is very nutritional.
Text_ortho: And dis gote o, we like it very much because it is very nutritional.

Text_en: All these things... ingredients you are adding, they have vitamins, minerals, and other things.
Text_ortho: All di tings, ingredient wey you dey add, vitamins, minerals, oder tings dey.

Text_en: So, that is what we make.
Text_ortho: So na im we dey make.

Text_en: Once... for lunch, we do have it.
Text_ortho: Once of our lunch, we dey take am.

Text_en: Bones, the meat, it's proteineous.
Text_ortho: Bones, di meat is proteinaceous.

Text_en: The acha's got protein too, right?
Text_ortho: Di acha too get protein abi?

Text_en: Uh... in the leaves, there's minerals, vitamins and other things.
Text_ortho: Eh in di leaves, minerals, vitamins, oder tings dey.

Text_en: So, I dont... we dont... I do not add oil.
Text_ortho: So I don't, we no, I no dey add oil o.

Text_en: No oil.
Text_ortho: No oil.

Text_en: It's plain.
Text_ortho: Is plain.

Text_en: Dont add oil.
Text_ortho: No add oil.

Text_en: Most people dont like it with oil.
Text_ortho: Most people don't like it wit oil.

Text_en: That is how we eat it.
Text_ortho: Dat is how we take it.

Text_en: Uh... so, that is how we cook it.
Text_ortho: Ehn so na so we dey cook am.

Text_en: Then, you will eat it.
Text_ortho: Den you take it.

Text_en: When you finish eating it, if you want to drink something, you can take kunu or gruel, the local kunu that we drink.
Text_ortho: If you finish eating, if you want to push it down, you fit take kunu, or gruel, di local kunu dat we take.

Text_en: Drinking it will help with digestion.
Text_ortho: Den you push it down wit it.

Text_en: And this one... this uh... gote, right, is very good, not only for a medicinal pur-... diabetes.
Text_ortho: And dis one, dis eh gote bah, is very good not only for ah medicinal pur-... diabetes.

Text_en: People that have diabetes, you know, you will not be able to eat rice.
Text_ortho: People dat have diabetes, you know you no go fit take rice.

Text_en: You will not be able to ea-... eat uh... corn, but acha is good.
Text_ortho: You no go fit ti-... take ehn maize, but acha is good.

Text_en: So it is recommended for them.
Text_ortho: So it is recommended for dem.

Text_en: And when you are sick, and you're recovering, it is another recommended food for convalescence.
Text_ortho: And when you sick, and you just dey recover, it is anoder recommended food for convalescence.

Text_en: That's what we give people because if you have no appetite, it'll give you an appetite.
Text_ortho: Na him we dey give people because if you no get appetite, e dey do.

Text_en: Even for small children, it is very good for every...
Text_ortho: Even small children, it's very good for every...

Text_en: The... this word... gote, right, is the best for pregnant women because it strengthens the blood.
Text_ortho: Di, dis word, gote ma, is di best for pregnant women because e dey add blood.

Text_en: The leaves, they strengthen the blood.
Text_ortho: Di leaves dey add blood.

Text_en: Even if you go to this uh... kind of normal maternity, they do tell us that we should eat plenty of leaves, so this thing of ours, our blood, will be strong.
Text_ortho: Even if you go for dis dem ehn normal maternity of a ting, dem dey tell us make we take plenty of leaves so dat our dis ting, our blood go come.

Text_en: So, it is not only for the rich people as... even if you are as poor as anything, you can cook this gote.
Text_ortho: So is not only for di rich people as even if you are as poor as anyting, you fit make dis gote.

Text_en: Very little money, very little money.
Text_ortho: Very small money, very small money.

Text_en: If you have two hundred naira, or five hundred naira, you can cook gote for the household.
Text_ortho: If you have two hundred naira, or five hundred naira you can make gote for di househood.

Text_en: Buy these leaves o-... one hundred naira, two, two hundred; the garden eggs, fifty naira; hip-... spinach, fifty naira; the other leaves.
Text_ortho: Buy dis kashi o-... hundred naira, two, two hundred, di garden egg fifty naira, hip-... spinach fifty naira, di oder leaves.

Text_en: That is all.
Text_ortho: Dat is all.

Text_en: And the acha, a little.
Text_ortho: And di acha small.

Text_en: That is all.
Text_ortho: Dat is all.

Text_en: So it's very affordable.
Text_ortho: So is very affordable.

Text_en: You can afford it.
Text_ortho: You fit afford am.

Text_en: It's not expensive.
Text_ortho: E no dey expensive.

Text_en: So everybody can make this and have a good meal, a balanced diet, that at least won't hurt your wallet.
Text_ortho: So everybody can make dis, and have a good meal, balanced diet wey at least your pocket no go suffer.

Text_en: Hello, my people!
Text_ortho: Hello my people!

Text_en: It's me, Chibozor Chilaka.
Text_ortho: Na me Chibozor Chilaka.

Text_en: We're in Jettan right now.
Text_ortho: Na Jettan we dey so o.

Text_en: But I dont have much to say, but I will go ahead and say that life is not easy.
Text_ortho: But I no get much ting to say, but I go lead us go dis way sey life no dey easy o.

Text_en: You're supposed to know what's happening now in this country.
Text_ortho: Una suppose know wetin dey happen now for dis country.

Text_en: So many things are happening, but we will still thank God for life.
Text_ortho: So many tings are happen, but we go still tank God for life.

Text_en: No matter how hard life is, we should remember we have God.
Text_ortho: No matter how hard life dey, but meh we remember sey God dey.

Text_en: Because when we have God on our side, everything will keep moving forward, even though if you try to serve God, temptation will still be coming your way as the young man that you are, or the young woman that you are.
Text_ortho: Because when we get God by our side, everyting go dey move even dough if you try sey you wan serve God, temptation go still dey come your way as a young man wey you be, or a young girl wey you be.

Text_en: But what... you will still know that no matter how you try to do it, problems will still come your way.
Text_ortho: But wetin you go still know sey no matter how you try do am, problem go still come your way.

Text_en: But that does not mean you should give up.
Text_ortho: But dat one no mean sey una go give up o.

Text_en: And even, even though you are trying to serve God as the young man, or young woman that you are, people will still be telling you "what are you doing?"
Text_ortho: And even, even dough you dey try to serve God as a young man, or young girl wey you be, people go still dey tell you sey wetin you dey do?

Text_en: Are you sure of what you are doing?
Text_ortho: You sure of wetin you dey do?

Text_en: But's leave that aside for a moment.
Text_ortho: But moh leave dat one for now.

Text_en: Let's keep talking about what is happening.
Text_ortho: Moh still talk about wetin dey happen.

Text_en: Anything happening now in this life, right, you should first put... you must first involve God.
Text_ortho: Anyting wey dey happen now for dis life bah, meh first put, you must put God first inside.

Text_en: And, if you dont in-... involve God, by God, you are wasting your time.
Text_ortho: And, if you no put God insi-... inside wallahi, you dey waste your time.

Text_en: So whatever you are trying to do, you should... you should... you should try as a young person to be building things up.
Text_ortho: So anyting wey you dey try do, meh, meh, moh try as a youth dey build up tings.

Text_en: You know, let's try to be building our... to build our life up.
Text_ortho: You know moh try dey build our, build life up.

Text_en: Try to do things which we're supposed to do and we should remember that even in the uh... the Bible in, in Proverbs, it tells you that you should try to remember your Creator when you are young.
Text_ortho: Try dey do tings wey we suppose do so, and moh remember sey even for ehn Bible, for Proverb, e tell you sey meh try remember your creator when you dey young.

Text_en: Because if you dont serve God now, you dont know when you will serve him next.
Text_ortho: Cause if you no serve God now, you no know when next you go serve am.

Text_en: Will it be when you've grown old?
Text_ortho: Abi na when you don old?

Text_en: Because even though, if you remember well in the Bible, Cain and Abel... Cain... you're supposed to know how Cain, and Abel's case ended.
Text_ortho: Because even dough, if you remember for Bible well Cain, and Abel, Cain, you suppose know how Cain, and Abel own take end.

Text_en: Because Cain, he, he was a farmer, he gave God something thats not good while Abel, he gave God something good.
Text_ortho: Cause Cain, im, im be farmer, im give God wetin no good while Abel im give God wetin good.

Text_en: So, if Cain, and Abel could know what they were supposed to give to God, (one gave God something good and the other one did not give God something good), so now those of us who are youths, is it when we're old that we want to serve God?
Text_ortho: So if Cain, and Abel fit know wetin de suppose give God, (one give God wetin good, and one no give God wetin good), so now we wey con be youth, na when we old now we wan con serve God.

Text_en: But that does not mean... that does not mean that we will not live our lives as youth, but if we are living our lives as youth, we should still remember that there is God.
Text_ortho: But dat one no mean, dat one no mean sey we no go live our life as a youth, but if we dey live our life as a youth, moh we still dey remember sey God dey.

Text_en: He is in charge of everything we are doing.
Text_ortho: Im dey take charge of everyting wey we dey do.

Text_en: And anything we are doing now, in the future, we will still pay for it.
Text_ortho: And anyting wey we dey do now, for future, we go still pay for am.

Text_en: Whatever we eat now, whatever we drink now that enters our body, in the future, we will still pay for it.
Text_ortho: Any kind ting wey we eat now, anyting wey we drink now wey dey enter our body, for future we go fit still pay for am.

Text_en: Whether we drink, we smoke... we will still pay for it in the future.
Text_ortho: Wheder we dey drink, we dey smoke, we go still pay for am for future.

Text_en: So anything we are doing now in our days of youth, we should remember that life is still ahead of us.
Text_ortho: So anyting wey we dey do now for youth, moh remember sey life still dey front.

Text_en: You dont know what is ahead.
Text_ortho: You no know wetin dey happen for front.

Text_en: And to cut it short, let me talk about... let me talk about Nigeria's problems.
Text_ortho: And to cut long matter short, moh still talk about, moh still talk about Nigeria problem.

Text_en: So many things have been happening now because our government, they are really not doing what they're supposed to do for us.
Text_ortho: So many ting don dey happen now because our government, in true, true, no dey really do wetin dey suppose do for us.

Text_en: We all know that there are problems left and right.
Text_ortho: We all know sey problem dey up, right, left, and centre.

Text_en: We're talking about Boko Haram, we're talking about the IPO, we're talking about Oduduwa.
Text_ortho: We talk of Boko Haram, we dey talk of IPO, we talk of Oduduwa.

Text_en: So many things are out there now which even our government doesnt want to come out to tell us the truth about.
Text_ortho: So many tings dey on ground now wey even our government no wan come out con tell us di truth.

Text_en: It's been a long time since they told us that we are the leaders of tomorrow.
Text_ortho: E don tay wey de tell us sey we be leaders of tomorrow.

Text_en: But when are we going to become the leaders of tomorrow?
Text_ortho: But for when we wan become leader of tomorrow?

Text_en: Is it when we're old?
Text_ortho: Na when we don old.

Text_en: Now, if we look at it very closely, we dont have any youths today who are coming out to say that they want to run for anything.
Text_ortho: Now if we look very well, we no get any youth today wey dey comot say im wan con contest for anyting.

Text_en: Most of all, you will see us on social media.
Text_ortho: Highest, you go see us for social media.

Text_en: We are always playing with some phone, we are taking selfies, we are doing all kinds of things.
Text_ortho: We dey always press one phone, we dey do selfie, we dey do every kind of ting.

Text_en: Yes, that is good for those of us who are youths.
Text_ortho: Yes dat one good for we dat, wey be youth.

Text_en: Hey, I'm not saying that social media is bad.
Text_ortho: Tah I no talk sey social media dey bad o.

Text_en: It's good for us.
Text_ortho: E good for we.

Text_en: But, we s-... try our best, try to build ourselves up to become youths because if (like me) talk has never come out that I want to ru-... run for gover-... governorship now, you will tell me that I am a young man.
Text_ortho: But, make we s-... try our best, try build up oursef to become youth because if (like me) dey talk never comot say I wan con-... contest for gover-... governor now, una go tell me sey I be young man.

Text_en: That I haven't reached that age.
Text_ortho: Sey I never reach di age.

Text_en: If you dont vote for me, who else do you want to vote for?
Text_ortho: If una no vote for me, who else una wan vote for?

Text_en: It's the same leaders that are giving us the, the same recycling thing that's happening.
Text_ortho: Na di same leaders wey dey give us di, di same recycle ting wey dey happen.

Text_en: They will bring another man today.
Text_ortho: De go bring anoder man today.

Text_en: That man, if he doesnt rule, he will put forward his own child.
Text_ortho: Dat man, if e no rule, im go bring im own pikin.

Text_en: His own child will put forward his own child.
Text_ortho: Im own pikin go bring im own pikin.

Text_en: You and I would still be getting the same thing which we are getting.
Text_ortho: Me and you go still dey collect di same ting wey we dey collect.

Text_en: They never im-... improve our lives in any way.
Text_ortho: De no dey ever im-... improve our life in any way.

Text_en: So as youths let's try to build ourselves up.
Text_ortho: So make we as a youth try to build up oursef.

Text_en: Let's try and believe in ourselves, and let's try to support one another.
Text_ortho: Moh we try believe in oursef, and moh we try support each oder.

Text_en: Let's not look down on anyone who decides tomorrow that he wants to work for the betterment of this country.
Text_ortho: Moh no look down on anybody wey decide tomorrow sey e wan contest for di betterment of dis country.

Text_en: And mstchew another thing is that we, as youths, we need to be building ourselves up.
Text_ortho: And mtschew anoder ting be sey we as a youth, we need to dey build oursef.

Text_en: Schools are only... where we are going can't make us become better people because these schools are garbage in, garbage out.
Text_ortho: School dey only wey we dey go no fit make us become better people because dis school na garbage in, garbage out.

Text_en: This country for a long... how many years since we... they gave birth to us up until now?
Text_ortho: Dis country for long, how many years since when we, de born us up till now?

Text_en: Nothing is changing.
Text_ortho: Noting dey move.

Text_en: Instead, things have gone from bad to worse.
Text_ortho: Rader, tings dey dey bad to bad.

Text_en: Even our parents tell us that when they were much younger, things (back in their day) were better.
Text_ortho: Even our parent go tell us sey when de dey much younger, tings (during deir own time) dey better o.

Text_en: Now (we are here now), things are still not better for us.
Text_ortho: Now (we don reach now), our own tings still no dey better.

Text_en: Is this good?
Text_ortho: Na better ting?

Text_en: It's not good at all.
Text_ortho: No be better ting na, be dis now.

Text_en: If you go to other countries, they are progressing.
Text_ortho: If you go oder countries, de dey increase.

Text_en: They are doing research all the time.
Text_ortho: De dey do research every time.

Text_en: Things are always progressing for them day by day.
Text_ortho: Tings dey always increase for dem day by day.

Text_en: They always try to do things which will be better for them in the future.
Text_ortho: De always try to do tings wey go better for dem tomorrow.

Text_en: Even some people, in their countries, they are mostly using schools... people who are educated.
Text_ortho: Even some people, deir countries, de dey mostly use schools, people wey go school.

Text_en: Though maybe one department can decide to do some research.
Text_ortho: Dough maybe one department fit decide to do research.

Text_en: The research that student did, that is what will help the country.
Text_ortho: Dat research wey dat student do, na im go help di country.

Text_en: Before you know it, they have developed.
Text_ortho: Before you know, de don increase.

Text_en: Before you know it, other people will come around, to, to buy things for the, the same school!
Text_ortho: Before you know, oder people go come around, come, con buy tings for di, di same school o.

Text_en: It's from that school that they bring about development.
Text_ortho: Na dat same school na im dey bring about development.

Text_en: But here in Nigeria, nothing like that is happening.
Text_ortho: But for here for Nigeria, noting like dat dey happen o.

Text_en: If you and I do research, we will go to a computer... or we will go to a cyber caf, or we will go to our school lab to collect what someone else has done.
Text_ortho: If me, and you do research, na computer we go go, or we go go cyber cafe, or we go go our school lab go collect work wey person don do.

Text_en: To do the same old things which someone else has done.
Text_ortho: Dey do di same old ting wey person don do.

Text_en: We will still be doing the same thing.
Text_ortho: We go still dey do di same ting.

Text_en: So tell me how we want to progress today.
Text_ortho: So tell me how we wan take grow today.

Text_en: We will not be able to grow if this continues like this.
Text_ortho: We no go fit grow if dis ting continue like dis.

Text_en: So we need to hold our leaders accountable for everything they are doing for us.
Text_ortho: So we must hold our leaders accountable for everyting wey de dey do for us.

Text_en: Because if we dont hold them accountable, this country will not move forward.
Text_ortho: Because if we no hold dem, dis country no go move forward.

Text_en: And the problem with us is that we, we are afraid.
Text_ortho: And di problem wit we, sey we, we dey fear.

Text_en: If a man comes out today to say he wants to re-... do... he wants to start a revolution, this one will run out saying he is not involved.
Text_ortho: If one man comot today say e wan re-... do, e wan cause revolution, dis one go run comot say im hand no dey.

Text_en: If you go to other countries, developed countries, they dont hesitate the way we do, they only do what helps them develop.
Text_ortho: If you go for oder country, wheder developed countries, de no get two head wey we get o, only wetin help dem to develop demsef.

Text_en: They put religion aside, put (uh... what do they call it), ethnicity aside.
Text_ortho: De leave religious aside, leave (ehn wetin de call am) ethnicity aside.

Text_en: They just embrace one thing which is unity.
Text_ortho: De just embrace one ting which is unity.

Text_en: And that unity, is what... brought about that development for that country.
Text_ortho: And dat unity na bring about dat development for dat country.

Text_en: My name is Joy, Joy Jatto.
Text_ortho: My name na Joy, Joy Jatto.

Text_en: I work in this school where we are now.
Text_ortho: I dey work for dis school wey we dey so.

Text_en: I live in Bukuru.
Text_ortho: I dey live for Bukuru.

Text_en: I'm a native of Plateau State.
Text_ortho: I be indigene of Plateau State.

Text_en: I live in Bukuru with my parents.
Text_ortho: I dey live for Bukuru with my parents.

Text_en: Uh... this Jos, as you see it, is a very beautiful state.
Text_ortho: Uhn dis Jos, as you see am, na very beautiful state.

Text_en: The weather, we dont have any problem here.
Text_ortho: Di weather, we no dey get any problem for here.

Text_en: We have good weather.
Text_ortho: Better weather dey.

Text_en: The heat does not bother us at all.
Text_ortho: Heat no dey worry us at all.

Text_en: So, the people in Jos are very peaceful people, very friendly people.
Text_ortho: So, people wey dey Jos na very peaceful people, very friendly people.

Text_en: They dont look for trouble at all.
Text_ortho: De no dey look for wahala lailai.

Text_en: Uh... in my university, I studied French.
Text_ortho: Ehn for university wey I go, na French I read.

Text_en: So, I... then I got a job here.
Text_ortho: So, I con dey, I con get job for here.

Text_en: I work here.
Text_ortho: I dey work for here.

Text_en: Uh... we have plenty of the tourist sites in Jos.
Text_ortho: Ehn di tourist site wey we get for dis Jos plenty, many.

Text_en: We have the zoo, the wildlife park, the museum.
Text_ortho: We get di zoo, di wildlife park, museum.

Text_en: All those places, they are very beautiful.
Text_ortho: All dose places de are very beautiful.

Text_en: We can go to the zoo, go and see animals.
Text_ortho: We fit go di zoo, go see animal.

Text_en: Animals which have been there for a long time.
Text_ortho: Animals wey don tay.

Text_en: The elephant, it's even over a hundred years old.
Text_ortho: Elephant, e don pass hundred years sef.

Text_en: It's still there.
Text_ortho: E still dey dere.

Text_en: We have snakes.
Text_ortho: We get snakes.

Text_en: All those animals which you'd never expect, they are...
Text_ortho: All dose animals wey you never even expect, dem dey.

Text_en: They are in the zoo.
Text_ortho: Dem dey di zoo.

Text_en: And then in the museum, you will see a lot of pieces of art that are very beautiful.
Text_ortho: And den museum, you go see plenty, plenty artworks wey dey very beautiful.

Text_en: You will like them.
Text_ortho: Una go like am.

Text_en: It's fine.
Text_ortho: E fine.

Text_en: You can go there, go and buy things, take them home.
Text_ortho: Una fit go dere, go buy carry am go una place.

Text_en: Because in Jos, we have a lot of things.
Text_ortho: Because dis Jos too, we get plenty things.

Text_en: We also have uh... different cultures.
Text_ortho: We also get ehn different culture.

Text_en: For instance me, I am a Berom girl.
Text_ortho: Like me, na Berom girl I be.

Text_en: We are...
Text_ortho: We dey...

Text_en: Our cultural food is gote.
Text_ortho: Our cultural food na gote.

Text_en: This gote, they make it with acha.
Text_ortho: Dis gote, dem dey make am with acha.

Text_en: Even people who have diabetes... gote cures diabetes.
Text_ortho: People wey get diabetes sef, gote dey cure diabetes.

Text_en: It treats very many illnesses.
Text_ortho: E dey treat many, many sickness.

Text_en: People come from outside, just to come and see what we are using acha for.
Text_ortho: People dey come from outside just to come see wetin we dey carry acha dey do.

Text_en: We even use it to make pudding.
Text_ortho: We dey even carry am dey do pudding.

Text_en: We can make acha pudding.
Text_ortho: We fit make acha pudding.

Text_en: Add your milk to it, and sugar.
Text_ortho: Put your milk for inside and sugar.

Text_en: It will help you, and you will like it.
Text_ortho: E go help you, and you go like am.

Text_en: It's food for diabetic patients.
Text_ortho: Na food for diabetic patients.

Text_en: And if you dont want have uh... a big uh... belly like this (people who have a very big belly) if you are eating acha, it will help the belly, make it go flat.
Text_ortho: And if you no want to dey get ehn big ehn belle like dis people wey get big, big belle, if you dey chop acha, e go help di belle make e go inside.

Text_en: Acha is a very nutritious food.
Text_ortho: Acha na very nutritious food.

Text_en: You make it with plenty of vegetables.
Text_ortho: You dey make am with plenty vegetable.

Text_en: All those greens... you can buy them in the market.
Text_ortho: All dose green, you fit buy dem for market.

Text_en: And this Jos, we dont have any problem, as I told you.
Text_ortho: And dis Jos, we no get wahala like I tell una.

Text_en: Our market... our things are very cheap.
Text_ortho: Our market, our things are very cheap.

Text_en: If you go buy things in Katako market, if you want to buy cloth, the cloth is really, really cheap.
Text_ortho: If you go buy things for Katako Market, if you wan buy cloth, di cloth dey very, very cheap.

Text_en: You shouldn't go to a uh... shop or a supermarket.
Text_ortho: You must not go for uhn boutique, abi na any other supermarket.

Text_en: Go to Katako, buy your jeans, buy your shirt.
Text_ortho: Go to Katako, buy your jeans, buy your shirt.

Text_en: Really, really cheap.
Text_ortho: Very, very cheap.

Text_en: Buy your sweater.
Text_ortho: Buy your sweater.

Text_en: As you can see, this town, it is very cold, you should go to Katako to buy your sweater.
Text_ortho: As you see sey dis town, e dey very cold, you go Katako go buy your sweater.

Text_en: Very affordable.
Text_ortho: Very affordable.

Text_en: Even brands.
Text_ortho: With di label sef.

Text_en: You will see them there.
Text_ortho: You go see am for dere.

Text_en: Its a second-hand market.
Text_ortho: Na okrika market.

Text_en: You'll see a lot of nice things you'll want.
Text_ortho: You go see plenty fine, fine things wey you want.

Text_en: And you can buy them for cheap.
Text_ortho: And na small money you go carry buy am.

Text_en: We have different cultures in Jos.
Text_ortho: We get different culture for dis Jos o.

Text_en: Berom, Ngas... you know.
Text_ortho: Berom, Ngas you know.

Text_en: Ah, another food that Jos people like to eat, is dog.
Text_ortho: Ah another food wey Jos people dey like to dey chop, na im be dog.

Text_en: That meat... they like eating dog meat in this town.
Text_ortho: Dat meat, de chop dog meat well, well for dis town.

Text_en: Jos people really like dog.
Text_ortho: Jos people like dog.

Text_en: Ngas people, Berom people (my own tribe), we like eating dog.
Text_ortho: Di Ngas people, Berom people, my tribe sef, we dey chop dog well, well.

Text_en: But me, I don't eat it with them, but dog is considered meat where I'm from.
Text_ortho: But me I no dey follow chop o, but dog na meat for my place.

Text_en: Its a delicacy.
Text_ortho: Na better meat.

Text_en: We also have uh... (among the tribes which are in this place), we have the Mangu, we have uh... the Ankwai.
Text_ortho: We also get (ehm among di tribes wey dey dis place), we get Mangu, we get ehm Ankwai.

Text_en: Ankwai people, they drink burkutu a lot.
Text_ortho: Ankwai people, dem dey drink burkutu well, well.

Text_en: They are the ones who make burkutu.
Text_ortho: Na dem dey make burkutu.

Text_en: Burkutu is a kind of local beer that they make.
Text_ortho: Burkutu na dis kind local beer wey dem dey make.

Text_en: Oh, Ankwai people drink it a lot.
Text_ortho: Toh Ankwai people dey drink am well, well.

Text_en: Burkutu is very cheap here in Jos.
Text_ortho: Burkutu dey very cheap for dis Jos.

Text_en: It's a drink that if you drink it, and you dont eat, it can make you fall down.
Text_ortho: Na drink wey be sey if you drink am you no chop, e fit fall you for ground.

Text_en: But it's more the Ankwai people who drink it.
Text_ortho: But na Ankwai people dey drink am pass.

Text_en: Other tribes drink it too, but it's a local drink that Ankwai people are making, and it is very affordable.
Text_ortho: Any oder tribe sef dey drink am, but na local drink wey Ankwai people dey make am, and e dey very affordable.

Text_en: We have kunu, which we make, which is very medicinal as well.
Text_ortho: We get kunu wey we dey make, wey dey very medicinal too.

Text_en: That one is not alcoholic, it's not beer.
Text_ortho: Dat one, no be alcohol, no be beer.

Text_en: Everybody can have that one.
Text_ortho: Everybody fit take dat one.

Text_en: It doesnt need sugar, it doesnt need anything.
Text_ortho: E no dey put am sugar, e no dey put am anything.

Text_en: They use kunu, and there are different types of kunu.
Text_ortho: Dey use kunu, and di kunu dey of different types.

Text_en: There's one for which we use, (uh... this thing), to do it, tiger nuts.
Text_ortho: E get one wey we dey use ehm dis thing do am, tiger nut.

Text_en: We call it aya in Hausa.
Text_ortho: We dey call am aya for Hausa.

Text_en: That kunu is very nice.
Text_ortho: Dat kunu dey very, very sweet.

Text_en: You don't even put sugar in it.
Text_ortho: You no go even put sugar.

Text_en: You will use aya, you will use dabino to make the kunu.
Text_ortho: You go use aya, you go use dabino do di kunu.

Text_en: And it really helps people.
Text_ortho: And e dey help person well, well.

Text_en: If you drink it, you wont want to have, have sugar again.
Text_ortho: If you drink am, you no go wan taste, taste sugar again.

Text_en: Because that kunu, it is very very rich.
Text_ortho: Because dat kunu, e dey very, very rich.

Text_en: Uh... we make soup.
Text_ortho: Ehn we dey do soup.

Text_en: As soup, we have <hau> miyan kuka <hau>
Text_ortho: For our soup, e get miyan kuka.

Text_en: That kuka is very tasty.
Text_ortho: Dat kuka dey very sweet.

Text_en: We cook it with plenty of mil-... meat like that, which will make the soup tasty.
Text_ortho: We dey cook am with plenty mil-... meat like dat wey go make di soup sweet.

Text_en: Kuka.
Text_ortho: Kuka.

Text_en: We have <hau> miyan taushe <hau> which they make with um...
Text_ortho: We get miyan taushe wey dem dey make am with ehm...

Text_en: They use potash to make that soup too.
Text_ortho: Dem dey use potash dey make dat soup too.

Text_en: It makes the soup tasty.
Text_ortho: E dey make di soup sweet.

Text_en: Uh... there is masa.
Text_ortho: Ehn e get masa.

Text_en: Jos people make a lot of masa.
Text_ortho: Jos people too dey make masa.

Text_en: Our own masa, we can make it with rice, we can make it with corn.
Text_ortho: Our own masa, we fit make am with rice, we fit make am with corn.

Text_en: It depends on what you want to use it for.
Text_ortho: It depends on wetin you wan carry am do.

Text_en: Which one?
Text_ortho: Which one?

Text_en: You will just pick.
Text_ortho: You go just select.

Text_en: If it's the corn kind, you will make it.
Text_ortho: If na di corn own, you go make am.

Text_en: It is tasty.
Text_ortho: E dey sweet.

Text_en: If it's the rice kind, you will make it.
Text_ortho: If na di rice own, you go make am.

Text_en: People are buying it.
Text_ortho: People dey buy am.

Text_en: It is really nice.
Text_ortho: E dey very nice.

Text_en: Early in the morning in Jos, you will see people in joints eating masa like how, in other places, maybe they would be eating ewa [beans], or something else, like that.
Text_ortho: Early morning for Jos, you go see people for joint dey chop masa like di way wey for anoder place, maybe dem go dey chop ewa, or something else like dat.

Text_en: But in Jos, it's masa.
Text_ortho: But for Jos na masa.

Text_en: We have masa joints where people will just gather to buy, waiting in line, buying masa to eat.
Text_ortho: We get masa joint where people go just gather dey buy, dey queue, dey buy masa make dem chop.

Text_en: Even if you're in the office, some people buy it and take it to the office.
Text_ortho: Even if you dey office, some people dey buy am carry go office.

Text_en: Some will, from the office, send their boys, or go there themselves to buy masa, and kunu.
Text_ortho: Some from office go come send deir boys, or dem sef, dem go come dere go buy masa, and kunu.

Text_en: You will see them together.
Text_ortho: You go see dem together.

Text_en: You will buy drinks.
Text_ortho: You go buy drink.

Text_en: Kunu, there's one which they make with rice, as I told you, there are different kinds of kunu.
Text_ortho: Di kunu, e get di one wey dem dey make am with rice like I tell una sey different kinds of kunu dey.

Text_en: There's that one they make with tiger nuts, the one which they make with rice.
Text_ortho: Dat one wey dem dey make with tiger nut, di one wey dem dey make with rice, e dey.

Text_en: So, if you dont buy akara (which is the usual thing), you can buy and take masa and kunu.
Text_ortho: So if you no buy akara (wey be sey na di usual thing), you fit buy masa and kunu take.

Text_en: Eh myself, well my father, he is a policeman.
Text_ortho: Eh me, my fader sha, na police man im be o.

Text_en: I'm a policeman's daughter.
Text_ortho: I be police man daughter.

Text_en: So work... I came to this school.
Text_ortho: So na work I, carry me come dis school wey we dey.

Text_en: My parents are...
Text_ortho: Na my parents dey.

Text_en: My father is a policeman.
Text_ortho: My fader na police man.

Text_en: My mother, she is a businesswoman.
Text_ortho: My moder, na business woman she be.

Text_en: Even myself, I go into small scale businesses.
Text_ortho: Even me sef, I dey touch small, small business.

Text_en: I'm not just into teaching.
Text_ortho: No be only dis teaching work I dey do.

Text_en: I am also into business, selling shoes and bags.
Text_ortho: I still dey do my business, dey sell shoes, dey sell bag.

Text_en: Sometimes, I travel to Lagos to buy them and bring them here.
Text_ortho: Sometimes, I dey travel go Lagos, go buy dem come.

Text_en: You know that things in Lagos are also nice.
Text_ortho: You know sey Lagos tings, e dey also fine.

Text_en: I go there to bring the goods to Jos, and then sell to my people.
Text_ortho: Go carry am come Jos, come sell am for people.

Text_en: But if it's okirika [used] things, it looks like we have the best here in Jos because things are very cheap, your clothing... anything you want to buy.
Text_ortho: But if na okirika market, e be like sey we get di best for dis Jos because tings dey very cheap for your clothings, anyting wey you want buy.

Text_en: Children's clothes are also available, the used ones, you'll get them almost new.
Text_ortho: Even children cloth sef, for dat Okirika, you go get dem first grade.

Text_en: A lot of people go there to buy it.
Text_ortho: Plenty people dey go dere go buy.

Text_en: There are lots of fruit in this state.
Text_ortho: E get plenty fruit for dis state.

Text_en: You've noticed.
Text_ortho: Una don see am.

Text_en: We have fruit.
Text_ortho: We get fruit.

Text_en: We buy them really cheap.
Text_ortho: We dey buy dem very cheap.

Text_en: It's not expensive at all, never.
Text_ortho: E no cost at all lai, lai.

Text_en: Watermelons, oranges, bananas which... they are very cheap.
Text_ortho: Watermelon, orange, banana wey dey very cheap.

Text_en: So people don't get sick in Jos anyways because our weather is good, our food is good, and it's not expensive.
Text_ortho: So Jos people no dey sick anyhow sha because our weather good, our food good, and e no cost.

Text_en: Anybody can come to this...
Text_ortho: Anybody fit come to dis...

Text_en: You can... you can come to Jos to buy the fruit.
Text_ortho: You fit, you fit come dis Jos buy di fruit.

Text_en: You will enjoy it.
Text_ortho: You go enjoy am.

Text_en: And accomodation isn't costly in this town, at all.
Text_ortho: And accommodation for dis town, e no dey costly at all.

Text_en: Vistors... strangers can come anytime.
Text_ortho: Visitors, stranger fit come anytime.

Text_en: They don't pay much in rent.
Text_ortho: Di money wey dem dey pay for rent, e no cost.

Text_en: And the people of Jos... even if you don't know anyone and you are new in this town, you'll meet people who won't make fun of you.
Text_ortho: And Jos people, even if you no sabi anybody, you just enter dis town, you meet stranger, no go want carry you do yeye.

Text_en: They would want to help you, show you the way, show you a place you can stay.
Text_ortho: E go want help you, show you your way, show you where you fit stay.

Text_en: They would even tell you areas where accomodation is expensive and where it is cheap.
Text_ortho: E go even tell you where accommodation dey expensive, and which one dey cheap.

Text_en: That's who Jos people are.
Text_ortho: Na so Jos people dey.

Text_en: They are very peaceful.
Text_ortho: Dem dey very peaceful.

Text_en: They don't look for trouble!
Text_ortho: De no dey look for trouble o.

Text_en: They don't like to fight, or anything.
Text_ortho: De no dey like fight, or anyting.

Text_en: As you see, whether you are a Christian or a Muslim, we all live together.
Text_ortho: As you see, wheder Christian, Muslim o, we dey live togeder.

Text_en: We don't like trouble at all.
Text_ortho: We no dey like trouble at all.

Text_en: So Jos is a very beautiful state.
Text_ortho: So Jos na very beautiful state.

Text_en: I like this state.
Text_ortho: I like dis state.

Text_en: I like to stay in Jos.
Text_ortho: I like to dey stay for Jos.

Text_en: Even if I go to Lagos, the heat over there makes it uncomfortable for me to stay long because I'm already so used to this town.
Text_ortho: Even if I go Lagos, heat no dey gree me stay because I don dey use to dis town.

Text_en: This weather here is so beautiful.
Text_ortho: Dis our weather, na beautiful weather.

Text_en: And we don't like to leave it anyways because this is home.
Text_ortho: And we no dey like to dey leave am anyhow like dat because here na home.

Text_en: It's just like we're in America.
Text_ortho: E just dey like sey we dey America.

Text_en: It's not...
Text_ortho: E no...

Text_en: People say that if a guy from Jos goes to America, he won't have problems adapting because the weather also gets so cold here like...
Text_ortho: De say if Jos man go America, e no go suffer again because di cold wey dey here sef be like sey...

Text_en: I haven't been to America yet but the cold here is like what they describe in America.
Text_ortho: I never go America sha o, but di cold, e be like di one wey dem dey describe for America.

Text_en: So if someone leaves Jos for America, they can stay there because you're already used to the weather.
Text_ortho: So if person leave Jos go America now, e fit stay because you don dey use to di weather.

Text_en: Hm... about our hair, you know we have lots of hairstyles which we like to plait here in Jos.
Text_ortho: Hm for hair, you know sey we get plenty hairstyle wey we dey like to dey plait for dis Jos.

Text_en: We have exotic hairstyles.
Text_ortho: We get beriberi style.

Text_en: We plait our hair to the front, and to the back.
Text_ortho: De plait am front, and back.

Text_en: They will pack it like this, it's beautiful and really cheap.
Text_ortho: Dem go pack am like dis, e go fine, e dey very cheap.

Text_en: You'll see, our girls like it.
Text_ortho: You go see our girls dey make am.

Text_en: We don't really wear weave here.
Text_ortho: No dey too wear weavon for here.

Text_en: It's mainly plaiting.
Text_ortho: Na plaiting.

Text_en: People wear weave, but no-... not much.
Text_ortho: People dey wear weavon, but no-... not much o.

Text_en: Here, we plait our hair, mainly.
Text_ortho: Na plaiting we dey plait for here.

Text_en: Because plaiting here isn't expensive at all.
Text_ortho: Because to plait, for here, e no cost at all.

Text_en: And the people of Jos are experts in the hairdressing business.
Text_ortho: And Jos people sabi to make hair.

Text_en: In fact, before you go, I can show you where you can get your hair done.
Text_ortho: Before una go sef, I fit show una where una go fit go make una hair.

Text_en: You'll like it.
Text_ortho: Una go like am.

Text_en: It's really cheap, really affordable and it will last longer on you.
Text_ortho: E dey very cheap, very affordable, and e go last you.

Text_en: We do our hair now and leave it on for a month.
Text_ortho: We fit make hair now, carry am for one month.

Text_en: You'll still see it.
Text_ortho: You still see am.

Text_en: It'll still look neat.
Text_ortho: E go still dey new.

Text_en: Becaust they'll plait it very well.
Text_ortho: Because dem go plait am well.

Text_en: But in Jos, dressing hair... (just because hairdressing is the main business of the women here), you can't just call up your hairdresser and say you want to get your hair done.
Text_ortho: But Jos, to make hair (just because di hair sef, na im be di main business for women here), you no go fit just call your hairdresser sey you want go make hair.

Text_en: You'll need to book ahead of time because there's always a lot of people there.
Text_ortho: You go book her because people dey plenty for dere.

Text_en: There are many, many girls who dress hair in this place, but first you, you will book a space because the wait is mostly long.
Text_ortho: E get plenty, plenty girls wey dey make hair for here, but you, you go book first because di queue dey plenty most of di time.

Text_en: Do you see why I like Jos?
Text_ortho: See why me, I like Jos?

Text_en: Because life here is easy.
Text_ortho: Because life for dis place na jeje.

Text_en: No problems, no hustle and bustle like in Lagos, no heat, nothing.
Text_ortho: No wahala, no rushing like all dese Lagos, no heat, nothing.

Text_en: Even when it rains, you'll just notice that our weather is nice.
Text_ortho: Even as rain dey fall sef, you go just see sey our weather sweet.

Text_en: You don't have any problems.
Text_ortho: You no get any problem.

Text_en: Wo-... reach... uh... rashes won't appear on your body because the weather isn't hot.
Text_ortho: Wo-... reach, eh rashes no go dey comot for your body because heat no dey.

Text_en: The weather is good here.
Text_ortho: Na better weather dey here.

Text_en: I can't compare it with Lagos because there's too much heat over there!
Text_ortho: No go fit compare am with Lagos because heat too much for dat side!

Text_en: You'll see rashes, you'll see people's skin being affected with all kinds of things, but here, the weather is good on us.
Text_ortho: You go see rashes, you go see people skin dey spoil, but for here, di weather dey sweet us.

Text_en: We don't worry about rashes, or anything.
Text_ortho: We no dey worry for rashes, or anyting.

Text_en: With the way the weather is, we don't really put on makeup.
Text_ortho: As di weather dey sef, we no too dey do any makeup.

Text_en: And if you insist on putting on makeup, it wont get messed up.
Text_ortho: And if you say you go do your makeup, e no go spoil.

Text_en: You know that if the weather is too hot, it it messes up makeup, but here, people who wear makeup wear it for longer because the weather is cold.
Text_ortho: You know sey if heat too much, e dey spoil makeup, but for here, people wey dey do makeup, e go last dem because di weather dey cold.

Text_en: It's nice and it doesn't affect makeup.
Text_ortho: E dey good, and e no dey affect makeup.

Text_en: So myself, I love this Jos of mine a lot.
Text_ortho: So me, I like dis my Jos very well.

Text_en: Plateau State is the home of peace, and tourism, a beautiful place to be.
Text_ortho: Plateau State na home of peace, and tourism, a beautiful place to be.

Text_en: And I'm sure that before you leave, even if you go back home right now, you will feel like you've left a better place.
Text_ortho: And I sure sey before una go go, if una go back house now sef, una go dey feel am sey ah una don leave better place now.

Text_en: Because the weather... I know that you are feeling cold, but you are starting to get used to it by now.
Text_ortho: Because di weather, I know sey una dey catch cold, but by now una don dey use to am.

Text_en: Because we have good weather here.
Text_ortho: Because na good weather dey here.

Text_en: There are no problems with it.
Text_ortho: Dere is no any wahala about it.

Text_en: The people are very peaceful, very accommodating.
Text_ortho: Na very peaceful people, very accommodating.

Text_en: They will listen to you when you speak; if you need anything, even if you've lost your way, you will come across lots of people who will guide you.
Text_ortho: If you talk, dem go listen to you, if you want anyting, if you lost your way sef, you go see plenty people wey go guide you.

Text_en: Nobody wants to get money out of you.
Text_ortho: Nobody want collect your money.

Text_en: Nobody!
Text_ortho: Nobody!

Text_en: We don't have pickpocketing in Jos.
Text_ortho: We no dey do picking pocket for Jos o.

Text_en: It's hard.
Text_ortho: E dey hard.

Text_en: They don't do that here at all.
Text_ortho: No dey do dat one for here at all.

Text_en: They don't snatch people's bags in Jos anyhow.
Text_ortho: De no dey snatch people bag for Jos like dat.

Text_en: Hm'm!
Text_ortho: Hm'M!

Text_en: People are plenty happy with the little they have.
Text_ortho: Di people dey very okay wit di little wey dem get.

Text_en: They're a very peaceful people, and very accommodating.
Text_ortho: Na very peaceful people, and very accommodating.

Text_en: We are not that troublesome.
Text_ortho: We no get wahala like dat.

Text_en: That's what I want to tell you about Jos.
Text_ortho: Di ting wey I go tell una about dis Jos.

Text_en: Thank you very much!
Text_ortho: Tank you very much!

Text_en: Most people talk about why men watch football.
Text_ortho: Most people dey talk about why men dey watch football.

Text_en: In the first place, if you see a man watching football, most of the time...
Text_ortho: In di first place, if you see man dey watch football, most times...

Text_en: Typically, anyway, some women watch football.
Text_ortho: Typically, anyway some women dey watch ball.

Text_en: But you will see... maybe it's one in ten or two in ten.
Text_ortho: But you go see maybe na one out of ten, or two out of ten.

Text_en: Football fans are mostly men.
Text_ortho: Mostly, football fans na men.

Text_en: I sat down to think about it one day.
Text_ortho: I sidown tink am one day.

Text_en: In any house you go to, if you see the men in the house, if it's about time to broadcast a football match, they will say, "ah, there's a football match."
Text_ortho: Any house wey you go, if you see di men wey dey di house, if de wan show ball, de go say ah ball dey.

Text_en: They want to watch a match, they want to watch a match.
Text_ortho: De wan watch match, de wan watch match.

Text_en: The women will say no, no, they want... it's Zee World they want to watch, or they want to watch Big Brother, or something.
Text_ortho: Di women go say no no de wan, na Zee World de wan watch, or de wan watch Big Broder, or someting.

Text_en: Then they will start fighting over who holds the remote.
Text_ortho: De go come begin drag remote.

Text_en: You know, or someone will say, "ah, no, we have to watch the game."
Text_ortho: You know or you go see one person go say ah no, na ball we must watch.

Text_en: The others will go and sit down on one side, complaining.
Text_ortho: Di oder ones go go sit down one side dey complain.

Text_en: Saying, "what do these people even like about watching football matches?"
Text_ortho: Sey dis people, wetin de dey even see for dis ball?

Text_en: "Are they paying you?"
Text_ortho: De dey pay una?

Text_en: "Do you know the players?"
Text_ortho: You sabi di people wey dey play?

Text_en: Uh... a match that's got nothing to do with you, you'll sit down and want to kill yourself.
Text_ortho: Ehn ball wey no concern you, you go sit down, you wan kill yoursef.

Text_en: I sat down to think about it.
Text_ortho: I sidown tink am.

Text_en: What makes men enjoy watching football matches?
Text_ortho: Wetin make men like to dey watch ball?

Text_en: So I sat down and found three things I noticed about what makes men enjoy watching football matches, which is different from women.
Text_ortho: So I sit down, come bring out three tings wey I see wey make men like to dey watch ball wey dey different from women.

Text_en: I'm not saying anyone is right or wrong.
Text_ortho: No be sey I say anybody dey right, or e dey wrong o.

Text_en: But there are differences between men and women, which make men like football while the women don't really care for it.
Text_ortho: But e get differences wey dey between men, and women, wey make men like ball, wey women no too send am.

Text_en: And the first thing is that every man, right from when a male child is born (which means he's a small child), they're more competitive than women.
Text_ortho: And number one ting be sey every man right from when you born male pikin (wey be sey im na small pikin), de get dat hunger for competition pass women.

Text_en: It's in their nature.
Text_ortho: Na deir nature be dat.

Text_en: Once you have a male child, that yearning for competition is in his mind.
Text_ortho: Once you born male pikin, dat desire for competition dey inside im mind.

Text_en: He wants to test himself against his friends, and see that he is the best.
Text_ortho: E wan test imsef against im mate make im see sey na im comot as di best.

Text_en: That desire for competition is in us.
Text_ortho: Dat desire for competition dey inside us.

Text_en: And we grow up with it.
Text_ortho: And we dey carry am grow.

Text_en: Once, you notice that a man has grown to maturity, even if he himself cannot take part in competitions, he will want to watch the matches so he can say, "okay, these are the people I support".
Text_ortho: Once you see man don grow up, even if e imsef no fit take part for competition, e go wan watch make e say okay na dis people I dey support.

Text_en: And on the days they win, it will look like he's the who played and won.
Text_ortho: And di day wey de win, e go be like sey na im play ball win.

Text_en: That's why you see us.
Text_ortho: Dat'S why you dey see us.

Text_en: We discuss football.
Text_ortho: We dey talk ball.

Text_en: We will say, "ah, we beat these people, we beat those people."
Text_ortho: We go say ah we win dis people, we win dose people.

Text_en: You are a Chelsea fan; you are not a Chelsea fan, you weren't involved.
Text_ortho: You be Chelsea, you no be Chelsea, you no dey dere.

Text_en: You've never been near to their stadiums but you will say we are the ones, we are the ones.
Text_ortho: You never near deir stadium before, but you go say na we, na we.

Text_en: It's because we have identified with them.
Text_ortho: Na because we don identify wit dem.

Text_en: Why?
Text_ortho: Why?

Text_en: Because of the competitive nature which is in men.
Text_ortho: Because of dat nature of competition wey dey inside men.

Text_en: Secondly, every male child has that desire to see someone as his hero.
Text_ortho: Secondly, every male child get dat desire make e see somebody wey be im hero.

Text_en: Men want to have heroes.
Text_ortho: Men get desire for hero.

Text_en: They have that need to... for someone to look up to, who they want to be like, right from childhood.
Text_ortho: De get dat need to, for somebody wey de dey look up to, wey de wan be like right from small.

Text_en: That's why men, if you see them watching (even when they are younger), they like watching cartoons like Ben Ten, they like things like Superman, they like Batman, they like Spiderman.
Text_ortho: Dat is why men, if you see dem dey watch (even when de dey small), de like cartoon like Ben Ten, de like tings like Superman, de like Batman, de like Spiderman.

Text_en: Why?
Text_ortho: Why?

Text_en: Because these are people who do things against all odds, and they will come out as champions.
Text_ortho: Because dis na people wey dey do tings against all odd, and de go comot as Champion.

Text_en: This does something in a man's soul, and that's what makes us like watching football.
Text_ortho: Di ting get wetin e dey pull for inside man soul, and na wetin make us like to dey watch ball be dat.

Text_en: Because football gives us the heroes we look up to everyday.
Text_ortho: Because football dey give us hero wey we dey look everyday.

Text_en: People like Cristiano.
Text_ortho: People like Cristiano.

Text_en: We'll see people like Messi, you will see people like Neymar, we see boys like uh... either Juan Mata, or Lukaku.
Text_ortho: We go see people like Messi, you go see people like Neymar, we dey see boys like eh wheder na Juan Mata, or Lukaku.

Text_en: We see them.
Text_ortho: We dey see dem.

Text_en: And they are people who, even if we don't know anything about playing football, they represent us.
Text_ortho: And na people wey be sey even if we no sabi ball, de dey represent for us.

Text_en: Then, we will make them our heroes.
Text_ortho: We go come make dem our hero.

Text_en: And the third reason, every man wants to be a champion in something.
Text_ortho: And di third reason, every man wan be champion for someting.

Text_en: Even if you're not the one to take a ball with you to a field in order to play, you want to have that mentality that we got something done.
Text_ortho: Even if no be you carry ball enter field go play, you wan carry dat mentality sey we do someting.

Text_en: And we won, we achieved something, no matter the circumstances in which we found ourselves.
Text_ortho: And we win, we achieve no matter di circumstance wey we see oursef.

Text_en: We have conquered all the odds which came up against us.
Text_ortho: All di odds wey come against us, we don conquer dem.

Text_en: We have emerged as the champions.
Text_ortho: We don emerge as Champion.

Text_en: And that's what every man likes.
Text_ortho: And na wetin every man like be dat.

Text_en: So that's what makes men like to watch football more than women.
Text_ortho: So na wetin make men like to dey watch ball pass women.

Text_en: Because women... it's not that they don't like these things
Text_ortho: Because women no be sey de no like dis tings.

Text_en: But mstchew they don't really care about it.
Text_ortho: But mtschew de no too send am.

Text_en: Those kinds of things are not in a woman's psychology like they are in a man's.
Text_ortho: Dose kind tings no dey for woman psychology di way e dey for man own.

Text_en: So that's why women prefer to watch things which are calm, which have mild uh... stories.
Text_ortho: So dat's why women prefer to watch tings wey dey calm, wey get mild eh story.

Text_en: You wanna know something?
Text_ortho: You know someting wey be sey na gist?

Text_en: That's why they watch Zee World, because it's a story,
Text_ortho: Dat'S why de go watch Zee World because na story,

Text_en: That's why they watch Telemundo.
Text_ortho: Dat'S why de dey watch Telemundo.

Text_en: Why?
Text_ortho: Why?

Text_en: Because it's a story.
Text_ortho: Because na story.

Text_en: Not something where everythi-...
Text_ortho: No be tings wey be sey everyti-...

Text_en: In fact, if you look at most women... not all women like action movies.
Text_ortho: Infact, if you see most women, no be all women like action movie.

Text_en: They like calm things where they tell stories which have sweet endings... happy endings.
Text_ortho: De like someting wey dey calm wey be sey na story wey de dey tell, wey get sweet ending, happy ending.

Text_en: That's what women like to watch.
Text_ortho: Na wetin women like dey watch be dat.

Text_en: But men are different.
Text_ortho: But men mind dey different.

Text_en: So if we have this understanding between us, maybe women will stop harrassing men, saying, "why do men watch football matches?"
Text_ortho: So if we fit get dis understanding between oursef, maybe women go stop to dey harass say why men dey watch football?

Text_en: How is it that they can sit down and waste ninety minutes because you want to watch twenty-two boys kicking a ball around.
Text_ortho: Why be sey de go sit down burn ninety minutes talk sey you wan watch twenty two boys just dey dey kick ball up, and down?

Text_en: They don't understand.
Text_ortho: De no understand.

Text_en: If you sit down and think about it, you will be able to understand men.
Text_ortho: If you sit down tink am, you go fit get dat level of where man mind dey.

Text_en: Then you will let things be, saying "okay, I know how you feel, I know how you think."
Text_ortho: You go come leave am say okay I know wetin you dey feel, I know how you dey tink.

Text_en: "Sit down and watch your game."
Text_ortho: Sit down, watch your ball.

Text_en: "We don't mind."
Text_ortho: We no send you.

Text_en: "Go and enjoy yourself."
Text_ortho: Go do your own.

Text_en: "We'll do ours later."
Text_ortho: Later, we go do our own.

Text_en: Thank you very much!
Text_ortho: Tank you very much!

Text_en: Uhuh, there are two ways he used to cook Egusi.
Text_ortho: Ehen di method wey e take cook egusi, na two.

Text_en: Step one, method one, is this.
Text_ortho: Step one, method one, na im be dis.

Text_en: You will f-... you'll have ground your pe-...
Text_ortho: You go f-... you go don grind your pe-...

Text_en: When your pepper is ground, keep it!
Text_ortho: Your pepper wey don already grind, keep!

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Now, the pepper is kept to the side.
Text_ortho: Di pepper now, e dey one side.

Text_en: Your fish, everything, you will wash it and keep it like that.
Text_ortho: Your fish, everyting, you go wash am keep like dat.

Text_en: And your Maggi [seasoning] (you'll have already crumbled the Maggi), keep it!
Text_ortho: And your maggi (you go don already crumble di maggi), drop am!

Text_en: Then you will (on your stove), put it on the burner... put your pot on the burner.
Text_ortho: Den you go (on your gas) put am for fire, put your pot for fire.

Text_en: When you have set your pot on the burner, uh... pour in palm oil.
Text_ortho: If you put your pot for fire, eh you add up red oil.

Text_en: When you've poured in palm oil, you will let it mstchew... let it heat up a little.
Text_ortho: If you add red oil, you go allow am, mtschew go allow am hot small.

Text_en: When it's heated up a little, just pour in your onion.
Text_ortho: If e don hot small like dat, you just put your onion.

Text_en: After you have poured in your onion, pour in your pepper.
Text_ortho: After you put your onion, you pour your pepper.

Text_en: When you have poured in your pepper, stir it.
Text_ortho: If you pour your pepper, you stir.

Text_en: After stirring, then you'll pour in water, add your Maggi, add your fish, put in everything.
Text_ortho: After you stir, you go con pour water, put your maggi, put your fish, put everything.

Text_en: Put in all your okporoko [stockfish].
Text_ortho: Put your okporoko dem.

Text_en: Put it in!
Text_ortho: Put am!

Text_en: After you've put it in, cover it so that it can boil a little.
Text_ortho: After you put am, you cover am make e boil small.

Text_en: When it's boiled, then put in your egusi.
Text_ortho: If e boil, you go con put your egusi.

Text_en: The egusi you have already ground and put aside, you will add it.
Text_ortho: Di egusi you don already grind keep, you go con put am.

Text_en: But if it has... if you want it be lumpy, you will do something like press it.
Text_ortho: But if e get, if you wan make e do seed, seed, you go like press am.

Text_en: Press the egusi so that oil will come out.
Text_ortho: Press di egusi so dat oil go comot!

Text_en: If oil comes out, you will start putting it in the sauce as if you are making crumbs in the sauce, like that.
Text_ortho: If oil comot now, you go start dey put am for di soup like sey you dey make crumbles inside di soup like dat.

Text_en: When you've put it in the sauce like that, you will cover it for a period of ten to fifteen minutes.
Text_ortho: If you don put am inside di soup like dat, you cover am for like ten to fifteen minute.

Text_en: When it's done, you will put in your ugwu [fluted pumpkin], or waterleaf.
Text_ortho: After e don, you go con put your ugwu, or waterleaf.

Text_en: Whatever leaf vegetable you have, just put it in.
Text_ortho: Any leaf wey you just get, you just put am on top.

Text_en: Leave it for a minute or so.
Text_ortho: Leave am for like one minute or so.

Text_en: The egusi sauce, it is ready.
Text_ortho: Di egusi soup, e don ready.

Text_en: That's step one.
Text_ortho: Dat's step one.

Text_en: That's step one, method one.
Text_ortho: Dat one na step one, method one.

Text_en: Another method to you cook egusi sauce your egusi, it will...
Text_ortho: Anoder method wey you dey carry cook egusi soup, your egusi, e go.

Text_en: The ground egusi, you will make it... turn it into paste.
Text_ortho: Di grounded egusi, you go make am, turn am to paste.

Text_en: You will add water.
Text_ortho: You go put water.

Text_en: Just a little water!
Text_ortho: Small water o!

Text_en: Just a little water like that, you will add it that way.
Text_ortho: Dat kind small water like dat, you go put am like dat.

Text_en: Like you will stir it, stir it, stir it.
Text_ortho: Like you go stir am, stir am, stir am.

Text_en: Keep it on the side!
Text_ortho: Keep am for one side!

Text_en: You will put oil in a pot.
Text_ortho: You go put oil for pot.

Text_en: Instead of putting pepper in directly, like in the other method, this time around, it's the egusi you will pour directly into that oil which is already hot.
Text_ortho: Instead of putting pepper direct like di oder method, dis time around now, na di egusi you pour direct for dat oil wey don hot.

Text_en: Now, as that oil has heated up, and since you have poured in your egusi, you will just be stirring it.
Text_ortho: Now, as dat oil don hot, now wey you don pour your egusi, you go just dey stir am.

Text_en: You will be stirring it till it starts to burn.
Text_ortho: You go dey stir am till di ting burn.

Text_en: You will see that the thing is well fried.
Text_ortho: You see sey di ting don fry well, well.

Text_en: In fact, it is starting to burn.
Text_ortho: E don dey even burn sef.

Text_en: Then, you will pour in water.
Text_ortho: You go con pour water.

Text_en: You will pour in water and you will add your pepper.
Text_ortho: You pour water inside, you put your pepper.

Text_en: Now, you will pour in your ingredients, your pepper, your fish, your, your stock, your okporoko.
Text_ortho: Now, you go con, you pour your ingredient, your pepper, your fish, your, your stock, your okporoko.

Text_en: If you like, you can put in bitter leaf.
Text_ortho: If you like, you fit put bitter leaf.

Text_en: When you've added it and you've added your Maggi, you will cover it so it can boil.
Text_ortho: After you put am, you don put your maggi, you cover am if e boil.

Text_en: When it's boiled, then put in your leafy vegetable.
Text_ortho: Sey e don boil, den you put your leaf.

Text_en: When you have put in your leafy vegetable, and you notice that it's done, bring it down!
Text_ortho: When you put your leaf, sey e don do, bring am down!

Text_en: Your egusi's ready.
Text_ortho: Your egusi, e don ready.

Text_en: Then ogbonno.
Text_ortho: Den ogbonno.

Text_en: Ogbonno sauce.
Text_ortho: Ogbonno soup.

Text_en: Ogbonno sauce is very easy to cook, you know.
Text_ortho: Ogbonno soup dey very, very easy to cook you understand.

Text_en: In fact, ogbonno... like some people... some people will be frying their pepper before they do the ogbonno.
Text_ortho: Ogbonno sef, like some people, some go dey fry deir pepper before de do di ogbonno.

Text_en: But the method which everyone uses, well, around here, in this area of ours... you'll put water on the burner.
Text_ortho: But di method wey everybody dey use sha, for dis side, for dis our area, you put water for fire.

Text_en: When you've put water on the burner, you'll add your pepper, your Maggi, your stockfish, your crayfish, your ponmo, everything.
Text_ortho: After you put your water for fire, you put your pepper, your maggi, your stockfish, your crayfish, your ponmo, everything.

Text_en: Uh... you know your assorted meat, you'll add it all.
Text_ortho: Eh you know your orisirisi, you go don put am.

Text_en: When you've put it all in, you'll put in your Maggi, and cover it.
Text_ortho: After you put am, you put your maggi, den cover am.

Text_en: Leave it to boil.
Text_ortho: Allow am make e boil.

Text_en: Then your egusi... your ground ogbonno... sorry, your ground ogbonno, you will mix it with oil.
Text_ortho: Den your egusi, your grounded ogbonno, sorry your grounded ogbonno, you mix am wit oil.

Text_en: You'll mix it until it's like a paste.
Text_ortho: You go mix am to like paste.

Text_en: Get out your oil, then you will put it in that... the water.
Text_ortho: Withdraw oil, den you put am inside dat, di water.

Text_en: It will boil, it will dissolve in the water.
Text_ortho: E go boil, go scatter for inside di water.

Text_en: When it's boiled, you'll notice that...
Text_ortho: When e boil, you see sey...

Text_en: Because when it's boiled, it draws, everything will be normal.
Text_ortho: Because when e boil now, e start dey draw, everyting go just normalise.

Text_en: Then, your ugwu, or your...
Text_ortho: Den, your ugwu, or your...

Text_en: Yes, your ugwu which has been washed already, you will add it.
Text_ortho: Yes, your ugwu wey e dey washed already, you go con put am.

Text_en: Just after a minute, bring it down.
Text_ortho: Just after one minute, you bring am down.

Text_en: Your ogbonno is ready.
Text_ortho: Your ogbonno, e don ready.

Text_en: That's all.
Text_ortho: Dat is all.

Text_en: My name is Jacob from Kaduna.
Text_ortho: My name na Jacob from Kaduna.

Text_en: When I grew up with my grandfather, he was the one taking care of me.
Text_ortho: When I grow up wit my grandfader, na im dey take care of me.

Text_en: My parents are in Lagos.
Text_ortho: My parents dey for Lagos.

Text_en: That's where I stayed.
Text_ortho: Na dere I dey stay.

Text_en: They brought me to Kagoro.
Text_ortho: De carry me come Kagoro.

Text_en: And I grew up there.
Text_ortho: And I was dere, grow up.

Text_en: He enrolled me in a secondary school... he enrolled me in a primary school.
Text_ortho: Im put me for secondary school, im put me for primary school.

Text_en: All the schools.
Text_ortho: All di schools.

Text_en: And I was very happy with him.
Text_ortho: And I was very happy with im.

Text_en: So much that he supports me in everything I do.
Text_ortho: Wey, everyting wey I dey do na im dey do am for me.

Text_en: And when he... when I grew up, when I was about to get married, he was... he announced the name of a woman I don't know as my wife to be.
Text_ortho: And when e, when I grow up, when I about to marry, e was, e pronounce a wife for me, which I don't know.

Text_en: And at the time put forth by God, the wife came, as foretold by my grandfather.
Text_ortho: And di time reach wey be sey (God don say dis di time wey my grandfader talk am) di wife came.

Text_en: And the way I got married at that time is not the... same as they do nowadays.
Text_ortho: And di way I marry dat time, no be di so de, de dey do nowadays.

Text_en: Now, they give so much money.
Text_ortho: Now, na plenty, plenty money de dey give.

Text_en: At that time, myself, I gave a bride price of two thousand naira.
Text_ortho: Dat time, me, na two thousand naira I give as bride price.

Text_en: In fact, they collected it saying they will... were very happy.
Text_ortho: Even de collect am say de go, were very happy.

Text_en: But nowadays, if you don't bring a goat, twenty bags of uh... cement, uh... twenty bags of uh... salt, rice, everything!
Text_ortho: But now, if you no bring goat, twenty bags of eh cement, eh twenty bags of eh salt, rice, everyting!

Text_en: Even with a donkey, they'll say to bring one.
Text_ortho: Wit donkey sef de say de may bring!

Text_en: With a duck!
Text_ortho: Wit duck!

Text_en: Look how the world is!
Text_ortho: See how di world be!

Text_en: Is that how things will go on?
Text_ortho: Na so we go carry everyting go?

Text_en: How will the next gene... generation be?
Text_ortho: How di gene-... generation go be?

Text_en: Maybe they will be asked to build houses for their parents.
Text_ortho: Maybe de go say meh de build house for dem parents.

Text_en: We pray for God to help us in this generation, for things to get better.
Text_ortho: We pray dat God will help us in dis generation, dat tings will come better.

Text_en: And nowadays, even the women, maybe the men are not the ones looking for them.
Text_ortho: And nowadays, even women now, maybe no be men dey go look for dem.

Text_en: Women are the ones looking for wom-... mow-... men, nowadays.
Text_ortho: Na women de go look for wom-... mow-... man now.

Text_en: They want to get married by force.
Text_ortho: De wan marry by force.

Text_en: I pray that God will help us look within ourselves so we'll see better things in life; for God to continue to be with us, and guide us.
Text_ortho: I pray dat God will help us, for us to search oursef to see better ting in life, for God to continue to be wit us, and guide us.

Text_en: And another thing is women don't compose themselves... they don't compose themselves.
Text_ortho: And anoder ting again, women don't compose deirsef, de didn't compose deirsef.

Text_en: They don't compose themselves at all.
Text_ortho: De don't compose deirsef at all.

Text_en: If they compose themselves, dress well, look very beautiful, from there, men...
Text_ortho: If de compose deirsef, dress fine, look very fine, na dere men...

Text_en: When we come back and see them, and say we want to marry them.
Text_ortho: When we go come back, and see dem, and say de wan marry dem.

Text_en: But we have different traditions.
Text_ortho: But we have different tradition.

Text_en: The Southerners have their traditions, as do the Northerners and the Middle Belters.
Text_ortho: Di South have deir own tradition, di North have deir own tradition, di Middle Belt has deir own tradition.

Text_en: Some are, are, are conservative about it.
Text_ortho: Some, dey, dey, dey do am small, small.

Text_en: Some spend a lot of money on it.
Text_ortho: Some dey do am wit plenty money.

Text_en: So we don't know how we will bring things together.
Text_ortho: So we don't know how we go bring tings togeder.

Text_en: Maybe God will help us reverse all these things, so we will come together as a family, as Nigerians, to help one another do things as God will help us, that we will be uh... very happy with it.
Text_ortho: Maybe sey God go help us to reverse all dese tings dat we will come togeder as one family, as Nigerians, to help one anoder to do tings di way God will help us dat we will be eh very happy wit it.

Text_en: That's the way it is.
Text_ortho: Na so we see am o.

Text_en: But uh... the question I want to ask is, "how will Nigerians come together?"
Text_ortho: But ah di question wey I wan ask be sey how will Nigeria come togeder?

Text_en: Such that we'll have a common bride price, that we (will) become one, that we...
Text_ortho: Wey be sey we go do, put dis bride price togeder dat we become one, dat we...

Text_en: In some places, parents won't be burdened while in some other places, they will be burdened.
Text_ortho: Anoder place, parent will not suffer am, anoder place, go suffer am.

Text_en: In a lot of places, if you don't bring a lot of things, they won't give her to you.
Text_ortho: Some many places, if you no carry plenty tings come, de no go give you.

Text_en: They will say you should build a house for them.
Text_ortho: De go say make you build house for dem.

Text_en: In some, some pla-... places again, they will say, "just take her!"
Text_ortho: Some, some pla-... place again, de go say just carry go!

Text_en: They give her to you.
Text_ortho: De don give you.

Text_en: So how can we bring this thing together, and help ourselves?
Text_ortho: So, how can we bring dis ting togeder, and help oursef in life?

Text_en: Oh!
Text_ortho: Oh!

Text_en: We thank God that in His infinite mercy He will help us... will really help us.
Text_ortho: We tank God dat God in infinite mercy go help us, go help us well, well.

Text_en: He knows that these things will get better, and change us in Nigeria.
Text_ortho: E see sey dese tings go become better ting in life, and change us in Nigeria.

Text_en: And we pray that God will hel-... give us good people who will listen to us.
Text_ortho: And we pray dat God will hel-... give us better people wey go hear us.

Text_en: And they will hear about all these things, so that they will come together and make sure we have good things in Nigeria.
Text_ortho: And all dese tings, de will hear dem for dem to come togeder, and see sey we do better ting for Nigeria.

Text_en: Thanks be to God!
Text_ortho: Tank God!

Text_en: And in many of the places we see now, in our hospitals, a lot of people are sick.
Text_ortho: And many places wey we dey see now, our hospital, many people are sick.

Text_en: Sometimes, there are no drugs.
Text_ortho: Sometimes, no medicine.

Text_en: They will still be there.
Text_ortho: De go dey dere o.

Text_en: Problems.
Text_ortho: Wahala.

Text_en: Problems.
Text_ortho: Wahala.

Text_en: No one will be able to go to the hospitals again because there's no money.
Text_ortho: Nobody go, fit go hospital again because no money.

Text_en: By money, I mean that some can afford food, some cannot.
Text_ortho: Money be sey some fit eat, some no fit eat.

Text_en: Some can afford to pay hospital bills while some cannot pay hospital bills.
Text_ortho: Some fit pay hospital bill, some no fit pay hospital bill.

Text_en: How can we resolve these things in this country?
Text_ortho: How can we resolve dis in dis country?

Text_en: We pray our God will help us... pray that God will help us.
Text_ortho: We pray our God will help us, pray dat God will help us.

Text_en: And our leaders, they should make sure that they help the poor ones do things that will help us in life.
Text_ortho: And our leaders, meh de kuku see sey de help di poor one to do tings dat will help us in life.

Text_en: Our doctors are going on strike again.
Text_ortho: Our doctors again, de dey go strike.

Text_en: People are dying.
Text_ortho: People dey die.

Text_en: So where are we heading?
Text_ortho: So where are we heading oursef to?

Text_en: Where are we heading?
Text_ortho: How are we heading oursef to?

Text_en: Doctors as well, have mercy on us.
Text_ortho: Doctors too have mercy upon us.

Text_en: And also the government, they should make sure that the doctors are paid.
Text_ortho: And di government too, de should see sey de pay di doctors.

Text_en: They should come... they should help the poor, they should reduce the high cost of drugs for our sake.
Text_ortho: Meh de come, make de help di poor, make de reduce medicine money for us.

Text_en: For those of us who can't pay so much money, they should please help us... they should please help us... they should please help us.
Text_ortho: We dat can not pay plenty money, abeg meh de help us, meh de help us o, meh de help us.

Text_en: And we will move on to schools as well.
Text_ortho: And we will go to school again.

Text_en: With schools, if you are not rich, you will not have access to quality education.
Text_ortho: School, if you no get money, you no go get better school.

Text_en: The primary level, if you are not rich, some people cannot even even afford pay five hundred naira.
Text_ortho: Primary, if you no get better money, even five hundred naira, some people no fit pay.

Text_en: Some parents can't afford to pay five hundred naira, not to mention two hundred naira.
Text_ortho: Some parent no fit pay five hundred naira talk less of two hundred naira!

Text_en: We pray that God will help us because we are looking to God to provide everything we say... we are praying for.
Text_ortho: We pray God will help us because everything wey we say, we dey pray for, na God we dey look for.

Text_en: And when God touches their, their hearts, they will look to the poor.
Text_ortho: And when God touch deir, deir heart, de go look unto di poor.

Text_en: We pray for God to help us.
Text_ortho: We pray God will help us.

Text_en: Even the way we eat, money for food, money, money, you can't even afford to buy a bit of rice.
Text_ortho: Even di way we eat, food money money, money, you can not even buy a mudu of rice.

Text_en: They will tell you that a measure of rice costs six hundred naira.
Text_ortho: De go tell you sey mudu of rice na six hundred naira.

Text_en: What work will a guy do to make six hundred naira for a measure of rice?
Text_ortho: Which work man go go do get six hundred naira go buy mudu of rice?

Text_en: Not to mention the other stuff you put in.
Text_ortho: You no talk of di ting wey you go put inside.

Text_en: You will buy Maggi seasoning, pepper, and tomatoes.
Text_ortho: You go buy maggi o, buy tattasai o, buy tomato o.

Text_en: Onions, how much will you pay?
Text_ortho: Onion, how much you go pay?

Text_en: How much will you make?
Text_ortho: How much you go get?

Text_en: You have many children, twelve children, six children, seven children, on your small measure of rice, one measure will not be enough for them.
Text_ortho: You get plenty children, twelve children, six children, seven children, your mudu of rice, one no go fit do dem.

Text_en: And even if you worked, payments won't be made.
Text_ortho: And if you work sef, no payment.

Text_en: So many of the people who have quit work are dying.
Text_ortho: Plenty, plenty people wey don resign, de die.

Text_en: No payments.
Text_ortho: No payment.

Text_en: Salaries are not being paid.
Text_ortho: Salary, de no pay.
