Text_en: Everywhere, etin-... everything is hard.
Text_ortho: Everywhere, etin-... everyting hook.

Text_en: So, what do they want us to do?
Text_ortho: So, what do de want us to do?

Text_en: And many of the things which have been happening is because ritual activities have taken over the country.
Text_ortho: And many tings wen de bin come be sey rituals don enter country.

Text_en: Cases of kidnapping are everywhere for the purpose of making money.
Text_ortho: Kidnapping everywhere because of money.

Text_en: A government is paying all these things X for, for the staff, giving them everything.
Text_ortho: It is a government dey pay all dese tings X, for, for di staff, give dem everyting.

Text_en: At least, everything for the better.
Text_ortho: At least, everyting for better.

Text_en: They caught someone there, caught someone there, shot everybody, killed everybody.
Text_ortho: De catch person dere, catch persons dere, shoot everybody, kill everybody.

Text_en: So, where are we going... where are we going... where are we going?
Text_ortho: Toh, where are we going, where are we going, where are we going?

Text_en: The military men who says they are... they are the ones guiding us, they are killing them.
Text_ortho: Soldier man wey de say de dey, na dem dey guide us, de dey kill dem.

Text_en: So, we don't love one another.
Text_ortho: Toh, we no love one anoder.

Text_en: There are problems, problems, problems everytime.
Text_ortho: Everytime wahala, wahala, wahala!

Text_en: Where do you want us to run to?
Text_ortho: Where una wan us run to?

Text_en: Should we leave Nigeria for you?
Text_ortho: Make una leave Nigeria for una?

Text_en: Or should we leave Nigeria for the people doing these things?
Text_ortho: Abi dose wey dey carry dis ting do, make we leave Nigeria for una?

Text_en: If we leave Nigeria for you, how many people will stay behind?
Text_ortho: If we leave Nigeria for una, how many people will stay?

Text_en: Eyinaya Family, will you be able to stay in Nigeria?
Text_ortho: Eyinaya Family, will you be able to stay in Nigeria?

Text_en: Just you?
Text_ortho: You alone?

Text_en: It can't be possible.
Text_ortho: E can not be possible.

Text_en: God, help us so that our soldiers will also help us.
Text_ortho: God, help us dat even our soldiers will help us.

Text_en: Take a look at the rains!
Text_ortho: See rain!

Text_en: Drain everywhere!
Text_ortho: Drain everywhere!

Text_en: Floods wash away people's belongings, floods are taking people's lives.
Text_ortho: Water dey carry people load, water dey kill people.

Text_en: No good roads, no standard drainages.
Text_ortho: No better road, no better drainage.

Text_en: Everything, problems.
Text_ortho: Everyting, wahala.

Text_en: God, help us... God, help us!
Text_ortho: God, help us, God, help us!

Text_en: Let our X leaders listen to us!
Text_ortho: Let our X, leaders hear us o!

Text_en: Let them hear God's voice and do the... what they were assigned to do.
Text_ortho: Make de hear God voice o, and do di, dat ting wey dey carry dem dere.

Text_en: They warned them to be good.
Text_ortho: De warn dem make de do better ting.

Text_en: Not, not that they should, should take care of themselves alone and leave the poor to die.
Text_ortho: No be, no be sey make, make de chop alone, leave di poor, and make de die.

Text_en: If the poor die, who will they govern?
Text_ortho: If di poor die, who de go govern?

Text_en: No one!
Text_ortho: Nobody!

Text_en: We pray that God will help them to see these things, and also help us.
Text_ortho: We pray dat God will help dem to see dis tings, and help us.

Text_en: Uh... my name is John Nkemjika Nwobo.
Text_ortho: Ehn my name na John Nkemjika Nwobo.

Text_en: I come from Imo State.
Text_ortho: I come from Imo State.

Text_en: Well my people, I mean, things are difficult.
Text_ortho: Well my people, as in things no easy now o.

Text_en: Because uh... I remember, that in Jonathan's era, everyone was just showing off, but things are difficult under this Buhari regime.
Text_ortho: Because ehn I remember, dat Jonathan time o, everybody just dey flex, but dis Buhari regime, things no easy at all.

Text_en: I wanna... I'm just wondering what will happen within, I mean the citizens, in the next ten years.
Text_ortho: I wanna, I just dey wonder wetin go happen within as in di citizen in di next ten years.

Text_en: The way things are going now, it's not funny at all.
Text_ortho: As things dey go now, things no funny at all.

Text_en: Um... like if you think back to the Jonathan era, contracts were awarded and people had work to do.
Text_ortho: Ehm like if you think dat time of Jonathan, contract dey come out, people dey work.

Text_en: Well um... they were giving out things, people were travelling.
Text_ortho: Well ehm, dem dey give out tin, people dey travel.

Text_en: Traveling is very easy, but nowadays, it's like nothing is happening.
Text_ortho: To travel is very easy, but now, tins just dey like sey nothing dey happen.

Text_en: I wonder what's happening in Nigeria right now.
Text_ortho: I wonder wetin dey happen with Nigeria for now.

Text_en: Well my friend, I really believe that the situation in this country nowadays is something uh... we all need to get together and talk about.
Text_ortho: Well my broder, I really believe sey di situation of dis country now, na something eh all of us need to gather together, talk about am.

Text_en: We all need to get together, talk about it, figure out how we will solve our problems.
Text_ortho: All of us need to gather together, talk about am, know how we go take solve our problem.

Text_en: Because, we cannot leave... let Americans come and solve our problems.
Text_ortho: Because, we no fit leave, let Americans come solve our problem.

Text_en: We need to do it by ourselves.
Text_ortho: We need to do am within ourselves.

Text_en: When, when you talk about um... the students now, for you to... um... it's not easy for you to get into school now.
Text_ortho: When, when you talk about ehm di student now, for you to, ehn for you to get admission now, e no easy.

Text_en: You need to struggle.
Text_ortho: You need to struggle.

Text_en: You will take...
Text_ortho: You go write...

Text_en: You will come across people who didn't take... who didn't even take the examination, you will see them get in while you who rested... struggled to sit for the Post UME and everything else... you need to stay back and, and then you need to say, "okay, go ahead...."
Text_ortho: You go see people wey no write, no even write exam, you go see dem just enter, but you wey rest, struggle write post UME and every oder thing, you need to stay back and, and den you need to say okay de go like.

Text_en: You have to struggle beforehand if you don't have anyone to help you.
Text_ortho: You have to struggle before if you don't have anybody.

Text_en: That's how this country is.
Text_ortho: Na so di country just be now.

Text_en: So if you want anything in Nigeria now, you need to be well connected.
Text_ortho: So for you to get anything for Nigeria now na just connection.

Text_en: In fact, the other day, I had... I went to uh... a party with my girl.
Text_ortho: Even di oder day sef, I get, I go ehn party with my madam.

Text_en: As soon as we went into the hall of the event, the women just started asking me who invited me.
Text_ortho: As we enter hall, naim, di woman come dey ask me who I follow come?

Text_en: I had to tell her that it was a certain woman before she would give me a plate of rice!
Text_ortho: I tell am sey na one madam before she give me plate of rice!

Text_en: Imagine!
Text_ortho: Imagine!

Text_en: Even getting a plate of rice in Nigeria now involves connections.
Text_ortho: To even get plate of rice for Nigeria now, na connection.

Text_en: Uhm!
Text_ortho: Uhm!

Text_en: It's not easy at all, but...
Text_ortho: Di thing no easy at all but...

Text_en: Well man, what I am really thinking of uh... the country is that we should just find means ( I mean, know how) things we will do to solve our present problems.
Text_ortho: Well bro, wetin me I just dey really think of ehn di country now na make we just find way (as in know how), things we go take solve our problem for now.

Text_en: Because if we are waiting for our government, they will not help us.
Text_ortho: Because if we dey wait for our government, dem no go help us.

Text_en: And also, my fellow youths like me also...
Text_ortho: And also my fellow youths like me also...

Text_en: And I also advise them when it comes to...
Text_ortho: And I dey also advise dem when it comes to...

Text_en: Like our guys who are into the fraudulent acts known as Yahoo, and other stuff like that, that stuff doesn't pay at all.
Text_ortho: Like our guys wey dey do yahoo, and oder stuff like dat, dose stuff no dey pay at all.

Text_en: That stuff doesn't pay.
Text_ortho: Dose things no dey pay.

Text_en: I noticed some guys recently, they will tell you that this guy riding this car is no superhero.
Text_ortho: I notice some guys now, de will tell you sey dis man wey dey ride dis car no get two heads.

Text_en: Myself, I want to be like him.
Text_ortho: Meself wan be like am.

Text_en: But all those things don't add value.
Text_ortho: But all dose things no dey pay.

Text_en: We need to like... just identify what we can do on our own.
Text_ortho: We need to like just know wetin we fit work on our own.

Text_en: Like if you go to China now, you will see young boys... they're the ones making these phones we use; they send them to us and we buy them.
Text_ortho: Like if you go China now, you go see young boys now, all dese phone wey dey use, na dem dey do am, bring send for us, we dey buy.

Text_en: Because all those cars we use were designed by young boys like us.
Text_ortho: Because all dose cars wey we dey use, na young boys like us dey design am.

Text_en: But here in Nigeria, we're always going into fraudulent acts called Yahoo and/or oil bunkering, and the like.
Text_ortho: But for Nigeria here, wetin we dey always take na yahoo, and, or oil bunkering, and di rest.

Text_en: Uh... but I sure know that those, those things don't pay at all.
Text_ortho: Ehn but I know sure sey dose, dose ones no pay at all.

Text_en: So uh... we just have to work hard, then think ahead, and come up with solutions to our problems.
Text_ortho: So ehn na just for us to work hard, den think further, and know how we fit take solve our problem.

Text_en: For instance, just now, I remember when I worked with an Indian man.
Text_ortho: Like as I dey now, I remember o when I work with one Indian man.

Text_en: I, I tried to save a bit of money and bought a small car, which I used for commercial purposes.
Text_ortho: I, I try save small money, come buy one small motor, come use am dey do taxi.

Text_en: That was uh... four back... four years back, but one of my guys made the comment, "man, this is beneath you!"
Text_ortho: Dat was ahm four back, four years back, but one of my guy come dey like guy, you no suppose dey do dis kind thing!

Text_en: But I told the guy that it's just... with time, and perseverance, things will surely be alright.
Text_ortho: But I con like advise di guy say na just with time, and perseverance, and things go surely dey okay.

Text_en: It was through that taxi that I met...
Text_ortho: Na through dat taxi I come meet...

Text_en: As we speak... through that taxi, I met the HR Manager of Total, the Mr Didebey from France.
Text_ortho: As me and you dey talk now, through dat taxi I meet di HR manager of Total, di Mr Didebey from France.

Text_en: And since I met that man, things have changed in my life.
Text_ortho: And since I meet dat man, things don somehow change for my life.

Text_en: The man advised me on education, the man has guided me.
Text_ortho: Di man don advise me about education, di man don talk to me.

Text_en: He told me that he himself went through what I am going through at the moment.
Text_ortho: Tell me sey imself pass through wetin me I dey pass now.

Text_en: But he later excelled in life.
Text_ortho: But im later excel in life.

Text_en: But I should just continue to do my things the way I believe it should be done, and God will really see me through.
Text_ortho: But make I just continue to do my own things di way wey I believe am, and God go really see me through.

Text_en: Even as you and I are talking, the man has gone back to France.
Text_ortho: Even as I, me, and you dey talk now, di man don go back France.

Text_en: But the man still...
Text_ortho: But di man still...

Text_en: But everyday, he and I chat on WhatsApp.
Text_ortho: Yet everyday me, and am dey chat on WhatsApp.

Text_en: He calls me.
Text_ortho: E dey call me.

Text_en: He still introduces me to people who will be able to like assist me uh... maybe when I graduate, so that I can get uh... a good job that will change my life.
Text_ortho: E still dey like push me to people wey go fit like assist me ehn maybe when I don graduate so dat I fit get ehn good job to change my life.

Text_en: So that's how life is.
Text_ortho: So na so just life be.

Text_en: Life isn't really easy.
Text_ortho: Life no really easy.

Text_en: And I don't believe that if you were born poor, you will remain poor.
Text_ortho: And I no believe sey if your parent born you, you no get anything, you go remain like dat.

Text_en: It depends on how, how you struggle, and how you want to really help yourself.
Text_ortho: E depend how, how you struggle, and how you wan really help yourself.

Text_en: Well, when you... when people say that people like Dangote, Otedola, and the rest... that it's because... that it's... I don't believe it.
Text_ortho: Well, when you, when people talk sey na people like Dangote, Odetola, and di rest, sey na because, sey na, I no believe.

Text_en: Because if you read Dangote's history, and all those rich men of today, the way they started, yourself, you will wonder whether...
Text_ortho: Because if you read di history of Dangote, and all dose rich men today, di way wey dey take start, you self, you go wonder whether...

Text_en: I mean, you will just imagine that it was not their parents who laid the foundation for them.
Text_ortho: As in you go just imagine sey no be deir parents lay di foundation for dem.

Text_en: It's just they... something they really wanted to do, and how they would work things out in their lives, to ensure they live a better life.
Text_ortho: Na just de, something wey de really want do, and how dey want take work out things for deir life to make a better life for dem.

Text_en: So I really believe that when you believe in yourself, you'll really make it in life.
Text_ortho: So I really believe sey when you believe in yourself, you really make am in life.

Text_en: You don't need to depend on anyone.
Text_ortho: You no need to depend on anybody.

Text_en: You don't need to... you don't need like...
Text_ortho: You no need to, you no need like...

Text_en: Since maybe because your parents didn't give birth to you, your parents are poor, that's why you are poor.
Text_ortho: Since maybe because your parents no born you, your parents no get money, na im make you poor.

Text_en: Don't, don't think like that.
Text_ortho: Meh, meh you no think like dat.

Text_en: It's all those negative thoughts that will really push you backwards.
Text_ortho: Na all dose negative thinking go really push you back.

Text_en: So uh... about my parents, I thank them for bringing me into this world, and I am aware of the situation at hand, and uh... all... everything I need to do is to work hard in order to ensure that my younger ones, or my unborn children will not go through what I'm going through.
Text_ortho: So ehn as for my parents, I thank dem sey de bring me come dis world, and I don see how things be, and ehn all, everything wey I need to do now, na to work hard to make sure sey my junior ones, or my future children no go pass through wetin me, I pass through.

Text_en: My name is Adeniyi Moruf Mustapha.
Text_ortho: My name na Adeniyi Moruf Mustapha.

Text_en: Uh... my... I, I... my State is Oyo State.
Text_ortho: Eh my, I, I, my state na Oyo State.

Text_en: Although I was born in Lagos and everything about me is in Lagos, I do it... I, I attended uh... CMS [Church Missionary Society] Primary School, which is in Bariga.
Text_ortho: Aldough na Lagos dem born me, and everyting about me, na Lagos I do am, I, I go to eh CMS primary school wey dey Bariga.

Text_en: And uh... from there, I attended uh... CMS Grammar School, which is also in Bariga.
Text_ortho: And eh from dere too, I go to eh CMS grammar school wey dey Bariga too.

Text_en: And myself, where I am staying is very close to... is very close to Bariga.
Text_ortho: And even me sef, where I dey stay, very close to, e dey close to Bariga.

Text_en: So Bariga is not my birth place!
Text_ortho: And so I no be Bariga born o.

Text_en: Ab-... I mean, I am not a ga-... Bariga boy.
Text_ortho: Ab-... as in I no be ga-... Bariga boy.

Text_en: But in one way or the o-...
Text_ortho: But one way, or di o-...

Text_en: Uh somehow, somehow I will say uhuh, I am with Bariga in a way... in a way.
Text_ortho: Eh somehow, somehow I go say ehen I dey wit Bariga somehow, somehow.

Text_en: So there was a time that my father felt I was not doing well in CMS where I was.
Text_ortho: So e get one time wey be sey my papa feel sey I no do well for CMS wey I dey.

Text_en: Then he decided to take me to uh... a boarding school.
Text_ortho: E come look say okay make im carry me go eh boarding school.

Text_en: Maybe that will help me improve.
Text_ortho: Maybe dat one go help me take improve myself.

Text_en: So I went to...
Text_ortho: So I go to...

Text_en: Then he took me to Ibadan.
Text_ortho: Den e come carry me go Ibadan.

Text_en: So I went to Emmanuel College High School.
Text_ortho: So I go Emmanuel College High School.

Text_en: Uh... from there... I spent only one year.
Text_ortho: Eh from dere I spend only one year.

Text_en: Afterwards, it looks like he was not really happy with the thing.
Text_ortho: After, e be like sey di ting no come sweet im belle well, well.

Text_en: Then he said, okay, it looks like I, I, I, I n-... I, I still wasn't performing like he wanted.
Text_ortho: E come say, okay e be like sey I, I, I, I n-... I, I still no do wetin im want make I...

Text_en: That's m-... uh... I mean, my result happened to show that I was not up to the standard I should have been.
Text_ortho: Dat'S m-... eh as in be sey, my result say di ting never dey kajad as e suppose be.

Text_en: So he brought me back to Lagos.
Text_ortho: E come carry me come back come Lagos.

Text_en: Then I went to a Muslim School.
Text_ortho: Den I come go one Muslim School like dat.

Text_en: The name is Toyyibat Comprehensive High School.
Text_ortho: Di name na Tayyibaat Comprehensive High School.

Text_en: And that was where I finished my Secondary School education.
Text_ortho: And na dere I come finish my secondary school.

Text_en: But what I will remember... why...
Text_ortho: But di ting wey I go remember, why...

Text_en: Because I studied...
Text_ortho: Because I studied...

Text_en: Uh... I studied Accounting in school.
Text_ortho: Ehm I read accounting for school.

Text_en: But if I remember well enough what led me into studying this subject... because the thing that, that I really wanted to do was Electrical Engineering.
Text_ortho: But wetin I go remember wey make me read dis course, because di ting wey, wey really sweet my belle make I do for my life, na electrical engineer.

Text_en: Because I remember that I used to get my hands into everything uh... electrical when I was a kid.
Text_ortho: Because I remember dat time when I dey small, everyting wey concern eh electric, na im I dey put hand.

Text_en: And I, I really love the job.
Text_ortho: And I, I like di job well, well.

Text_en: So he called me this one day.
Text_ortho: So e come get one day, e come call me.

Text_en: When I was...
Text_ortho: When I dey...

Text_en: I think I was in Senior Secondary School [SS] One.
Text_ortho: E be like sey I dey SS one.

Text_en: He called to ask what profession I would like to go into.
Text_ortho: E come call me sey wetin be di job wey I wan do?

Text_en: If I... If I wanted to go to school...
Text_ortho: If I, if I want go school...

Text_en: And myself uh... when, when...
Text_ortho: And me eh when, when...

Text_en: Before he took me to Ibadan, I was in CMS.
Text_ortho: Before im carry me go Ibadan, I dey CMS.

Text_en: B-... uhuh... before he took me to Ibadan, when I was in CMS, I...
Text_ortho: B-... ehen before im carry me go Ibadan, when I dey CMS, I...

Text_en: After my uh... JSS three, when I came back, I was about to start SS.
Text_ortho: After my eh JSS three wey I come, I want enter SS.

Text_en: So I remember that I didn't... I didn't continue.
Text_ortho: So I remember sey I no, I no resume.

Text_en: Maybe I may...
Text_ortho: Maybe I may...

Text_en: What I can... I can say I was responsible for is that I did not resume for the SS [Senior Secondary] classes on time.
Text_ortho: Di ting wey I go fit, wey I go fit talk sey e cause am be sey I no resume SS one on time.

Text_en: So by the time I decided to resume studying, the science class which should have led me into the path of Electrical Engineering was already in full swing.
Text_ortho: So by di time wey I go say make I go resume, di science class wey suppose put me for electrical, de don start.

Text_en: So when I attended classes with them for like uh... almost... nearly a month had passed already, mstchew!
Text_ortho: So when I come stay dere for like eh almost, one month don nearly knock mtschew!

Text_en: I just felt like I wasn't understanding what they were doing.
Text_ortho: I just observe sey e be like sey I no grab wetin de dey do.

Text_en: I just took my chair to uh... art... uh... art class.
Text_ortho: I just carry my chair go eh art eh, art class.

Text_en: No.
Text_ortho: No.

Text_en: Art class!
Text_ortho: Art class!

Text_en: So I was done with the second term when my dad called me.
Text_ortho: So after wey I don finish second term, naim my papa come call me.

Text_en: And I know that what t-... led to this again was that there was no one to tell me that if you want to do such and such thing, don't leave the...
Text_ortho: And I know sey di ting wey t-... cause am too again be sey nobody wey go fit tell me sey, if you want do so, so, so ting o, no comot for.

Text_en: So since I had moved into the art class, he asked, "what exactly do you want to do?"
Text_ortho: So as I don go art class, e come ask sey wetin you want do sef?

Text_en: Then I said electrical engineering.
Text_ortho: I come say na electric.

Text_en: He said uh... "you are fooling yourself!"
Text_ortho: E say eh you dey fool yourself!

Text_en: "Electrical engineering?"
Text_ortho: Electrical?

Text_en: "And you are in art class?"
Text_ortho: And you dey art?

Text_en: He said, "you've missed it, that means you won't be able to go for it."
Text_ortho: E say you don miss am, na, na im be sey you no go fit go.

Text_en: He said I should think of uh... anything... another thing I will be able to do, which will be in line with my current class.
Text_ortho: Sey make I tink of eh anyting, anoda ting wey I go fit do, wey go relate to di class wey I dey now.

Text_en: Then I said it's banking, and finance.
Text_ortho: I come say na banking, and finance.

Text_en: He said he didn't like banking and finance.
Text_ortho: E say im no like banking, and finance.

Text_en: It will just tie me to one place.
Text_ortho: Sey di tin go just tie me for one place.

Text_en: I won't be able to...
Text_ortho: I no go fit...

Text_en: That I'll only be in the bank, and uh... these people who are into money, money things, mstchew.
Text_ortho: Sey na only bank, and eh dese people wey de do money, money tin, na dere I go dey mtschew.

Text_en: So he said...
Text_ortho: So he now said...

Text_en: In fact, it was my father who picked accounting for me.
Text_ortho: In fact na my papa choose dis account for me.

Text_en: Because he felt that with accounting, you can work anywhere.
Text_ortho: Because im feel sey account, you fit work for anywhere.

Text_en: So from there, when I finished in uh... in Toyibat... luckily, when I finished in two thousand and... nineteen ninety four, by nineteen ninety five, early uh... in uh...
Text_ortho: So from dere, when I come finish for, eh for Tayyibaat, luckily, when I finish in two thousand and, nineteen ninety four, by nineteen ninety five, early eh in eh...

Text_en: When it was (uh... I think) January nineteen ninety five, or ninety... in February, I got into Oko Polytechnic.
Text_ortho: When e don reach (eh I tink) January nineteen ninety five, or ninety February, I enter Oko Poly.

Text_en: Oko Polytechnic is a small school in Anambra State.
Text_ortho: Oko Poly na small school for Anambra State.

Text_en: Uh... Federal Polytechnic, Oko... I had my ND [National Diploma] education there.
Text_ortho: Eh Federal Polytechnic Oko, na dere I come do my ND.

Text_en: Then I had my uh... IT [Industrial Training] in a Federal, Federal Ministry.
Text_ortho: Den I do my eh IT for one Federal, Federal ministry like dat.

Text_en: After which I came to Yaba Tech, for my HND.
Text_ortho: Den after which I come go Yaba Tech, go do my HND.

Text_en: And I...
Text_ortho: And I...

Text_en: It was accounting I studied.
Text_ortho: Na di accounting wey a-... I read all through.

Text_en: Then, later, I went to Imo for my Service.
Text_ortho: Den later, I go serve for Imo.

Text_en: But there was a time I had a fire accident.
Text_ortho: But e get one time wey I get fire accident.

Text_en: So I still had the injury I got from that fire accident when I reported for service.
Text_ortho: So dat fire accident injury still dey my body when I go serve.

Text_en: So... and because I didn't want to stay there, I wrote a letter to them saying I have uh... medical issues.
Text_ortho: So and because I no wan stay for dat side, I come write letter give dem say see o, I get eh medical challenge o.

Text_en: So they should post me back to...
Text_ortho: So sey meh dem return me back to...

Text_en: That was how the whole thing worked out fine.
Text_ortho: Na so di tin come jell.

Text_en: I was posted back to Lagos.
Text_ortho: De come return me back to Lagos.

Text_en: So I finished my, my uh... service in Lagos.
Text_ortho: So I finish my, my eh service for Lagos.

Text_en: Then, my father was someone who really loved education.
Text_ortho: Den my papa na somebody wey be sey e love book well, well.

Text_en: He loved education, which means that the... he knew he made a mistake by not... by not putting me in the right place from the beginning.
Text_ortho: Love book, wey be sey di, e know sey im do mistake for not, for not putting me for right place from beginning o.

Text_en: But after that, he started monitoring my education.
Text_ortho: But after dat time, im come dey follow me for my education.

Text_en: Said he wanted... he wanted to make sure that this profession I'm in, the highest... the, the level which anyone who is into this course reaches, reaches, you will also get there and he will not let me rest.
Text_ortho: Sey im wan, im want make sure sey dis one wey I dey do, di highest, di, di level wey person wey do dis course dey dey, you go reach am, and im no dey leave my neck.

Text_en: So I got uh... a job in Lagos State.
Text_ortho: So I come gain eh job for Lagos State.

Text_en: But when I got to Lagos State, the salary wasn't great.
Text_ortho: But when I come reach Lagos State, di salary no good.

Text_en: And if you want to go for that kind of course, it requires a lot of money.
Text_ortho: And if you want do dat kind course, na money.

Text_en: And my father mstchew, he didn't as have much on him as when he... when we were little.
Text_ortho: And my papa mtschew, tings no dey im pocket like, as e dey when im, when we dey small.

Text_en: So he b-... he was like "you've started working, right?
Text_ortho: So e b-... e feel say shebi you don dey work?

Text_en: "You, you, you are able to... you are able to support yourself to, you know, wherever you want to go."
Text_ortho: You, you, you fit, you fit sponsor yourself go (you know) where you want go.

Text_en: So he has been on my neck since then because I started this job in two thousand, and one.
Text_ortho: So e come dey my neck since because I enter dis job for two thousand, and one.

Text_en: So he was on my neck.
Text_ortho: So e come dey my neck.

Text_en: So every year, he will be telling you haven't taken your ICAN [Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nigeria] exams.
Text_ortho: Every year like dat, im go dey tell me sey you never do your ICAN.

Text_en: That you're, you're just like someone who... you're in a pool with everyone else.
Text_ortho: Sey you are, you just be like person wey all of una dey inside water.

Text_en: If you... if you qualified as a member of ICAN, that means you'd stand out from the others.
Text_ortho: If you, if you get your ICAN, na im be sey your own head go comot pass every oda person head.

Text_en: He kept giving me that until one day when one mir-... when there was a miracle in my life.
Text_ortho: Im dey give me dat until one day, one mir-... one day wey miracle come happen for my life.

Text_en: Because anytime I want to start this exam, I get held back by a lack of money.
Text_ortho: Because anytime wey I want start dis exam, na money dey tie me down.

Text_en: I don't have money.
Text_ortho: I no dey get money.

Text_en: I even met with my boss saying, "boss, please lend me some money so I can start this thing!"
Text_ortho: I even go meet my oga say oga, abeg, borrow me some money make I take start dis tin!

Text_en: He said uh... said uh... he didn't know what I wanted to do with the ICAN thing.
Text_ortho: E say ehn, say ehn im no know wetin me dey go do for di ICAN tin.

Text_en: That people who do ANAN can also make it.
Text_ortho: Sey people wey dey do ANAN, de dey make am.

Text_en: In fact, at that time, I had even given up saying, "okay, let me do this ANAN."
Text_ortho: Pa-... infact, dat time, I even don give up say okay make I do di ANAN.

Text_en: Then I was told that I would need to wait another eight months before I could join ANAN.
Text_ortho: De come tell me sey I go need to wait for anoda eight month before I go fit join ANAN.

Text_en: So I figured instead of waiting for eight months, why don't I just start the uh... ICAN?
Text_ortho: Naim I come look say ehe for me, to dey wait for eight month, why not kukuma start dis eh ICAN?

Text_en: This particular one, I can start right away.
Text_ortho: Dis one, I fit start am now.

Text_en: That's what took my mind off ANAN.
Text_ortho: Na im make me comot my mind for ANAN.

Text_en: So I waited for two years after that before I could get money.
Text_ortho: So I come stay two years after dat time, before I come even get money.

Text_en: How did it happen?
Text_ortho: How di tin come happen?

Text_en: That day, I just got married.
Text_ortho: Dat day, I just marry.

Text_en: I got married in two thousand, and eight.
Text_ortho: I marry two thousand, and eight.

Text_en: My, my first kid was born in two thousand, and nine
Text_ortho: My, my first pikin, for two thousand, and nine.

Text_en: So I can remember that on a particular Sunday when my ki-... mstchew, when there was no money to eat.
Text_ortho: So I could remember dat e get one Sunday like dat wey my pik-... mtschew wey money no dey to even chop dat day.

Text_en: I was just staring blankly.
Text_ortho: I come dey look.

Text_en: Ah God, I said, "what kind of life is this?"
Text_ortho: Ah God, I say which kind life be dis?

Text_en: So from that point, I also believed that mstchew... this job I'm doing isn't what I'm meant to be doing.
Text_ortho: So from dere, me too believe sey mtschew dis job wey I dey do no be di job wey I suppose to dey do.

Text_en: That if I just got my ICAN certificate now I could leave this place and go to another company, where I will get paid better.
Text_ortho: Sey if to say I don get dis ICAN now, I fit comot here go anoda company wey be sey go dey fetch me better money.

Text_en: Mstchew, so I was thinking on that particular day.
Text_ortho: Mtschew so dat day, I come dey tink.

Text_en: So I got to the office on Monday.
Text_ortho: So for Monday, I come reach office.

Text_en: And I am not bragging.
Text_ortho: And no be sey I dey brag.

Text_en: I'm the hardworking type.
Text_ortho: I be type wey be sey I dey hardworking.

Text_en: But on that day, I was restless and mtschew... I couldn't do much.
Text_ortho: But dat day, di tin come affect me, wey be sey mtschew I no fit do much.

Text_en: Okay.
Text_ortho: Okay.

Text_en: I was in the office, working.
Text_ortho: I just dey office dey do my work.

Text_en: And then one, one of my...
Text_ortho: Naim one, one of my...

Text_en: The woman is older than me, but I am her senior...
Text_ortho: Di woman senior me, but I senior am...

Text_en: She is older than me in age, but my rank at work is higher than hers.
Text_ortho: E senior me for age, but I senior am for level.

Text_en: So she told me uh... Mr Mustapha, will you take part in this uh... this uh... I dont know what... how they call it... these uh... monthly money contributions where someone will collect all the money contributed this month and another will collect...
Text_ortho: E come tell me sey eh Mr Mustapha wheda I go do dis, eh dis eh I no know wetin, how dem dey call am, dis eh contribution wey be sey somebody go carry dis month, anoda person go carry?

Text_en: I said, "look, mstchew... I don't have time."
Text_ortho: I say wo, mtschew I no get time.

Text_en: Me, how much money will I make?
Text_ortho: Me, wey be sey how much be my salary?

Text_en: Eleven thousand naira.
Text_ortho: Eleven thousand naira.

Text_en: So now I'll get into this kind of mstchew...
Text_ortho: Naim I go come put head for dis kind mtschew...

Text_en: So on second thought, I reconsidered it and thought okay.
Text_ortho: So on a second, I come look say okay.

Text_en: I figured that uh... even if I don't... if, if it's not my turn the first month, I can beg the person who is to collect the first one.
Text_ortho: I come tink am sey ah even if I no, if, if no be my turn for dis first time, I fit beg person wey be first time.

Text_en: He should give me his own portion.
Text_ortho: Make e give me im own portion.

Text_en: When it's my turn, he will collect it.
Text_ortho: When e come to my turn, im go carry am.

Text_en: At least, I should take...
Text_ortho: At least, make I take...

Text_en: Maybe this will help me start the ICAN examination.
Text_ortho: Maybe dis one go help me start di ICAN.

Text_en: So mstchew... I said, "okay, I will take part in it."
Text_ortho: So mtschew I come say okay, I go do.

Text_en: So they said we will pick numbers.
Text_ortho: So de come say na through ballot we go pick.

Text_en: So they put num-... they wrote numbers on a paper.
Text_ortho: So de come put num-... de come put number for paper.

Text_en: They rolled them up and put them in a plastic container.
Text_ortho: Roll am, put am for one plastic.

Text_en: They asked us to start picking the numbers.
Text_ortho: De say make we dey pick.

Text_en: When it was...
Text_ortho: When e don...

Text_en: When the third person picked, then they all said that... the remaining two people said that if I don't pick...
Text_ortho: When di third person don pick, naim all of dem come talk sey, di remaining two come talk sey if I no pick...

Text_en: That they... if I don't pick mine, they would not pick theirs.
Text_ortho: Sey de, if I no pick, de no go pick.

Text_en: Mstchew, I just prayed to God saying, "God, I am in your hands!"
Text_ortho: Mtschew I just pray to God sey God, I dey your hand o!

Text_en: So I picked mine.
Text_ortho: I come pick.

Text_en: So when we all picked the numbers, we started showing the numbers.
Text_ortho: So after wey all of us don pick, we come dey show.

Text_en: Everyone started opening the papers, saying uh... someone picked second.
Text_ortho: Everybody come dey open say ah one person pick second.

Text_en: I said, "uh... supposing I was the one who picked the second number, I would have loved it."
Text_ortho: I say eh if to say na dat seconds, I for like am o.

Text_en: Another person picked number five.
Text_ortho: Anoda person pick five.

Text_en: Then I was asked to accept my fate.
Text_ortho: Naim dem say make I gba.

Text_en: I said, "oh, why do you want me to open mine now?"
Text_ortho: I say oh why be sey you want make I open my own now?

Text_en: They said, "why?"
Text_ortho: De say why?

Text_en: As soon as I opened it, number one.
Text_ortho: As I just open like dis, number one.

Text_en: That was how I started my ICAN exams that time.
Text_ortho: Na so my ICAN start dat time.

Text_en: So I met with my father.
Text_ortho: So I come go meet my papa.

Text_en: I told him "you were the one who wanted me to start these exams."
Text_ortho: Tell am sey na you want make I start dis tin o.

Text_en: I have thirty thousand and I want to start lectures.
Text_ortho: I don get thirty thousand, and I wan start lecture.

Text_en: I need i-... fifty five or so.
Text_ortho: I need i-... fifty five something.

Text_en: Then he, he wrote me a check that day.
Text_ortho: E come, e come write check give me dat day.

Text_en: That's how I just started.
Text_ortho: Na so I just start.

Text_en: And under... wi-... eh... within two years, I made it.
Text_ortho: And under, wi-... eh within two years, I don make am.

Text_en: So that's my ICAN story.
Text_ortho: So na so my ICAN history be.

Text_en: And I was so brilliant that time.
Text_ortho: And I bin so dey kajad dat time sha.

Text_en: Thank God!
Text_ortho: Tank God!

Text_en: So...
Text_ortho: So...

Text_en: Uh... good afternoon.
Text_ortho: Eh una, good afternoon.

Text_en: My name is Lekan.
Text_ortho: My name na Lekan.

Text_en: And myself, I work with Lasaco Assurance PLC.
Text_ortho: And me, I dey work with Lasaco Assurance PLC.

Text_en: And basically, what we do isn't just collecting money from people.
Text_ortho: And basically, wetin we dey do no be sey we just dey collect money from people.

Text_en: And I know that you have heard about insurance before.
Text_ortho: And I know sey una don hear about insurance before.

Text_en: And you will be asking the question, "what exactly do they do in insurance companies?"
Text_ortho: And una go dey ask sey wetin dem dey do for insurance company?

Text_en: We're very simple.
Text_ortho: We dey very simple.

Text_en: You know that in life, there is danger everywhere.
Text_ortho: You know sey as person dey live, danger dey everywhere.

Text_en: You sleep, you wake up, you take your bath.
Text_ortho: Sey you sleep, wake up, you bath.

Text_en: You go out.
Text_ortho: Sey you go out.

Text_en: It's a risk in itself.
Text_ortho: Na risk on its own.

Text_en: And in our company, what we do is that all those risks that people face (you look for what to eat on a daily basis), those are the risks we accommodate.
Text_ortho: And wetin we dey do for our own company be sey all dose risk wey man dey face (you dey find wetin you go chop on a daily basis), na dose risks we dey accommodate.

Text_en: That is... we protect you so that if anything happens, we will give you money.
Text_ortho: Na im we dey protect una sey if anyting happen, we go give una money.

Text_en: See!
Text_ortho: See!

Text_en: With insurance, you see, you can...
Text_ortho: For insurance eh you fit...

Text_en: We can protect anything you place value on, anything you love, anything you treasure.
Text_ortho: Anything wey you place value, anyting wey be sey you love, anyting wey you treasure, we fit protect am.

Text_en: That's what insurance does for people.
Text_ortho: Na wetin insurance dey do for people be dat.

Text_en: We can insure your car, we can insure your life and we can insure your house.
Text_ortho: We fit insure your car, we fit insure your life, we fit insure your house.

Text_en: Even your children who you love, we can make insurance policies for them.
Text_ortho: Even your children wey you love sef, we fit do insurance policy for dem.

Text_en: And all these things have their own benefits.
Text_ortho: And all dese tings get im own benefit.

Text_en: Not that someone will just be collecting your money, and you will be afraid.
Text_ortho: No be sey person go just dey collect your money, and you go dey fear.

Text_en: Nobody knows what will happen tomorrow.
Text_ortho: Nobody know wetin go happen tomorrow.

Text_en: Someone can sleep and not wake up tomorrow.
Text_ortho: Person fit sleep make e no wake up tomorrow.

Text_en: And you already have plans to send your lovely child to school.
Text_ortho: And you don plan for your mind sey you want send dat your lovely child go school.

Text_en: Insurance can guarantee that the child will go to school whether you're around or not.
Text_ortho: Insurance fit guarantee sey dat child go go school even weda you dey around, you no dey around.

Text_en: So, Insurance is beautiful.
Text_ortho: So insurance dey beautiful.

Text_en: But as time goes on, we know that we will get to a level in this country of ours and everyone will appreciate what insurance does for people.
Text_ortho: But as time dey go, we know sey we go reach one level for dis our country, and everybody go appreciate wetin insurance dey do for people.

Text_en: To enjoy life, to sleep with both eyes closed.
Text_ortho: To enjoy life, to sleep with your two eyes closed.

Text_en: In fact, don't be going k-...
Text_ortho: In fact no dey go k-...

Text_en: Older people say that if you want to go to sleep, leave one eye opened, but we can guarantee you that with insurance uh... you can sleep with both eyes closed.
Text_ortho: Elders talk sey if you want sleep, make you open one eye, but we fit guarantee you sey with insurance eh, you fit sleep with all your eyes closed.

Text_en: No problem.
Text_ortho: No shaking.

Text_en: We've got your back covered.
Text_ortho: We get your back.

Text_en: So that's what insurance does for people.
Text_ortho: So na wetin insurance dey do for people be dat.

Text_en: Thank you!
Text_ortho: Tank you!

Text_en: Sometimes, you will be wondering about insurance packages for rich people... can someone who is not wealthy buy an insurance packages?
Text_ortho: Sometimes una go dey wonder sey shey insurance dey for person wey get money, person wey no too get money, shey im fit buy insurance?

Text_en: See, the truth is that there's an insurance package for everyone.
Text_ortho: See di truth be sey insurance dey for everybody.

Text_en: But because we are afraid because of the impression that only someone who doesn't need... who has lots of money, can buy insurance packages, but with five thousand naira, you can also buy life insurance policies.
Text_ortho: But because we dey fear sey na person wey don chop wella, wey im pocket full fit buy insurance, with five thousand naira, you fit buy insurance policy for your life.

Text_en: You can protect your house with less than five thousand.
Text_ortho: You fit protect your house with less dan five thousand.

Text_en: Insurance was not created for rich people.
Text_ortho: Insurance no be sey dem create am for person wey get money.

Text_en: In fact, it's more beneficial to people who really don't have much money.
Text_ortho: In fact, na people wey no too get money di ting dey benefit pass.

Text_en: If you built a house and your house is worth maybe ten million naira, the amount you will pay us to protect your house in case of a fire isn't even three thousand naira.
Text_ortho: If you build house, and your house na maybe ten million naira, di money wey you go pay us to protect your house if fire burn am no reach three thousand naira.

Text_en: So compare... you should compare the amount you will pay to the danger that will come up if that house gets burnt!
Text_ortho: So compare, make una compare di money wey you go pay with di danger wey go happen if dat house burn!

Text_en: So whether you are rich or poor, for any product you want to buy, you will be the one to tell us the protection you need, and we will offer you some advice.
Text_ortho: So wheda you get money, abi you no get money, any product wey you want buy, na you go tell us di protection wey you need, and we go give you advice.

Text_en: We will tell you the amount you will pay, what you can protect, how you will go about it.
Text_ortho: We go tell you how much you go pay, wetin you fit protect, how you go go about am.

Text_en: See, insurance is beautiful, even in schools, anywhere you are, in the church too.
Text_ortho: See, insurance dey beautiful, even for school, anywhere wey you dey, for church.

Text_en: I know that pastors will ask you to put your faith in God.
Text_ortho: I know sey pastor go tell you sey make you carry your faith put am for God.

Text_en: That God's got your back covered.
Text_ortho: Sey God get your back.

Text_en: It's true!
Text_ortho: Na true!

Text_en: It's not a lie!
Text_ortho: No be lie!

Text_en: But God... since God has already gotten your back covered, He has also given you brains, which you are supposed to use to protect yourself.
Text_ortho: But God, as God don get your back, im don give you brain say make you take protect yourself too.

Text_en: That's what insurance does.
Text_ortho: Na wetin insurance dey do be dat.

Text_en: Make...
Text_ortho: Make...

Text_en: I am not telling you that God does not protect people.
Text_ortho: No be sey I dey tell you sey God no dey protect people.

Text_en: No!
Text_ortho: No!

Text_en: God protects people.
Text_ortho: God dey protect people.

Text_en: He's got our backs covered, for sure, but you also ought to do a thing or two.
Text_ortho: E get our back accepted, but yousef suppose do one, or two tings.

Text_en: You should add a thing or two.
Text_ortho: Make you add one to two.

Text_en: So that everything will stand strong and if anything happens, you are sure that the fund you need to keep you on your feet is available somewhere.
Text_ortho: Make everyting dey, take tanda sey if anyting happen, you sure sey money dey somewhere wey go keep you on your feet.

Text_en: It's not a good thing to be at work, searching for what to eat, and then something happens, and you cannot make money again.
Text_ortho: E no good when you go dey work, you dey find wetin you go chop, and someting happen, you no fit make money again.

Text_en: If you are unable to make money again with insurance... will the money you were making while you were still working keep coming in?
Text_ortho: If you no fit make money again with insurance, dat money wey you dey make while you still dey work go dey enter?

Text_en: Insurance will ensure that any money you were making before... in fact, now that something has come up, whether it's in the form of an accident or a sickness, or death...
Text_ortho: Insurance go ensure sey any money wey you dey make before, even now when something don happen (wheda na accident o, wheda na sickness o, abi death)...

Text_en: I know you will speak.
Text_ortho: I know sey you go talk.

Text_en: We all pray to live a long life.
Text_ortho: All of us dey pray sey make we live long for life.

Text_en: That's it!
Text_ortho: Na so!

Text_en: But if it happens, insurance has guaranteed that if death eventually occurs... that if it happens, there's an amount of money which they will give your family members like "the loss you suffered, your husband or your wife has planned for that, he had such things on their mind for you."
Text_ortho: But if e happen, insurance don guarantee sey if death eventually occur, sey if di ting happen, money dey wey dem go give your family say di loss wey una suffer, una husband, abi una wife don plan sey, na so, so, so thing e get in mind for una.

Text_en: Insurance can help you get what you have in mind, whether you are around or not.
Text_ortho: Dat ting wey you get in mind, insurance fit even make you achieve am wheda you dey around, abi you no dey around.

Text_en: You can come, and you can insure anything.
Text_ortho: Una fit come, and you fit insure anyting.

Text_en: You know in... so far you love that thing, you, you know that that thing uh... is very important.
Text_ortho: You know in so far you love dat ting, you, you know sey dat ting eh dey very important.

Text_en: Insurance is the answer you ought to get.
Text_ortho: Insurance na di answer wey you suppose get.

Text_en: Insurance is the way out, which will protect everything you value in this life.
Text_ortho: Insurance na di way out wey go protect everyting wey you place value on for dis life.

Text_en: It can be your life, it can be your wife, it can be your children.
Text_ortho: E fit be your life, e fit be your wife, e fit be your children.

Text_en: It can be their education, since you want them to go to school, they should study, they should become lawyers, they should become doctors, they should become anything in life.
Text_ortho: E fit be deir education sey you want make dem go school, make dem study, make dem become lawyer, make dem become doctor, make dem become anyting for dis life.

Text_en: Insurance will help you achieve that.
Text_ortho: Insurance go help you achieve dat one.

Text_en: In fact, if you were employed before but later became unemployed, insurance can still protect the salary you were earning, the one you were being paid by your employer.
Text_ortho: In fact, you dey work before, work no dey again, insurance still fit protect di salary wey you dey earn before, wey you dey collect from your employer.

Text_en: So it doesn't matter if...
Text_ortho: So e no mata wheda...

Text_en: Oh, I've lost my job, I can't keep paying.
Text_ortho: Oh I no get work again, I no fit dey pay.

Text_en: In fact, when you're retired, when you've told your employer that I've been working for you long enough, and now, I want to rest and enjoy my money, insurance can protect that money as well.
Text_ortho: In fact, after you don retire, when you don tell your employer sey di one wey I don do with una don do, sey now I want rest and enjoy my money, insurance still fit protect dat money as well.

Text_en: Which means that if you spent all the money they gave you, we will continue paying you as far as you've asked us to protect the money which you collected.
Text_ortho: Wey be sey even if you finish di money wey dem give you, we go dey pay you dey go so far you don come tell us sey you want protect dat money wey you collect.

Text_en: We call that annuity.
Text_ortho: Dat one, we dey call am annuity.

Text_en: So you will realise that if you take a good look at insurance, it is full of advantages.
Text_ortho: So you go see sey if you look insurance very well, e get advantage.

Text_en: Not that someone will collect your money.
Text_ortho: No be sey person go collect your money.

Text_en: In fact, it is so beautiful that once you enter into business with us, you will enjoy it.
Text_ortho: In fact e dey beautiful sotay once you enta business with us, you go enjoy am.

Text_en: We were established for your sake.
Text_ortho: Na because of una de establish us.

Text_en: We have come to serve you.
Text_ortho: Na una we come serve.

Text_en: And the amount you will pay is not so much.
Text_ortho: And di money wey una go pay, no be sey di ting much.

Text_en: So if you have informed us of what you want to protect, we'll advise you that okay, since you have told us what you want to protect, we will tell you that you will pay a little bit of money.
Text_ortho: So if you don tell us wetin you want protect, our own na to just give you advice sey okay o, as you don tell us sey na dis one you want protect, we go tell you na shikini money you go pay.

Text_en: If you combine... if you compare the amount you will pay and what you want to protect, you will realize that it is indeed a small amount of money.
Text_ortho: If you combine, if you compare how much you go pay, and wetin you want protect, you go see sey na shikini money.

Text_en: You s-... hustled... struggled to buy a million naira car.
Text_ortho: You s-... hustle, you struggle buy car one million naira.

Text_en: You pay fifty thousand naira to protect that car.
Text_ortho: You pay fifty thousand naira to protect dat car.

Text_en: If it gets stolen, you will get another one; if it gets burnt, you will get another one.
Text_ortho: If dem steal am, you go get anoda one, if fire burn am, you go get anoda one.

Text_en: If you hit someone, and someone... or someone hits your car, we will repair it for you.
Text_ortho: If you jam person, and person, or person jam you, we go repair am for you ni.

Text_en: So you should look into it too.
Text_ortho: So you too look am!

Text_en: Fifty thousand to one million, you will think that it's a small amount of money.
Text_ortho: Fifty thousand to one million, you go tink sey na shikini money.

Text_en: Even for your life, your properties, anything... the money we will give you as compensation based on the fact that you have a contract with us, that we want to protect you, if you compare it to the money which you, you will pay us, it's just a small amount of money.
Text_ortho: Even for your life o, for your property o, anyting, di money wey we go give you sey we take compensate you, sey you get contract with us, sey we want protect you, if you compare am to di money wey you, you go pay us, na just shikini money.

Text_en: You will not even feel the impact on your pockets.
Text_ortho: You no go even feel am for your pocket.

Text_en: It's not even up to the amount you will sp-... spend to have fun between January and December.
Text_ortho: E no even reach money wey you go sp-... spend jolloficate from January to December.

Text_en: So with this money you spend anyhow, you can protect yourself, protect your children, protect your family members, and protect the people around you.
Text_ortho: So with dis money wey you dey spend anyhow, you fit use am protect yourself, protect your children, protect your family, and protect people around you.

Text_en: That's what insurance has come to do for people.
Text_ortho: Na wetin insurance come do for people be dat.

Text_en: Thank you!
Text_ortho: Tank you!

Text_en: This is where we prepare shawarma, and this place is Lucky Special Shawarma, which we make here.
Text_ortho: Na here we dey do shawarma, and dis place na Lucky Special Shawarma wey we dey do here.

Text_en: Well, I'm the one who makes it.
Text_ortho: Toh na me dey do am.

Text_en: My name is Fidelis Isaac.
Text_ortho: My name na Fidelis Isaac.

Text_en: About shawarma, it has...
Text_ortho: As shawarma dey like dis, it has eh...

Text_en: We have it in grades.
Text_ortho: We have grade by grade.

Text_en: It comes in grades.
Text_ortho: E dey grade by grade.

Text_en: So we have the one worth five hundred naira.
Text_ortho: So we have di one of five hundred naira.

Text_en: And the one which is worth seven hundred.
Text_ortho: And e dey di one wey e be seven hundred.

Text_en: The other one is one thousand naira.
Text_ortho: Di oder one na one thousand naira.

Text_en: That... all of the shawarmas are big.
Text_ortho: Dat, all of dem na big shawarma.

Text_en: We have one which is Chicken Shawarma.
Text_ortho: We get di one wey be chicken shawarma.

Text_en: And as this is one of the favorites, the one for five hundred, we make it with just one sausage.
Text_ortho: And as de dey like dis now, di one of ehm five hundred, na one sausage wey we dey put am.

Text_en: The one for seven hundred, we make it with two sausages.
Text_ortho: Di one of seven hundred, two sausage, na im we dey put am.

Text_en: But the one for one thousand has two sausages, and it will be jumbo size.
Text_ortho: But di one of one thousand, na two sausage, and e go be jumbo size.

Text_en: So since we make it here, the market is growing because the price is this uh... constant, you know.
Text_ortho: So as we dey do am here, na so market dey grow because di price is dis eh constant you know.

Text_en: Now, the ingredients we use is salad.
Text_ortho: Now di ingredients now, na salad wey we dey use.

Text_en: Salad is cabbage.
Text_ortho: Salad na cabbage.

Text_en: We'll slice it, add carrot, add uh... corn, green beans, and all these things.
Text_ortho: We go slice am, put carrot, put eh sweet corn, green beans, and all dis things.

Text_en: And uh... you will add beef.
Text_ortho: And ehn you go put beef meat.

Text_en: Beef comes from cows.
Text_ortho: Beef meat na cow meat.

Text_en: You will add uh... chicken.
Text_ortho: You go put eh chicken.

Text_en: Chicken is a bird, you now.
Text_ortho: Chicken na fowl you know.

Text_en: So this is pepper which we also add.
Text_ortho: So dis one na pepper wey we dey put am also.

Text_en: And this is Lebanese bread... Chinese bread.
Text_ortho: And dis is Lebanese bread, Chinese bread.

Text_en: We put all these ingredients on it and then we fold and wrap it.
Text_ortho: Naim, we dey use put all dese ingredients den come fold, and wrap am.

Text_en: This is my toaster.
Text_ortho: Dis is my toaster.

Text_en: So these are the things we use to make shawarma.
Text_ortho: So dis are di things dat make shawarma.

Text_en: And for someone to sell Shawarma, it's all about, you know, time, and discipline.
Text_ortho: And it has to do wit you know time, and discipline for someone to sell shawarma.

Text_en: So it's a... it's a commitment thing.
Text_ortho: So it's a, it's a thing of commitment.

Text_en: That's... we do it here.
Text_ortho: Na im we dey do am here.

Text_en: So since jobs are not readily available in Nigeria nowadays, that's why we said we should be making shawarma.
Text_ortho: So as work no dey for Nigeria now, we just say meh we dey do shawarma.

Text_en: At least to create an opportunity for work.
Text_ortho: At least to create jobs chance meh person dey work.

Text_en: Uh... this is Ajegunle.
Text_ortho: Eh here na Ajegunle.

Text_en: So um... we do okay enough business.
Text_ortho: So ehm people dey try sha.

Text_en: That's why the price is as low as five hundred naira, so that people will buy it.
Text_ortho: Na im make di price come small like dis five hundred naira so dat people go buy.

Text_en: And by His... by the grace of God, they are buying... they are buying... they are trying.
Text_ortho: And by His, by di grace of God, de are buying, de are buying, de are trying.

Text_en: Anyone who wants to pass... who wants to buy, they will come in.
Text_ortho: Anybody wey want pass, wey wan buy, im go come.

Text_en: That's why I stay here to sell it.
Text_ortho: Na im make me stay here dey sell am.

Text_en: That's how it is.
Text_ortho: So na so e be.

Text_en: Taking myself for instance, I'm here in this place... this side of Ajegunle, I open by one o clock in the afternoon and I close by eleven.
Text_ortho: Like me, here wey I dey, dis place now o, dis side of Ajegunle, na one o'clock wey I dey open for afternoon, con close eleven.

Text_en: So at that time, I believe that people coming back from work will stop at my spot... my Shawarma Spot, to buy some.
Text_ortho: So as dat time now, I believe sey people wey wan return work go branch my spot, my shawarma spot, con buy.

Text_en: Um... that's all.
Text_ortho: Uhm dat is it.

Text_en: Good morning!
Text_ortho: Una good morning o!

Text_en: I'd like to say hi to you this morning.
Text_ortho: I say make I greet una dis morning.

Text_en: I am Awa Olowookere, Assistant Co-Commander; the Unit Commander of Isolo, for the Federal Road Safety Corps.
Text_ortho: I be Awa Olowookere, Assistant Co-commander di Unit Commander Isolo for Federal Road Safety Corp.

Text_en: Road Safety Corps members are the people who stand on the road, who you see on the road, who get you pissed off if you notice that they stopped you on the road.
Text_ortho: Road safety na dose people wey dey for road, wey una dey see for road, wey una dey vex if una see dem dey stop una.

Text_en: But now, that's not the only thing we do.
Text_ortho: But now, no be di only ting wey we dey dey do.

Text_en: Our duty in the Road Safety Corps is to teach road users.
Text_ortho: Our work for road safety na to teach people wey dey use road.

Text_en: And we are all road users.
Text_ortho: And na everybody dey use road.

Text_en: So we make sure that we get from the office to the churches and mosques.
Text_ortho: So we see sey we dey go from office, to churches, to mosque.

Text_en: We go talk to people about safety on the road.
Text_ortho: We dey go talk to people about road safety.

Text_en: We tell people all the things they're supposed to do... which they need to do in to make sure that their vehicles are ready to drive on the road.
Text_ortho: We dey tell people all di things wey dem suppose do, wey dem need to do to make sure gbe sey deir motor e ready for road.

Text_en: Because not all vehicles are road worthy.
Text_ortho: Because no be every motor person suppose carry to enter road.

Text_en: You could have abandoned a vehicle for some time; the vehicle is just parked there while you travelled.
Text_ortho: You go don leave motor for some time, di motor dey dere, you park am, you travel.

Text_en: When you come back, you walk up to the vehicle, wash it, turn the engine on and off you go.
Text_ortho: When you come back, you just come, you wash am, you on your engine, you move.

Text_en: When you get to so-... the road, the vehicle will stop and you will start complaining.
Text_ortho: When you reach so-... road now, di motor go stop, you go begin complain.

Text_en: That's what we are talking about.
Text_ortho: Na wetin we dey talk be dat.

Text_en: So before you move your vehicle in the morning, you're supposed to check it out.
Text_ortho: So before you move your motor for morning, you suppose check.

Text_en: There are some things you're supposed to check.
Text_ortho: Some tings dey wey you suppose look.

Text_en: You're supposed to check the radiator, check the water level in it.
Text_ortho: Suppose check di radiator, check di level wey your water reach.

Text_en: You'll check the oil.
Text_ortho: You go check your oil.

Text_en: You should check if the vehicle is due... if it's due for servicing, or if the oil is still... (there's uh... something we call viscosity) you will feel the, the, the viscosity of the oil to know if it's still high enough to use your vehicle.
Text_ortho: Make you look wheder dat motor even due, if e don due for service, or wheder di oil still (e get ah wetin we dey call viscosity), wheder di, di, di oil still soft wey you go feel dey carry you.

Text_en: Because if you dont check all these things...
Text_ortho: Because if you no look all dese things...

Text_en: Check your tires.
Text_ortho: Check your tyre.

Text_en: You know something?
Text_ortho: Una know one thing?

Text_en: The tire is the only part which makes contact with the road.
Text_ortho: Di tyre na dat thing wey only im dey touch di road.

Text_en: As you sit in the vehicle, the tire controls the vehicle, it makes it move.
Text_ortho: As you dey inside dat motor, na tyre dey control di motor wey dey make am move.

Text_en: Because, you know, motor vehicles are made of iron.
Text_ortho: Because you know, motor na iron.

Text_en: The iron parts alone cannot move.
Text_ortho: If you leave only di iron, e no go move.

Text_en: So we're telling you that you need to check your tires.
Text_ortho: So we dey tell una sey you need to check your tyre.

Text_en: Before you buy tires, look at the manufacturing date.
Text_ortho: Before you buy tyre, look di date of manufacture.

Text_en: You won't see an expiration date on tires.
Text_ortho: You no go see expiry day for tyre o.

Text_en: It's the manufacturing date... the day the tire was made.
Text_ortho: Na date of manufacture, di day wey dem make dat tyre.

Text_en: So when you look at the day, you wit-...
Text_ortho: So when you look di day, you wit-...

Text_en: The first two numbers on the tire...
Text_ortho: Di first two number wey dey for dat tyre...

Text_en: You'll see four numbers but the first two numbers are for the week that the tire was produced.
Text_ortho: Na four number you go see, but di first two number na di week wey dem produce dat tyre.

Text_en: Then the last two numbers will tell you the year.
Text_ortho: Den di last two number go tell you about di year.

Text_en: So if you see a tire which was made... which you... that says one one fourteen, that means the tire... that tire was produced in the eleventh week of twenty fourteen.
Text_ortho: So if you see tyre wey dem make, wey you, wey dem write one one fourteen, dat means sey na in di eleventh week of twenty fourteen na im dat tyre, dem make dat tyre.

Text_en: So you will add four years.
Text_ortho: So you go count four years.

Text_en: That will tell you the expiration date of that tire.
Text_ortho: Dat go tell you when dat tyre go expire.

Text_en: So you need to be checking your tires.
Text_ortho: So you need to dey check your tyre.

Text_en: Dont just look at the physical appearance of the tires to decide that uh... it's in good shape, this tire is still road worthy, it's a good tire.
Text_ortho: No just take eye look tyre say ah di teeth still sharp, dis tyre clean well, well, na good tyre.

Text_en: No!
Text_ortho: No!

Text_en: Check your tires!
Text_ortho: Check your tyre!

Text_en: And when you go, if you want to uh... check your tires, look at your car door.
Text_ortho: And when you go, if you wan eh check your tyre, look di body of your door.

Text_en: If you open the door, you will see the side of the door.
Text_ortho: If you open your door, you go see di side of di door.

Text_en: An iron which is called metal is right on the door.
Text_ortho: E get one iron dere wey dem dey call metal.

Text_en: You will see the pressure expected to be in each of your tires there.
Text_ortho: You go see di tyre pressure wey each of your tyre suppose carry.

Text_en: And that limit is what you're supposed to inf-... pump air into... pump your tire to.
Text_ortho: And na dat limit you suppose inf-... put air for inside, pump your tyre.

Text_en: So if you inflate your tire within... with the limit indicated on those instructions, it will be good for you.
Text_ortho: So if you pump your tyre within, with limit wey dey for dat instruction, e go help you.

Text_en: So you won't have the problem of your tire being over... you over-inflating your tire, meaning that there is too much or too little air in it.
Text_ortho: So you no go get case of sey your tyre over-... you overinflate your tyre, sey air too plenty inside, or e too low.

Text_en: Because if there is too much air in a tire, there is...
Text_ortho: Because if air too much for tyre, e get...

Text_en: Ah, you know how it is with a balloon.
Text_ortho: Ah you know as blow, blow dey be now.

Text_en: If you blow it up... blow it up... blow it up and you just touch it with a sharp object... any sharp thing, what will happen?
Text_ortho: If you blow am, blow am, blow am, if you just carry sharp object, sharp thing touch dat blow, blow, wetin go happen?

Text_en: It will burst.
Text_ortho: E go burst.

Text_en: And then we will be shouting, "ah, the tire has burst, the tire has..."
Text_ortho: Naim we go dey shout ah tyre don burst o, tyre don...

Text_en: Something made the tire burst because as the tire is moving on the road, it gets heated up.
Text_ortho: Na something make dat tyre burst because as e dey move for road, e dey hot.

Text_en: And the road gets hot too.
Text_ortho: And di road dey hot.

Text_en: Our weather affects it as well.
Text_ortho: Our weather again dey affect am.

Text_en: So putting all these things together, and when you go into a ditch, pah!
Text_ortho: So all dese things put togeda, and when you go enter gallop, pah!

Text_en: Little do you know that this tire is no good anymore, you will go a little ways more and it will burst.
Text_ortho: You no know sey dis tyre don get mark, but when you reach front, e go burst.

Text_en: So in the... you need to put the tire... inflate the tire to the correct level.
Text_ortho: So in di, you need to put your tyre, put air for di tyre wey go measure up.

Text_en: And again, if your tire's deflated (that's what we call under-inflation)... under-inflation also affects tires.
Text_ortho: And again, if your tyre don less (na one wey we dey call underinflation inflation), underinflation too dey affect tyre.

Text_en: It disturbs tires because when you put loads into your car and you enter into the tire... the car, it will press on the tire.
Text_ortho: E dey worry tyre because when you carry load, when you enter inside di tyre, di motor, e go press dat tyre.

Text_en: And you, you see that the tire is coming apart on both sides.
Text_ortho: And you, you see sey di tyre dey chop for di two sides.

Text_en: If you blow too much air into it, it will come apart in the middle, but if you...
Text_ortho: If you blow am too much, e go dey chop for di centre but if you...

Text_en: You know the air... if there's not much air in the tire, it will be coming apart in the, the...
Text_ortho: You know di air, di air inside no plenty, e go dey chop for di, di...

Text_en: If you notice that the two sides of your tire are getting smooth, you will say, "imagine, I just bought this tire and it's getting smooth."
Text_ortho: See sey di two sides of your tyre go dey smooth, you go say aha dis tyre, I just buy am, e just dey smooth.

Text_en: The air in your tire is not up to the correct level.
Text_ortho: Di air wey dey inside your tyre, e no reach.

Text_en: So you're supposed to check your tire so it doesn't over-inflate or under-inflate.
Text_ortho: So you suppose check your tyre make e no overinflate, or under-... inflate.

Text_en: Another thing we tell people is if you must drive, if you have to drive a car (you have bought a car and you have a license), don't drink alcohol, alcohol, all brands of distilled liquor, all these drinks which are being sold by the roadsides.
Text_ortho: Anoda ting wey we dey tell people, if you must drive o, if e be sey you must drive motor (you don buy motor, you get licence), make you no take alcohol alcohol, all dis ogogoro, all dis tings wey dem dey sell for road.

Text_en: Because those drinks contain things which have different effects on the human body.
Text_ortho: Because dose things get things wey dey affect person for body.

Text_en: If you're... if you drink alcohol, your vision will be different from somone who isn't under the influence.
Text_ortho: If you are, if you take alcohol, di way you go dey see go different from person wey no dey under any influence.

Text_en: It will affect you.
Text_ortho: E go affect you.

Text_en: You could be looking straight ahead and see nothing, even though someone has come out in front of you.
Text_ortho: You fit dey look front now say noting dey whereas somebody don enter your front.

Text_en: A bicycle has... someone riding a bicycle has caught up with you.
Text_ortho: Bicycle don, person don ride bicycle enter your front.

Text_en: You won't see them because you've drunk something that stops you from seeing clearly.
Text_ortho: You no go see am because you don take something wey dey prevent you from seeing well.

Text_en: And if you are driving, you're supposed to... you... you...
Text_ortho: And if you dey drive, you suppose, you, you.

Text_en: We, we do have a saying.
Text_ortho: We, we dey get wetin we dey say.

Text_en: You drive with your eyes, and see with your mind.
Text_ortho: You drive with your eye, and see with your mind.

Text_en: If you're driving a car, you are the one... you are seeing [with your eyes] but it's your mind that's calculating everything.
Text_ortho: If you dey drive motor, na you you dey look o, but na your mind you take dey calculate everyting.

Text_en: Look at the buildings here and there.
Text_ortho: Look at di building here and dere.

Text_en: Everywhere is full of houses, houses... beautiful houses... beautiful houses... beautiful houses.
Text_ortho: Everywhere na about house, house, better house, better house, better house.

Text_en: Ours is not wi-...
Text_ortho: Our own no be wi-...

Text_en: We are not different from them.
Text_ortho: We no dey different dan, like dem.

Text_en: The same thing do... we are the same.
Text_ortho: Na still di same tin wey de be, na im we be.

Text_en: So all those kinds of things, it's not good.
Text_ortho: So all dose kind ting, e no good.

Text_en: It's good if you... if... that... they should give a helping hand to your people, they should help those... the people who are better... help people who are better than you because you dont know where the help will come from.
Text_ortho: E good meh, if, sey make e dey help your people, dey help di one, di people wey better pass, dey help people wey better pass you cause you no know where di help go come from.

Text_en: So this year... I know that this year... this year will not pass me by.
Text_ortho: So dis year, I know sey dis year, dis year no go pass me by.

Text_en: And this year, I already know that this is my year.
Text_ortho: And dis year, I don already know sey dis year na my year.

Text_en: And it's my year of testimonies, my year of blessings, my year of divine... made... uh, uh, uh mercy, thats what this year is.
Text_ortho: And na my year of testimony, my year of blessing, my year of divine med-... eh eh eh mercy na im be dis year.

Text_en: So I know that as this year is moving on, myself, I am moving along with it.
Text_ortho: So I know sey as dis year dey carry on so, me, I dey carry on dey follow am.

Text_en: I am following it closely.
Text_ortho: I dey bumper dey follow am.

Text_en: Because I know that the way this year is presently... the way I am looking at this year, I know that the year is sh-... will bring good fortunes to me.
Text_ortho: Cause I know sey di way dis year be now, di way I dey look di year, I know sey di year dey sh-... go shine for my head.

Text_en: So, so this year, I have committed everything to the hands of God
Text_ortho: So so I don cover everyting put for God hand dis year.

Text_en: That... I know that there's no way this year will not be good for me!
Text_ortho: Sey I know sey no how wey dis year no go better for my life.

Text_en: So I am praying that as this year goes on, let it begin.
Text_ortho: So I dey pray sey as dis year be now, moh we start am.

Text_en: People with no professional training (because working as a security guard is not a profession), if you know that you are still young enough to learn a trade, you'd better go for the training.
Text_ortho: People wey no learn work (because security work no be work), if you know sey your age still dey you for make you learn work, you better go learn work.

Text_en: If you prefer to go into business, you go into it.
Text_ortho: If na business, you enter business.

Text_en: He should introduce you to anyone he feels comfortable with.
Text_ortho: Anyone wey e know sey im go carry you, e carry you go.

Text_en: Because people have worked as security guards... I have met some people.
Text_ortho: Because security work, people don do am, I don jam some people.

Text_en: Myself, it's been three months now.
Text_ortho: Me, na three months now.

Text_en: That I've been on the job, but those three months feel like a hundred years to me.
Text_ortho: Na me, I don do am, but dat three month don dey me like sey na hundred years.

Text_en: Some people said they have been on this job for twenty years, got married with the proceeds, had five children... had ten children, without a house.
Text_ortho: Some people don say de don do am twenty years, carry am marry wife, born five children, born ten children, no house.

Text_en: They dont even have a place to lay their heads, which is not good.
Text_ortho: De no even get place wey de dey put head dey lie down which no good.

Text_en: So whoever knows that...
Text_ortho: So anybody wey know sey...

Text_en: The things he will do will bring him good luck.
Text_ortho: Tings wey im go do, e go favour am.

Text_en: If it is work, you will go and learn.
Text_ortho: If na work, we go learn.

Text_en: If it is houseboy and you still have enough time, you go and be a houseboy.
Text_ortho: If na boy, time still dey your hand, you go do boyi.

Text_en: Being a houseboy does not bring good luck, but it does bring some people good luck.
Text_ortho: Boyi no dey favour, but e get people wey im dey favour.

Text_en: But when you're well behaved... but it's better to go for some vocational training.
Text_ortho: But when you calm your hand down, but it's better meh you go learn work.

Text_en: Engage yourself!
Text_ortho: Spend time!

Text_en: In the next four or five years, you'll have become your own boss.
Text_ortho: Like four, five years, you don get your own.

Text_en: Before you know it, in two or three years and you'll have eased off.
Text_ortho: Before you know, two to three years, you don relax.

Text_en: He's started living large, bought equipment or tools, rented an apartment, bought land to build a house on, begun to enjoy life like the others.
Text_ortho: E don dey do big boy, don buy machine, rent house, buy property put for house, begin dey bubble like oders.

Text_en: But now wa-... the way we feel nowadays... we need quick money.
Text_ortho: But now wa-... di way im dey us now, we need quick money.

Text_en: Bringing in money is what we need now.
Text_ortho: Ego buta, na im we need now.

Text_en: We need to go and bring in money.
Text_ortho: To go carry di money come, na im we need.

Text_en: Because the way we are looking at the world, it looks as if it is late already.
Text_ortho: Because di way we dey look di world now, e be like sey don even late for us sef.

Text_en: But I know that it's not late yet.
Text_ortho: But I know sey e never late.

Text_en: But I know that God will do it.
Text_ortho: But I know sey God go do am.

Text_en: God will do it because we were destined to help our mother who is in the village.
Text_ortho: God go do am for us because our moder for village, de born us meh we help dem.

Text_en: And since we were born into a poor family, there's no money.
Text_ortho: And as we born for poor family, no money.

Text_en: We were not even given money for a soft landing here.
Text_ortho: De no even give us money moh we take carry come.

Text_en: They are looking up to us.
Text_ortho: Na our hand na im de dey look.

Text_en: December is over, we didn't go.
Text_ortho: December don pass now, we no go.

Text_en: New Year's is over, we didn't go.
Text_ortho: New year pass, we no go.

Text_en: And they're still looking out for us.
Text_ortho: And de still dey look for us.

Text_en: There's no way you arrive the village without taking bread along... you can't go to the village without taking bread along.
Text_ortho: No how wey you land now, you no go buy bread, no how wey you go village, you no go buy bread.

Text_en: You will buy the traditional wear for your mothers, and you'll still give your mother some pocket money worth between five thousand to ten thousand naira.
Text_ortho: You go buy wrapper for your moders, still give your moder pocket money like five thousand, ten thousand.

Text_en: So the woman will be smiling as she takes from it, saying that uh... her son is back.
Text_ortho: Meh di woman dey take am, dey smile say ehn im son come back.

Text_en: Imagine that you go empty handed.
Text_ortho: And you con come go empty handed.

Text_en: No money; nothing.
Text_ortho: Money no dey, noting dey.
