Text_ortho: Dat one na federal level.

Text_en: Now you understand that from Federal to State, to Local Government, Ward level and the like, I trust them.
Text_ortho: You get so from federal, to state, to local government, to ward, and all di rest like, I trust dem.

Text_en: You know I know they can't go beyond what they've been mandated to do.
Text_ortho: You get I know sey de no fit do pass wetin we send dem.

Text_en: You have an idea of the level, based on who you are.
Text_ortho: You know di level now base on who you be.

Text_en: Someone said, "shut up Titi, you are a smooth talker!"
Text_ortho: Somebody say shut up Titi, you get mouth!

Text_en: Seriously, I trust them.
Text_ortho: But seriously, I trust dem.

Text_en: I trust that no matter how bad it is, they will consider us in whatever decision they want to make.
Text_ortho: I trust sey bad as e bad reach, any decision wey de go make, de go think about us before dey make am.

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Yes, because we are all in this together... we are in this together.
Text_ortho: Ehn because all of us, we dey inside dis waka together o, we dey inside together.

Text_en: You understand, the difference between me and the guy who is in charge on the other side, is that myself, I buy one mudu [measure] of Garri while he buys one bag.
Text_ortho: You get di difference between me, and bros wey owes side now, na sey me, I dey buy one mudu of garri, e dey buy one bag.

Text_en: There is no difference in price at the market.
Text_ortho: Di price for market no dey different.

Text_en: The same price is applicable to both the poor and the rich.
Text_ortho: Na di price wey de sell give poor man na im de dey sell give rich man.

Text_en: The difference is that I buy in a smaller quantity and the rich guys... they buy in bags, trailers, loads and the like.
Text_ortho: Di difference, na im be sey me dey buy small, small, and di big bros, dem dey buy bag, trailer, load, and all di rest.

Text_en: You get it?
Text_ortho: You get?

Text_en: But, that doesn't mean that a bag of rice for the poor is different from a bag of rice for the rich man.
Text_ortho: But, dat one no mean sey bag of rice for poor man, e dey difference for bag of rice for rich man.

Text_en: No!
Text_ortho: No!

Text_en: The price is the same.
Text_ortho: De dey di same price.

Text_en: So they will consider us in anything they want to do.
Text_ortho: So anything wey de wan do, de go think about us.

Text_en: So that's why I was telling you on Friday that you should trust them to think about the matter, and they will not just make any decision.
Text_ortho: So dat one na why I bin tell you on Friday sey make you trust sey de go reason about di matter, and de no go just make any decision.

Text_en: And I was happy this morning when I woke up and realized they didn't make a rash decision.
Text_ortho: And I happy dis morning when I wake up wey I see sey de no just make just anyhow decision.

Text_en: I told you!
Text_ortho: I bin tell you now!

Text_en: Believe whatever I tell you, even if I say the rain will fall in the dry season!
Text_ortho: Dey believe me if I tell you sey rain go fall for dry season!

Text_en: Believe it!
Text_ortho: Believe it!

Text_en: Do you know what I saw?
Text_ortho: You know wetin I see?

Text_en: Why will I believe the unbelievable?
Text_ortho: Why I go dey believe some kind things?

Text_en: But, but you know... let's be serious here... let's be serious here.
Text_ortho: But, but you know serious, serious!

Text_en: Jokes aside!
Text_ortho: Comot joke for di matter!

Text_en: So based on that information which filtered out on Friday, I'll tell you the story as it's supposed to be.
Text_ortho: So on top dat informate wey bin comot on Friday, now, I go tell you di tori as e suppose be.

Text_en: You understand, because the news didnt get to us the way it's supposed to.
Text_ortho: You get because no be as e suppose be na im e later reach we side.

Text_en: By the time the story got to us, it was distorted.
Text_ortho: By di time wey di tori reach we side, some people don comot small, don add small.

Text_en: They put salt on it, they put pepper, they added so many things!
Text_ortho: De don put salt, de don put pepper, don put so many things.

Text_en: This is a ploy to make the story sell.
Text_ortho: You get to just make di story make e sell small.

Text_en: But here's the deal.
Text_ortho: But see di deal here.

Text_en: According to the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Works, Kabir Gaya, representing the APC [All Progressives Congress] in Kano, the way he spoke about the matter, it's obvious that you shouldn't act on a one-sided story.
Text_ortho: According by di way wey Senate Commitee on Top of Works, dem chamo, Kabir Gaya wey dey representate APC Kano, di way wey e take yarn di matter, de no dey hear one side of tori judge o.

Text_en: If you pass judgement based on what you heard from one side of the story, then you are not a good judge.
Text_ortho: If you hear one side of yarn judge, you no be correct judge now.

Text_en: You need to listen to all sides of the story before you make up your mind.
Text_ortho: You go hear here, hear dere, hear every, den you go come yarn di colour of your belle.

Text_en: But right now, the story... it differs.
Text_ortho: But right now, di tori, e different.

Text_en: Because according to Mr Kabiru Gaya, he says that, that it's true they had a talk on some bills under consideration, concerning, concerning the roads.
Text_ortho: Because from wetin dey comot from di mouth of Oga Kabiru Gaya, im dey yarn sey, sey na true sey de sidon talk base on some kind bill wey de bin don dey judge, judge on top, on top of road matter.

Text_en: But that they did not say that the five... you and I will part with five naira.
Text_ortho: Sey but dem no yarn sey di five, five naira go comot for di hand of me, and you.

Text_en: So the next time you drive your car to the filling station for fuel... it's not like the five naira will come from you directly.
Text_ortho: So di next time wey you drive your motor to go sha mai for gidan mai, no be sey di five naira go comot directly from you.

Text_en: The five naira tax is an arrangement that has been on ground, long before now.
Text_ortho: Di five naira, na arrangy wey don dey ground e don tay.

Text_en: You and I were not aware of it.
Text_ortho: Me, and you just no know about am.

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: So according to what should be, based on the arrangement of road fund bills which is being proposed, which the Committee has said, "okay, you should th-... think about this issue, look into it, you understand, it's different from what the people heard."
Text_ortho: So according by di way wey di matter e suppose be, base on di arrangy of road fund bill wey de bin propose, wey di Commitee bin say okay make una re-... reason dis matter, mey una shook eye on top, you get e dey different from di tori wey reach country people side.

Text_en: You understand the main... the main thing is that people like us bring in the oil.
Text_ortho: You understand di main, main thing, na im be sey na di people wey dey carry di oil enter.

Text_en: You know that we take it raw... crude, just as it comes from the ground.
Text_ortho: You know sey we dey carry am raw, fresh as e comot for ground.

Text_en: We do remove it, right?
Text_ortho: We dey carry am comot abi?

Text_en: Then they dust the body, clean it up, and bring it back following what me and you can buy.
Text_ortho: Den we go come go dust all di body, clean am up ehn, con carry am come back base on wetin me, and you fit buy.

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Yes, it's not the crude that's being sold to us.
Text_ortho: Ehen no be di crude na im de dey sell give us.

Text_en: The crude is exported and refined until it's ready for use.
Text_ortho: Meh carry di crude comot, polish am, dust am, cook am, dry am, do everything doable.

Text_en: And yes, it has been brought back and it's being sold as petrol, they spe-... sell kerosine, diesel, gas and other products.
Text_ortho: Ehen den con carry am come back, den con dey sell petrol, dey spe-... sell kerosine, dey sell diesel, gas, and all di rest like dat.

Text_en: So what the Committee on Works proposed was that when the refined product is brought in, those who bring it in, those who sell it... so if the pump price in the filling station is one hundred and forty five naira... they're not trying to say that the pump price will move up from one forty five naira to one fifty naira.
Text_ortho: So wetin di Commitee on Top of Works bin dey judge on top, na unto sey as de dey carry am enter, di people wey dey carry am enter, di people wey dey sell am, so if pump price for filling station na one fourty five naira, dem no dey try talk sey di pump price go move from one forty five naira, to one fifty naira.

Text_en: No!
Text_ortho: No!

Text_en: They're saying that from that one forty five naira, they will get the five naira they need for the proposed road fund.
Text_ortho: De dey talk sey from dat one forty five naira, de go get di five naira wey de need for di arrangy of road fund.

Text_en: Yes, you got it!
Text_ortho: Ehen you too okay!

Text_en: Now, the picture is clearer, right?
Text_ortho: Now di picture don dey resemble each other abi?

Text_en: Now to the point where the story went amiss, where things got confused.
Text_ortho: Now make I tell you di point where di tori e miss, where everything turn di way wey e turn.

Text_en: You know that you know us by now.
Text_ortho: You know sey you know us now.

Text_en: It didn't start today, it's been on for a long time.
Text_ortho: No be today e don tay.

Text_en: We're waiting for the one who will make the announcement so that we will take out our anger on them.
Text_ortho: We dey wait for who go talk so dat we go para on top of im head.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: When the Senate Committee on Works was deliberating on the matter, an association heard about it and got upset.
Text_ortho: When Senate Commitee on Top of Works bin dey judge on top of di matter, e come get gombody wey hear about di matter, wey come provoke for di level.

Text_en: The name of the association is Conference of Nigerian Political Parties, also known as CNPP.
Text_ortho: Di name of di gombody na Conference of Nigerian Political Parties, alias CNPP.

Text_en: Then they said uh... they're here again, they've started again, let's make our voice heard!
Text_ortho: Na dem come talk sey uhm de are here again, they have started again, let us shook mouth!

Text_en: So they... zuga zugi zugi.
Text_ortho: Naim de con zuga zugi zugi.

Text_en: Ka zuga for Africa!
Text_ortho: Ka zuga for Africa!

Text_en: So they joined hands with the organized uh... labor congress.
Text_ortho: Naim de con zuga gombodi of organised ehn labour people.

Text_en: They urged the people to join them in protest!
Text_ortho: Naim de come ginger dem say make una come, make una come!

Text_en: We've heard some fresh news, you know.
Text_ortho: We don hear fresh one hm.

Text_en: That they want to raise the pump price by five naira.
Text_ortho: De say de wan add pump price money, de wan put five naira on top.

Text_en: So they also got upset.
Text_ortho: Naim dose one too para.

Text_en: Before we knew it, the Association of Students also joined in the protest saying please, please, please, the Labour Congress members are angry already.
Text_ortho: Before we know wetin dey happen, gombodi of student too don dey para sey abeg, abeg, abeg labour people don dey vex.

Text_en: The students also expressed their anger.
Text_ortho: Student too don dey para.

Text_en: That was how the story got to us, kata giti kata.
Text_ortho: Na so di story reach we side kata giti kata.

Text_en: And so I also said, "uh... they want to increase the pump price of fuel."
Text_ortho: Naim me too, I say eh de wan to add money to fuel price.

Text_en: Alright now, let's get these things straight.
Text_ortho: Alright now, make we get dese things straight.

Text_en: Now, the association of the CNPP [Conference of Nigerian Political Parties] accused the Speaker of the National Assembly saying that the Senators dont consider us before they take decisions.
Text_ortho: Now, di gombodi of CNPP de dey drop accusate on top of di Head of National Assemble sey di people wey dey dere, de no dey reason us before de make any decide.

Text_en: That they do nothing but play with their electronic gadgets like computers, phones and the like while making decisions.
Text_ortho: Sey de go just dey where de dey, just press deir, all di pressable, di computer, di phones, di everything, and dey just decide.

Text_en: That they don't really think about the masses, you know, and their welfare.
Text_ortho: Sey de no dey really think about di common man, and you know wetin dey okay for us, and all di rest.

Text_en: But from all these things I've told you, in order to clear the air concerning the news we heard on Friday... the initial story we heard on Friday is that uh... the Senate wants to raise the pump price... they want to raise it by five naira.
Text_ortho: But from all dese gist wey I don give you, wey I don follow clear di tory wey we bin hear on Friday, di original tori wey we hear on Friday na sey ah Senate wan add to pump price, de wan add five naira.

Text_en: But right now, this same Senate, through the repre-... their representative who is the Chairman of the Senate Committee for Works has spoken.
Text_ortho: But right now, dese same Senate dey comot now through di repre-... dem representate wey be chamo on top of Senate Committee for Works.

Text_en: Yes, Mr Gaya, he's saying no, it's not so!
Text_ortho: Yes Oga Gaya, im dey yarn sey no, no be so!

Text_en: This bill, this arrangement, this road fund bill, and the like, had been on the ground.
Text_ortho: Dis bill, dis arrangy, dis road fund, apala pala thing, e don dey ground.

Text_en: It's been a long time.
Text_ortho: E don tay.

Text_en: But all the associations that ought to pay the said amount had not been paying.
Text_ortho: But di gombodies dem wey suppose dey pay am, de no dey pay.

Text_en: Do you now understand where the misunderstanding came from?
Text_ortho: You understand where di misunderstanding come follow show now?

Text_en: Uhuh, because since the refined products are being brought into the country, they're supposed uh... as they sell to us, we, the country people who buy kerosine, fuel, diesel, and the like... gas for cooking, and the like, those who drive cars, use generators... as they sell to us, they ought to pay the five naira from their proceeds.
Text_ortho: Ehen because as de dey carry di oil come back inside country, de suppose eh as de dey sell give us, we, country people wey dey buy kerosine, fuel, diesel, and all di rest, gas, dey cook, and all di rest, dey drive motor, dey use generator, as de dey sell to us, from di money wey we dey pay dem, de suppose dey remit five, five naira.

Text_en: So the five naira on each litre has not been paid for a very long time.
Text_ortho: So dat five, five naira, e don dey hang since ninety epurutepu.

Text_en: Whose pockets does it go into?
Text_ortho: Which person pocket now e dey enter?

Text_en: That's the next question I want to ask.
Text_ortho: Na di next question wey me I wan even ask.

Text_en: Please, if they know, let them tell us.
Text_ortho: Abeg, if de know, meh de tell us.

Text_en: So if that five naira per litre is not being paid, then, what happened to it?
Text_ortho: So if dat five, five naira no dey show, wetin happen to our five, five naira?

Text_en: Because the five naira is very important.
Text_ortho: Because five naira is very important.

Text_en: Last week, uh... on Saturday, I found a hundred naira note in my pocket while checking.
Text_ortho: Last week ehn, okay on Saturday, I bin check my pocket, I see hundred naira.

Text_en: That hundred naira changed my life.
Text_ortho: That hundred naira change my life.

Text_en: My life improved because of the hundred naira.
Text_ortho: My life no remain di same after I see dat hundred naira.

Text_en: And how many five naira will you get from a hundred naira?
Text_ortho: And how many five naira dey inside hundred naira?

Text_en: Just twenty.
Text_ortho: Just twenty.

Text_en: So, do you know how, how many five naira notes have been unaccounted for?
Text_ortho: So you know how, how many five, five naira ehen na im don dey dey since one no know where e enter?

Text_en: That is for the EFCC [Economic and Financial Crimes Commission], and other agencies and the SS [State Security] officers.
Text_ortho: Ehn dat one na for EFCC, and di, all di rest, and di SS people dere.

Text_en: You know we really love them.
Text_ortho: You know we love dem well, well.

Text_en: Alright, back to the matter.
Text_ortho: Alright back to di matter.

Text_en: Based on the calculation on the ground, they said it would be as much as one hundred and sixty seven billion naira.
Text_ortho: Now, base on di calculate wey don dey ground, de dey follow yarn sey akpalapala don reach like one hundred, and sixty seven billion naira.

Text_en: Do you know how rich we would have been, if we had been doing a thrift contribution of five, five naira?
Text_ortho: Dat five five naira o, dat five, five naira da muna adashi, had it been we dey do contribution (local contribution), do you know how rich we be now?

Text_en: Yes, for... yes!
Text_ortho: Yes, for, yes!

Text_en: Maybe my father would have started the contribution before I was born.
Text_ortho: Maybe my pale go start di contribution before de born me.

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Do you how much we would have gathered by now?
Text_ortho: You know how much wey we go don get now?

Text_en: So based on the above, I leave the matter for your consideration.
Text_ortho: So base on dat level, now I don come drop di matter for your front.

Text_en: What do you think?
Text_ortho: Wetin you feel?

Text_en: Alright, I got the New Telegraph this morning, and I'll read out some of the stories uh... which are different.
Text_ortho: Alright I carry di New Telegraph dis morning, and some of di stories wey dey dere, ehn wey dey different, I go read am out.

Text_en: Ah, did you hear that TELCOS is losing a lot of money?
Text_ortho: Ah you dey hear sey TELCOS dey lose big money.

Text_en: They said they are...
Text_ortho: De said de dey...

Text_en: The loss or the, the, the loss they have suffered has hit one hundred, and fifty six point six bilion naira.
Text_ortho: Di lose, abi di, di, di loss wey de don suffer, e don hit one hundred, and fifty six point six billion naira.

Text_en: You know you have to stumble on some of the money (be-... be-... be-... billion...), because we dont know if it's a gazillion.
Text_ortho: You know you have to stumble on some of di money (be-... be-... be-... billion) because we no know wheder na gazillion.

Text_en: In our lifetime, we'll talk about gazillions.
Text_ortho: In our lifetime, we go talk about gazillion.

Text_en: Hehe.
Text_ortho: Hehe.

Text_en: Alright, you'll see this ex-soldier.
Text_ortho: Alright o you go see dis ex-soldier.

Text_en: What's he saying?
Text_ortho: Wetin e dey say?

Text_en: He is a confirmed kidnapper, he said, "I only kidnap valuable ladies", says the ex-soldier.
Text_ortho: He is a confirmed kidnapper, he say I kidnap only valuable ladies says ex-soldier.

Text_en: This is one of those times you won't want anyone to describe you as valuable.
Text_ortho: Dis one na one of di days wey you no go wan mey de describe you as valuable.

Text_en: Beacause if it's about your value, they should take away Luchin this morning.
Text_ortho: Because if na your value na im de dey take kidnap you, de should take away Luchi dis morning.

Text_en: Luchi is looking valuable, hehe.
Text_ortho: Luchi is looking valuable hehe.

Text_en: Alright, that one is in uh... page thirty four of the New Telegraph this morning.
Text_ortho: Alright o dat one dey inside eh page thirty four of di New Telegraph dis morning.

Text_en: Wike has sued the IGP, the EFCC, and the DSS over the way they are... they're planning his residence invasion.
Text_ortho: Wike don sue IGP, EFCC, DSS on top di way de dey, de dey plan im residence invasion.

Text_en: That means that the, the way they entered, you know, Ho-... Hollywood style.
Text_ortho: Dat be sey di way dey take enter you know Ho-... Hollywood style.

Text_en: It'll be like... it's like spies coming into your house when you dont know what's going on.
Text_ortho: E go be like dey, e, e be like sey na spies enter your house when e no know how far.

Text_en: They said the guy will sue them for that operation.
Text_ortho: De said di guy go sue dem for dat waka wey dem waka.

Text_en: It's in page six of the New Telegram.
Text_ortho: E dey inside page six of di New Telegraph.

Text_en: The Court stops the House of Representatives from prosecuting Anyim.
Text_ortho: Court stops rep from prosecuting Anyim.

Text_en: Why do they want to prosecute him?
Text_ortho: Why do de want to prosecute him?

Text_en: The man has taken the case to the High Court.
Text_ortho: Di man don run to di Moder Court.

Text_en: What has the the High Court done?
Text_ortho: Moder Court don do wetin?

Text_en: Protected him and said no!
Text_ortho: Use im wrapper cover im head say no!

Text_en: I'm warning you... don't try it... dont try it.
Text_ortho: Ehe eh don't try it, don't try it!

Text_en: That's it.
Text_ortho: Na im be di tin wey dey dere.

Text_en: Alright, that story is on page thirty five, because Luchi is about to advocate for the people.
Text_ortho: Alright dat one dey inside page thirty five ehn because Luchi is about to advocate for di people.

Text_en: Hehe, yes, we've all heard.
Text_ortho: Hehe ehn we all don already hear.

Text_en: They asked, "how long will our President stay away?"
Text_ortho: De talk sey how long our Presido go stay?

Text_en: All those things are there in the paper.
Text_ortho: All dose tins dey dere.

Text_en: Tears of joy as eighty two Chibok girls return.
Text_ortho: Tears of Joy as eighty two Chibok girls return.

Text_en: Oh, great!
Text_ortho: Oh very lovely!

Text_en: Government to parents: keep hope alive!
Text_ortho: Government to parents keep hope alive!

Text_en: Yes, it was said that one hundred and thirteen others... they said they will be released.
Text_ortho: Ehn de say one hundred and thirteen odas, sey de go return.

Text_en: That means that only one hundred and thirteen girls are still in their custody.
Text_ortho: Dat means only one hundred and thirteen remain for deir hand.

Text_en: Yes, that one, we, we, we, we...
Text_ortho: Ehn dat one, we, we, we, we...

Text_en: They are... they are... they are very...
Text_ortho: De are, de are, de are very, very...

Text_en: I'm very happy.
Text_ortho: I'm very happy.

Text_en: The Red Cross says, "we are a neutral intermediary."
Text_ortho: Red Cross dey talk sey we are neutral intermediary.

Text_en: That means that they themselves were involved in the negotiations.
Text_ortho: Dat mean sey demsef, de follow do di negotiation.

Text_en: On a neutral level, according to them.
Text_ortho: De say on a neutral level.

Text_en: All of that's in uh... the New Telegraph.
Text_ortho: All dat one, e dey inside ehm di New Telegraph.

Text_en: Well, anyway, they said Adeyinka Adebayo will be buried on May twentieth.
Text_ortho: Ehn anyway, de say Adeyinka Adebayo for burial May twenty.

Text_en: That was announced by his family.
Text_ortho: Ehn na im family na im talk dat one.

Text_en: Stop the Police from searching my house, Wike has told the court.
Text_ortho: Stop police from searching my house Wike don tell court!

Text_en: Maybe... what are you hiding, sir, that you don't want them to see?
Text_ortho: Maybe, what are you hiding Sir dat you don't want dem to see?

Text_en: Ehen!
Text_ortho: Ehen!

Text_en: Falomo School.
Text_ortho: Falomo School.

Text_en: Lagos may charge pupils with attempted rape.
Text_ortho: Lagos may charge pupils with attempted rape.

Text_en: I really, really, really want to commend the woman who did d-... this.
Text_ortho: I really, really, really want to commend big time dis woman wey do d-... dis.

Text_en: Did you know that when you see secondary school students when they are done writing their last paper, they will start acting like hooligans, tearing each other's clothes.
Text_ortho: Do you know dat now, when you see secondary school children, when de finish deir last paper, de will now become like hooligans tearing deir cloth.

Text_en: They said they were almost... they were almost raping girls, cutting their skirts with scissors.
Text_ortho: De said de were almost, de were almost raping girls using scissors to tear deir skirt.

Text_en: Then they'll hold them down, outside, in broad daylight.
Text_ortho: De would now hold dem down in broad daylight in outside opendential.

Text_en: This woman had to come out of her car, with her, her escorts.
Text_ortho: Dis woman had to come out of her car with her, her escort.

Text_en: That was how they were able to save more than a hundred girls, all of them from different pockets of...
Text_ortho: Dat was how de were able to save more dan a hundred girls all of dem, different, different pockets of...

Text_en: You know they would've vowed to deal with them, saying, "I'll show you, I'll show you."
Text_ortho: You know dem go don mean, dem say I go show you, I go show you.

Text_en: Today we... it might look like fun and games but it's not.
Text_ortho: Today we might be play, but dis is not play.

Text_en: When their clothes were being torn, they were mounting on them, trying to rape them.
Text_ortho: When deir clothing are being torn, de were climbing on dem, attempting to rape dem.

Text_en: I'm telling you!
Text_ortho: I dey tell you!

Text_en: Pi-... kids who had finished taking the... the WAEC exams, or finished their school term!
Text_ortho: Pi-... children wey don comot for, for WAEC, or de don finish deir school term!

Text_en: It was such a di-... a disheartening story to read, if you're a mother.
Text_ortho: It was such a di-... a disheartening ehn story to read if you be mama of pikin.

Text_en: I'm so happy that the Lagos State Government has taken this thing up.
Text_ortho: I'm so happy dat Lagos State government don take dis tin up.

Text_en: Because we shouldn't let things like this slide.
Text_ortho: Because we shouldn't let all dese tins slide.

Text_en: At least, all other secondary schools, they have been used as scapegoats.
Text_ortho: At least, all oda secondary school, de use dem as scapegoat.

Text_en: They won't try it.
Text_ortho: De no go try am.

Text_en: Alright, good morning, my beautiful countrymen.
Text_ortho: Alright una good morning my beautiful country people.

Text_en: How are you doing?
Text_ortho: How una dey?

Text_en: Yes, this is the hot new segment on the Good Morning Naija Show, which I brought to you this beautiful morning.
Text_ortho: Yes na di papapa informate on top di Good Morning Naija show I don carry come for una this beautiful morning.

Text_en: My name is Ajibike Ogunlade.
Text_ortho: My name na Ajibike Ogunlade.

Text_en: From the very first story, we heard that President Muhammadu Buhari has said that since they have found uh... these eighty two Chibok girls, that they have rescued them and that this is a gift to commemorate their second anniversary to all our countrymen.
Text_ortho: Ontop of very first story now, we don hear sey Presido Muhammadu Buhari don commot tian say dis one wey be sey de don eh find dis eighty two Chibok girls, sey de don rescue am, sey dis one na second anniversary gift to all we obodo people.

Text_en: Now since Mr Buhari, um... Mr Buhari said so yesterday, in the Presidential Villa, during a small reception which was organized for the rescued Chibok girls.
Text_ortho: Now dis one wey be sey Oga Buhari, ehm Oga Buhari bin yarn so, na for inside presidential villa yesterday, and during one small reception wey be sey de bin organise ehm because of di Chibok girls wey be sey de rescue.

Text_en: And in fact, after they were rescued yesterday, they were all taken to Abuja, um... to meet with the President and other important figures.
Text_ortho: And in fact, yesterday, after de bin rescue de, na so de carry all of dem go Abuja, ehm make dem go meet Presido, plus oda, oda important, important people.

Text_en: On this, Mr Buhari has said that he is very happy that the girls have been released.
Text_ortho: Ontop dis one now, Oga Buhari don yarn sey im dey very, very happy sey de don release dis girls.

Text_en: And in fact, he has promised all of us in the country that his government is very determined to make sure that the remaining girls who are yet to be released and all other persons who have been kidnapped by (uh... that these, these militants have kidnapped), and kept in their stronghold, will also regain their freedom.
Text_ortho: And in fact, e don comot promise all we obodo people sey im government dey very, very determine to make sure sey di remaining girls wey be sey de never release so, sey de must to release dem, plus all oda of we obodo people wey be sey de don kolobi, ehn dis, I no go gree, people don kolobi put inside deir own stronghold.

Text_en: Meanwhile, we have heard that the eighty two rescued Chibok girls... (yes, you have heard about it), that they have been treated well, that they have discussed and have met with the Chief of Staff to our President, Mr Abaki Harry.
Text_ortho: Meanwhile, we don hear sey di eighty two rescued Chibok girls now o (yes you don hear), sey de don do better, sey don discuss, and de don meet with the Chief of Staff to we Presido, Oga Abaki Harry.

Text_en: Apart from that, one of them also said that they have received very good medical attention from the medical team uh... of the Department of State Services.
Text_ortho: Apart from dat, one also say de don do better, better assessment with the medical team ehn of di Department of State Services.

Text_en: Now, the person who they spoke with the people who shared the story after this, they've had a discussion.
Text_ortho: Now person wey be sey dey discuss with tori people after dis, de don discuss.

Text_en: So it was the Chief of Staff, Staff himself, Mr Abaki Harry.
Text_ortho: So na di Chief of Staff himself, Oga Abaki Harry.

Text_en: As he was explaining that they have assessed all the girls, they have carried out appropriate examinations on each and every one of them.
Text_ortho: As im, e dey explain sey de don assess all di girls, de don do better correct examination on top each, and every one of dem.

Text_en: And in fact, he said all of them are in good condition right now.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey all of dem bin dey inside good form right now.

Text_en: Also, he said that it looks like they have noticed some injuries on two of the girls.
Text_ortho: Also e bin yarn sey e be like sey de bin see some kind small, small injury on top two of di girls.

Text_en: And in fact, he said that these injuries have no connection with the way they were reportedly rescued.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey dis injury so, e no get any kind connection wit di way wey we say de rescue dem.

Text_en: Also on this, we hear that the way... in fact, the rescue operation carried out on these girls was done in a professional way, and there were no errors.
Text_ortho: Now on top dis one also, we bin dey hear sey di way, in fact di rescue operation wey bin sey de do on top dis girls, sey di thing bin go very, very professionally, sey no comma dey on top am.

Text_en: Now, we heard that the Director of the DSS [Director of State Services] Medicals, Ann Okorafor, has also promised all of us in the country that these girls are in safe hands.
Text_ortho: Now we hear sey di director of di DSS medicals, Ann Okorafor sef don comot promise all we obodo people sey dis girls so, sey de bin dey inside di safe hands.

Text_en: And in fact, she said that they will receive the best medical care available anywhere in the world.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey de go receive the best medical care available anywhere inside obodo the world.

Text_en: Now, we heard that our President himself, President Buhari, is supposed he has started packing his bags, getting ready to go to London for follow-up medicals with all his doctors over there.
Text_ortho: Now we don hear sey we Presido imself, Presido Buhari suppose e don dey pack im kaya, e don dey get ready to go London make im go do follow up medicals with all im doctors wey be sey e dey dere.

Text_en: Now, we heard that one of um... these uh... the sources said that Mr President's Spe-... Special Adviser on Media and Publicity, Mr Femi Adesina, announced this yesterday, in Abuja.
Text_ortho: Now we hear sey dis one wey be sey, ehm dis ehn informate so sey na Oga Presido spe-... special adviser on top media, and publicity, Mr Femi Adesina na im yarn dis one yesterday for inside Abuja.

Text_en: Now, according to Mr Femi as well, he has been trying to explain that the duration... the period of time which Mr Buhari won't... will stay back in London... he said that only his Doctor can talk about that right now, but that this will not affect the smooth running of things in the country because the government will continue normally under the able leadership of our Vice President.
Text_ortho: Now according by Oga Femi also, e be dey explain sey di duration, di length of stay wey be sey Oga Buhari will, go stay inside London, sey na only im doctor na im fit talk that one right now, but sey dis one no go stop any kain waka wey be sey dey sele inside we obodo because of sey government go dey continue normally under di able leadership of we Vice Presido.

Text_en: Still on this, also, Mr Femi Adesina has said that Mr Buhari is very grateful to all those who have been praying for him and for all the good wishes which people have been sending him.
Text_ortho: Still on top dis one also, Oga Femi Adeshina bin yarn sey Oga Buhari bin dey very, very grateful to all di people wey be sey bin dey pray for am, plus all di good wishes wey bin sey people bin get, and people dey express for am.

Text_en: And in fact, he has said that he's hopeful that as we say, they are praying for him, and that in the same way, they will be praying for the peace and unity of our country.
Text_ortho: And in fact im bin yarn sey e dey hopeful sey as di way wey we say, de dey pray for am, na so de go dey pray for di peace and unity of we obodo.

Text_en: And we also heard that in January, Mr Buhari travelled to London for a similar check-up, and he came back... and he returned on March tenth, after fifty one days in London.
Text_ortho: And we hear sey for January so, Oga Buhari bin travel go London for a very, very similar checkup, and im bin come back, and im bin return for March ten after fifty one days in London.

Text_en: Now uh... it's been brought to our attention that the association of the people handling aviation matters in our country, (uh... now they call themselves the Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority), they have come out to warn passengers who get angry over minor issues.
Text_ortho: Now ah we don hear sey di joinbody wey be sey dey handle things on top aeroplane matter inside we obodo (eh de dey call demself the Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority now), de don comot dey drag ear, dey warn all dis passengers wey be sey dey ginger any small thing, dey just dey vex, dey just dey vex.

Text_en: And when they're angry, they also beat the ones who work with airplanes, uh... maybe the cr-... crew members.
Text_ortho: And as de dey vex so, na so de dey beat di people wey be sey de bin dey work inside aeroplane o, ehn maybe di cr-... crew member o.

Text_en: Or they go looking for trouble and beat the people working behind the desks.
Text_ortho: Abi de go find small wahala, bin beat people wey be sey dey, eh dey work behind di desk.

Text_en: They said anyone who takes part in this kind of misbehavior should put an end to it right away.
Text_ortho: Sey all dis people wey be sey de dey do dis kind badness, sey meh de stop am now, now, now.

Text_en: If not, they said they will sue them all.
Text_ortho: If not, sey de go carry all of dem go court.

Text_en: Now, this warning in the statement above is such that the General Manager of the association (uh... the... in charge of the media section of public relations), uh... Mr Sam Adurogboye, said so.
Text_ortho: Now dis dragging of ear wey be sey de dey drag ear give dem so, na inside dis statement on top be sey di General Manager of di joinbody, ehn di on top di media section public relation, ehn Mr Sam Adurogboye dey yarn so.

Text_en: Now, according to Mr Sam also, he's been saying that this warning is a result of the reports they were getting that these uh... airline staff are making reports that some people... some people will just get angry with them for things they have no control over.
Text_ortho: Now according by Mr Sam also, im be yarn sey dis one wey be sey de don dey drag ear, dey warn dis people, na because of di report wey be sey de dey get sey dis ehn aeroplane people dey report sey some people, some people go just dey vex with dem on top things wey be sey de no get power over.

Text_en: Now, Mr Sam has said that the airline staff being attacked is a very embarrassing thing.
Text_ortho: Now Mr Sam bin yarn sey dis one wey be sey de just dey attack ehn airline staff, sey dis one na very, very embarrassing something.

Text_en: And in fact, he does not have uh... it's not sensible.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey e no get ehn, e no get brain at all, at all.

Text_en: And in fact, that people... that customers take things into their own hands, especially when things dont favor them.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey make people, make customers no go dey carry di law put on top deir hand especially when things no dey favour dem.

Text_en: And he also advised all airlines operating in our country that they should... should uphold... they should strongly enforce the commissions they have; the terms, and conditions, and contracts on all the...
Text_ortho: And also e bin dey, dey advise all dis airlines wey be sey dey operate inside we obodo sey make, make de uphold, make de hold strongly all di commission wey be sey de bin get, di terms, and condition, and contract on all di...

Text_en: And in fact, they should put it on all the passenger's tickets at all times, so that people will read it, they will see what they're supposed to do and what they're not supposed to do when they have any issues.
Text_ortho: And in fact make de put am on all di tickets of passengers at all time so that people go dey read am, go see wetin de suppose do, and wetin de no suppose do when de bin get any kind issue at all.

Text_en: Moving on to stories on small businesses, we've heard that the Rice Farmers' Association in Kaduna State said they have come out asking for loans, they want to borrow money.
Text_ortho: Moving on into small business story now, we don hear sey di Rice Farmers Association inside Kaduna State now, sey de don comot to dey ask for loan, sey de wan borrow money.

Text_en: They said that they want to use the loan to enhance the production of rice for members of uh... their association for the twenty seventeen farming season.
Text_ortho: Sey dis money wey be sey de wan borrow so, sey de wan use am take enhance di production of rice ehn for people eh wey be sey dey inside deir joinbody for di twenty seventeen farming season.

Text_en: The Secretary of the association, Ishaya Audu, said this yesterday in Kaduna.
Text_ortho: Na di sece of di joinbody so, Ishaya Audu na im yarn dis one yesterday inside Kaduna.

Text_en: I said they should explain all the things they use in the production of rice.
Text_ortho: I say meh de explain say all di things wey be sey de dey use inside dem to produce rice.

Text_en: That the things... some of them dont have any of them.
Text_ortho: Sey di things, some of dem, de no get any of dem.

Text_en: Some of them dont have some of the materials again.
Text_ortho: Some of dem, de no get some of di materials again.

Text_en: And in fact, all these things have been reducing the production of rice in that state.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey all dese things don dey reduce di way wey be sey de dey produce rice inside dat state.

Text_en: And in fact his... um... the number of um... the bags of rice they produce is going down because they lack some of these materials.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey im, em di number of, em di bags of rice wey be sey de dey produce, sey di thing don dey reduce because of sey de no get some of dis materials.

Text_en: Now um... according to Mr Audu, he's been trying to explain that most of the farmers now produce at a loss because some of them dont have fertilizers; some of them dont have um... um... pesticides which they need to use to chase away all these um... animals that eat their produce.
Text_ortho: Now ehm according by Oga Audu, im bin dey explain sey most of di farmers now, sey dem dey produce at a loss because of sey some of dem no get fertilizer, some of dem no get ehm ehm pesticide wey be sey de go dey use take dey, dey pursue all dis ehm animals wey be sey dey chop, chop deir food.

Text_en: And in fact... and all this... he said please, he said they should loan them some money to improve production, to organize all the things they need to use for uh... to make sure that the rice they produce is up to standard, so that they'll be able to produce food for the people of our country.
Text_ortho: And infact, and all dis one so, sey biko, sey make de borrow dem money to use ehm to upgrade their situation, to use take package all di things wey be sey de go use take eh make sure sey dis rice wey be sey de dey farm so, so di thing go dey very, very well, very, very good so dat de go dey fit to produce food for we obodo people.

Text_en: And moving on to my last story, we have heard that in France, yes, the pro European candidate, Emmanuel Macron... yes, we have heard that huge celebrations are going on in France at the moment because he won the French Presidential election um... by between sixty five to sixty six percent of the vote.
Text_ortho: And moving on into my last story now for We Don Hear Sey, for inside France, yes the pro-European candidate, Emmanuel Macron, yes we don hear sey na better jubilation dey inside France now as im don win di French presidential election ehm sey by between sixty five to sixty six percent of the vote.

Text_en: Now, we heard that Macron will be the youngest President that France has ever had, and in fact that he beat the National Front leader, Marine Le Pen after a very, very tough contest.
Text_ortho: Now we hear sey Macron, na im go be di youngest ever president wey be sey obodo France don ever get, and in fact sey im bin beat the far right National Front leader, Marine Le Pen after one very, very strong contest wey be sey bin sele.

Text_en: Adding to this, we've heard that Le Pen said that she conceded, that she has agreed that, yes, it's Macron who defeated her.
Text_ortho: And on top dis one also, we hear sey Le Pen say she don concede, she don gree sey, yes na Macron na im chopulate am.

Text_en: And in fact, she congratulated him on his victory.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey she don call am, congratulate am on the victory.

Text_en: Adding to this, she has told her fans in Fr-... France that Fren-... uh, the French now have chosen their own president.
Text_ortho: Now on top dis one also, she bin dey tell her fans inside eh Fr-... France sey Fren-... em, obodo France now, sey de don choose deir own Presido.

Text_en: They have chosen their leader.
Text_ortho: De don choose deir own leader now.

Text_en: And in fact, it's worth noting that they voted for continuity because they liked the guy's... the guy's plans for their country.
Text_ortho: And in fact sey de bin dey vote for continuity because of sey de bin like wetin di guy's, di guy's plan bin dey for deir obodo.

Text_en: Now, we heard that so many people uh... voted for the far right leader.
Text_ortho: Now we hear sey plenty, plenty people ehn bin vote for the far right leader.

Text_en: But right now, everything is up um... to Emmanuel Macron as he got sixty five... sixty six percent of all the votes cast during the election.
Text_ortho: But right now, everything is up ehm to Emmanuel Macron as e now chopulate dis sixty five, sixty six percent of all the vote wey be sey de bin cast on top di matter.

Text_en: Alright, um... and thats the news we brought your way again today.
Text_ortho: Allright ehm and dat na di informate we don bring for una again today.

Text_en: Yes, and of course, I won't forget to tell you that for any other news on Wazobia TV, our website is here - www dot Wazobia TV dot TV.
Text_ortho: Yes and of course I no forget say on top any oda kind informate for Wazobia TV, our website dey dere, www dot Wazobia TV dot TV.

Text_en: Let's go into our weather studio.
Text_ortho: Make we enter our weather studio.

Text_en: Let's see what's on the weather forecast this morning.
Text_ortho: Make we see how weather go be for us dis beautiful morning.

Text_en: My name is Jibike Ogunladi.
Text_ortho: My name na Jibike Ogunladi.

Text_en: Good morning, Port Harcourt!
Text_ortho: Port Harcout, una good morning!

Text_en: My name is Silver Vick.
Text_ortho: My name na Silver Vick.

Text_en: You know, I'm telling you, very soon, I'll celebrate my one year anniversary of coming teaching you.
Text_ortho: You know, I tell una sey very soon, I go celebrate one year anniversary wey I don dey come, I don dey teach una.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: And there is w-... where I stopped last week, thats where I want to start from.
Text_ortho: And e get w-... where I bin stop last week, na dere I want start.

Text_en: Porico, I've been talking about something.
Text_ortho: Porico, I bin talk someting.

Text_en: I've been... I've been giving an analysis of the average child in Africa, or Nigeria precisely, who studies in a Nigerian University, in fact, most of the Nigerian Univerisities.
Text_ortho: I bin, I bin dey give analysis of di average pikin for Africa, or Nigeria precisely wey dey go Nigerian university, in fact most of Nigerian university.

Text_en: And I'm talking about it, I'm saying it aloud; I said I'm angry.
Text_ortho: And I dey talk am, I dey talk am loud, I say I dey vex.

Text_en: I said, number one, it's totally irrelevant for a kid to go to university in a country where we know that there are no jobs.
Text_ortho: I say number one, it's very irrelevant for pikin to dey go university for country wey we dey sure sey no job dey.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: You know that as you graduate from the university, there are no jobs waiting for you.
Text_ortho: You know sey as you come out, no job just dey wait for you.

Text_en: That's a stupid investment.
Text_ortho: Dat na stupid investment.

Text_en: That's what the white people call it.
Text_ortho: Na so Oyibo call am.

Text_en: Then in Pidgin English, that's an 'anyhow investment'
Text_ortho: Den for Pidgin English, na anyhow investment be dat.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Now if kids are to go to school in this country, then the people in authority should really make sure that they provide jobs so that the gratuating students will employed immediately.
Text_ortho: Now if children go dey go school for dis country, den people wey dey top go try very, very well make de dey provide job make de dey come out come work.

Text_en: Because every average child is a p-... is their mom's investment.
Text_ortho: Because every average pikin na im p-... na im mama investment.

Text_en: How are they their parents' investment?
Text_ortho: How e take be im mama, and papa investment?

Text_en: Currently, some parents are working as what we call civil servants.
Text_ortho: Currently now, some parents dem dey work wetin we dey call civil servant job.

Text_en: They'll start work by seven am, and finish by four.
Text_ortho: De go resume work by seven am, de go dey close by four.

Text_en: Some of them have been on this job for almost forty years.
Text_ortho: Some of dem don dey di job, e don dey go forty years.

Text_en: Where's the salary going?
Text_ortho: Where di money dey go?

Text_en: They spend it on training kids in schools, and all the Nigerian universities that turn out students who will never be economically relevant.
Text_ortho: De use am dey train some children for schools, and Nigerian universities wey dey graduate students dem wey no go everly dey economically relevant.

Text_en: How?
Text_ortho: How?

Text_en: You studied mechanical engineering, you graduated, and you didn't even open a hood.
Text_ortho: You do mechanical engineering, you graduate, you no open bonnet.

Text_en: How did you study engineering?
Text_ortho: How you take do di engineering?

Text_en: You haven't even set your eyes on an engine.
Text_ortho: You no even see engine sef.

Text_en: You studied math but on the average, you are better than the lecturer teaching you.
Text_ortho: You do mathematics, di lecturer wey dey teach you, on di average, you better pass am.

Text_en: Only one or two... a few private universities, are helping matters, and some that even if you want to go there and then you check the process to get into the school...
Text_ortho: Na just one, or two few private universities just dey help di matter, and some wey be sey even if you want enter den you con even check di process to enter di school sef.

Text_en: The brilliant ones, with sharp minds, dont get into the schools because if you dont pay for all the malpractices involved in the process, you dont get in.
Text_ortho: Di real one wey deir brain strong no dey reach enter because if you no pay for di malpractice, you no reach enter.

Text_en: Then the ones who get in corrupt the lecturers by giving them money; sorting everything out.
Text_ortho: Den di ones wey enter, na money de take dey even corrupt di lecturers, dey sort everyting.

Text_en: Then I started taking an assesment of an average child.
Text_ortho: Den I come dey take assessment on average pikin.

Text_en: How are they an investment?
Text_ortho: How e take be investment?

Text_en: The budget for an average three month old... just the food budget alone, for their first three months after birth, is over three hundred and fifty thousand.
Text_ortho: An average pikin wey dey three months old, on feeding budget alone, for three months from nine months pregnancy, you dey look budget of over three hundred, and fifty thousand.

Text_en: That's what the father has spent.
Text_ortho: Na im im fader don spend.

Text_en: So if you see a child of ten years old, you are actually looking at a food budget of over fifteen million naira.
Text_ortho: So if you see pikin of ten years old, na over fifteen million naira feeding budget you dey see so.

Text_en: Then when you see a man of twenty five years old, that is over sixty five million naira's worth of food budget.
Text_ortho: Den when you see man of twenty five years old, dat is over sixty five million naira feeding budget.

Text_en: That's what was spent on a child, just to keep them alive... feeding alone.
Text_ortho: Na im dem put inside head of one pikin mey e just dey alive feeding alone.

Text_en: Clothing, and housing.
Text_ortho: Clothing, and housing.

Text_en: Then housing and clothing is sixty five million.
Text_ortho: Den housing and clothing of sixty five million.

Text_en: And then you go to a Nigerian university where you'll spend close to three million to graduate without any trace of what you studied, to start with.
Text_ortho: Go con go one Nigerian university now wey you go spend close to three million to graduate, wey you no even see wetin e study to start with.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Then you will graduate
Text_ortho: Den you go con graduate.

Text_en: And you will be worth over seventy million.
Text_ortho: You go con worth over seventy million.

Text_en: So what I mean is that only... every avera-... average graduate out there, roaming on the streets, is worth over seventy million naira in hard Nigerian currency and maybe you have about four graduates in your house.
Text_ortho: So wetin I mean be sey only, every avera-... average graduate wey dey out dere for street dey roam about is worth over seventy million naira in hard Nigerian currency and maybe you get like four graduate for your house.

Text_en: That's your life savings loafing around your house.
Text_ortho: Na your life savings just dey loaf around for your house.

Text_en: Now, where are the available jobs in this country?
Text_ortho: Now where di available job wey dey di country?

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: So... if they eventually find jobs, do they get jobs for fifty thousand naira?
Text_ortho: So if de kuku see di job, de dey see job of fifty thousand?

Text_en: A hundred thousand?
Text_ortho: Hundred thousand?

Text_en: Tell me, a chid that graduates, that is worth seventy million, and a food budget budget, and education, including schools that lack lecturers (only a few have lecturers), who graduates and gets a job for fifty thousand, if that child is truly a financial investment to their parents, it means that child will not be able to pay back their mom until they, they die and are reborn seven times over.
Text_ortho: Tell me, pikin wey graduate, wey worth seventy million, plus feeding budget, and education, plus school wey lecturer no kuku dey (na few wey just get di lecturer), now wey graduate con dey work job of fifty thousand, if dat pikin na truly financial investment from di parents, na im be sey dat pikin no go fit pay im mama till e, e die reincarnate even seven times.

Text_en: So it's called a wasted investment.
Text_ortho: So it's called wasted investment.

Text_en: Now they tell them there that any business you do in Nigeria, which keeps you up with the local currency, my brother, you are on top of the world.
Text_ortho: De now come dey tell dem dere now sey any business wey you dey do for Nigeria now, wey dey regulate you to local currency, my broder, you dey high jump so.

Text_en: You're supposed to get into businesses which will give you unprecedented returns that are higher than global inflational rates.
Text_ortho: You suppose dey do businesses wey dey allow your financial flow come beyond di borders on a global slate.

Text_en: Until the country fixes itself up... since the country doesn't let in foreign investors, we ourselves will bring the foreign investors in.
Text_ortho: Until di country kuku fix insef, since di country no dey allow foreign investors enter, we, we go bring di foreign investors in.

Text_en: But first of all, you have to change your means of making money.
Text_ortho: But first of all, you get to change your means of earning.

Text_en: You have to change the fact that you must go to work by six a.m., leave by six... by six in the evening.
Text_ortho: You get to change di fact wey you must go work by six a.m., close by six, by six in di evening.

Text_en: Because nowadays, if you are working for another person, what do we call that?
Text_ortho: Because now, if you dey work on anoder person job, we dey call dat one wetin?

Text_en: Bribing you for your destiny.
Text_ortho: Bribing you for your destiny.

Text_en: Before you figure it out, you're already forty.
Text_ortho: Before you go realize, you don turn forty.

Text_en: Is it at the age of forty you want to realize that you can make shoes or bags?
Text_ortho: Na at forty na im want con dey realize sey you fit make shoe, or you fit make bag.

Text_en: So is it the first point we need to solve this problem?
Text_ortho: So wetin we take dey solve dis problem be number one?

Text_en: The first problem in this country now is poverty, and hunger.
Text_ortho: Di number one problem for dis country now, na poverty, and hunger.

Text_en: Then the second problem is misplacement of priority.
Text_ortho: Den number two problem, na misplacement of priority.

Text_en: Because if you go to a Nigerian university, just go and study a course that's relevant to this present day country!
Text_ortho: Because if you go university for Nigeria, go study course for dis current country o!

Text_en: I'm not talking about another country.
Text_ortho: I no dey talk for anoder country.

Text_en: If you are in Nigeria and you study sociology, philosophy... that's a misplacement of priority because those kinds of things dont have value in this nation right now.
Text_ortho: If you dey Nigeria, your course na sociology, philosophy, dat's misplacement of priority because e no get value for dis nation right now.

Text_en: You mean you're studying political science?
Text_ortho: You dey do political science where?

Text_en: In these chaotic politics?
Text_ortho: For dis scattered politics?

Text_en: And those are the co-... CRK... why don't you go to Bible School?
Text_ortho: And na dose co-... CRK, you no go Bible school?

Text_en: And those are the courses with the highest number of students.
Text_ortho: And na dose courses get di highest number of students.

Text_en: And if you take a close look at these students, you'll see they're not too bright.
Text_ortho: And if you check dese students very well, na students wey deir brain don lock.

Text_en: They just want to get through school so they can say they got through school.
Text_ortho: De want just pass school anyhow make e be sey dem pass school.

Text_en: Why aren't you able to advise these children?
Text_ortho: Why you no fit advise dese children?

Text_en: They should be doing things that will put money in their pockets, being aware of the fact that the more unemployed graduates we roll out, the more problems we create in this country.
Text_ortho: Make dem go do tings wey go dey put money for deir pocket knowing sey di more graduates wey no get job we dey roll out, na di more problem we dey create for dis country.

Text_en: Everybody wants to obtain certificates.
Text_ortho: Everybody want get certificate.

Text_en: So first of all, you who's listening to me, you will solve your financial problem and then you will attend my training so that you will know how to place your priorities right.
Text_ortho: So first of all now, you wey dey listen to me, you go solve your financial problem, den you go attend my training so dat you go know how to place your priorities right.

Text_en: And if you've been working for another man for close to thirty years, my friend, it looks like you will be judged twice.
Text_ortho: And if you don dey work for anoder man job, dey go thirty years, omo e be like sey your judgement na times two.

Text_en: Because once you get to heaven, God will judge you first for your sins and then for wasting your life.
Text_ortho: Because once you reach heaven, God go first judge you for your sins, den judge you for wasting your life.

Text_en: He will ask you, "the gift I gave you, how did you use it?"
Text_ortho: E go ask you di gift wey I give you make you go practice, how you take use am?

Text_en: "You helped fulfil another man's destiny."
Text_ortho: You go work for anoder man own destiny.

Text_en: So did the man not have his own plans?
Text_ortho: So di man no get e own plans?

Text_en: So first of all, if your problem in Nigeria at the moment is how to place three meals a day on your table... when you wake up every morning, your work (I wonder why you go to work) is to place three meals a day on your table, then the truth of the matter is that you don't exist.
Text_ortho: So first of all, if currently your problem for Nigeria now na how to place three square meal for your table, every morning when you wake up, your work, why you dey go work be sey na you want place three square meal for your table, di truth about di matter be sey you never dey exist.

Text_en: The moment you start to exist is the moment you get to that level where you know that you don't have to worry over what you and your family will eat.
Text_ortho: Di moment you start to exist be sey di moment you don reach dat level wey be sey you wake up, you know sey wetin you, and your family go chop don ready.

Text_en: That's the point where you can sit down and say, "now, let us change the country!"
Text_ortho: At dat point now, naim you fit siddown say oya make we change di country!

Text_en: You can't tell a man who can't afford three meals a day to go and change the country.
Text_ortho: You can't tell a man who can not afford three square meals to go, and change di country.

Text_en: What will he change?
Text_ortho: Change what?

Text_en: Let hunger deal with him, he will change his decision in five seconds unless the hunger pangs are not strong enough.
Text_ortho: Make hungry catch am, e go change im decision in five seconds unless dat worm wey dey im belle no strong.

Text_en: As funny as it may sound, and as much as I'm joking, this is a serious matter.
Text_ortho: As funny as it may sound, and as joking as I might be, na so serious di matter dey o.

Text_en: As funny as it may sound and as much as I might be joking, this is a serious issue.
Text_ortho: As funny as it may sound and as joking as I might be, na so serious di matter dey o.

Text_en: I know that I'm coming from a very humble background.
Text_ortho: I know sey I dey come from very humble background.

Text_en: My daddy is a reverend, my mommy is a pastor.
Text_ortho: Daddy na reverend, mumsie na pastor.

Text_en: Then, at the same time, the man was a medical psychologist, and then my mom was a linguist.
Text_ortho: Den, at di same time, di man na medical psychologist, den mumsy na linguist.

Text_en: Mstchew... when poverty started affecting with us in the house, I told them, "see, this can't work!"
Text_ortho: Mtschew when poverty start to dance reggae for inside our house, I tell dem sey see dis thing no go work o!

Text_en: See, I will go in the opposite direction.
Text_ortho: See I go go di oda way round.

Text_en: I made up my mind.
Text_ortho: I make up my mind.

Text_en: I told them that I wouldn't go for any engineering course in any school.
Text_ortho: I tell dem sey I no dey go do any engineering for any school.

Text_en: They said, "why?"
Text_ortho: De say why?

Text_en: I said I wanted to be a pilot.
Text_ortho: I say I wan be pilot.

Text_en: They said, "why?"
Text_ortho: De say why?

Text_en: I said apart from the fact that any career at all is a career, career... the essence of a career is to make money.
Text_ortho: I say outside di fact sey career na career, career, number one thing for career na to make money.

Text_en: Calling... that is what we are doing.
Text_ortho: Calling, na dat one wey we dey do.

Text_en: That this one, this what God gave us.
Text_ortho: Sey dis one, na im God give us.

Text_en: My career is being a pilot, my calling is to help people succeed in what I'm into.
Text_ortho: My career, na piloting, my calling, na to help people succeed dis one wey I dey do.

Text_en: Whether the calling gives me money or not doesn't concern me.
Text_ortho: Weda di calling give me money or not e no dey pain me.

Text_en: But you see, that career, piloting, you wouldn't ask me to fly a plane free of charge.
Text_ortho: But you see dat career piloting, you no go tell me make I come fly plane for you for free now.

Text_en: Do you know how much I paid to study in school?
Text_ortho: You know how much I pay go di school?

Text_en: Even now, while I'm still schooling, if you happen to be aboard a plane I fly, it'll end in disaster just like the Sosoliso airplane.
Text_ortho: While I still dey di school now self, if I fly you now self, sosoliso go be testimony.

Text_en: You know!
Text_ortho: You know!

Text_en: But so what I now do is, we have set up a standard organization we call the Billionaire's Code.
Text_ortho: But so wetin I dey do now be sey, we don set up one better organisation, we dey call am di billionaire's code.

Text_en: On the Billionaire's Code, we bring a lot of opportunities which can help you make at least five percent interest on your investment every Friday for the next fifty two weeks.
Text_ortho: For di billionaire's code now, we bring a lot of opportunities wey be sey e fit help you dey make at least five percent on your investment every Friday for di next fifty two weeks.

Text_en: Meaning that on anything which you invest...
Text_ortho: Meaning sey anyting wey you invest...

Text_en: Okay, let me talk money.
Text_ortho: Okay meh I call money name.

Text_en: Let's say you invest one hundred and thirty seven thousand naira... I won't tell you the name of the company.
Text_ortho: Let us say you invest one hundred and thirty seven thousand naira, I no go tell you di name of di company.

Text_en: That's why I want you to come to the seminar because Nigerians, you are too smart.
Text_ortho: Na im make I wan make you come di seminar because Nigerian, una too dey smart.

Text_en: As soon as I tell you the name, you would go and Google it, you won't get any information.
Text_ortho: As I tell you di name, you go run go google am, you no go see any information.

Text_en: I have seen it, I have seen it.
Text_ortho: I have seen it, I have seen it.

Text_en: Stop that!
Text_ortho: Stop dat ting!

Text_en: Learn to go to the school of money.
Text_ortho: Learn to go to di school of money.

Text_en: Stop surfing the internet.
Text_ortho: Stop surfing di Internet!

Text_en: What they upload on the internet is the review.
Text_ortho: Wetin de put for Internet na review.

Text_en: They dont upload the complete version.
Text_ortho: De no dey put di original ting dere.

Text_en: Go, and find out what it's all about.
Text_ortho: Go, and know what is all about.

Text_en: So that's why you need to attend a seminar.
Text_ortho: So dat's why you must come to a seminar.

Text_en: Dont invest in something you dont understand.
Text_ortho: No invest inside someting wey you no understand.

Text_en: It gives you five percent.
Text_ortho: E dey pay you five percent.

Text_en: So if... if you invest one hundred and thirty seven thousand.
Text_ortho: So sey, sey you invest one hundred and thirty seven thousand.

Text_en: Take away five percent of one hundred and thirty seven thousand.
Text_ortho: Chop five percent of one hundred and thirty seven thousand.

Text_en: That way, you can be making around seven thousand to eight thousand naira every Friday.
Text_ortho: Like dat one fit dey run around seven thousand to eight thousand naira every Friday.

Text_en: And they pay you in Euros.
Text_ortho: And de dey pay you in euros.

Text_en: You can withdraw it through uh... cryptocurrency, you can withdraw through OK Pay... you can withdraw it through uh... your direct domiciliary account.
Text_ortho: You fit withdraw am through ehm cryptocurrency, you fit withdraw through OK Pay, you fit withdraw am through eh your direct domiciliary account.

Text_en: If you check the five percent of one thirty seven thousand naira for fifty two weeks, thats like tripling your money.
Text_ortho: If you check five percent on one thirty seven thousand for fifty two weeks, dat na like doubling your money by three times.

Text_en: You understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: And what does this company deal in?
Text_ortho: And wetin dis company dey deal on?

Text_en: They deal in real estate, bank liabilities, debentures, IPOs.
Text_ortho: De dey deal on real estate, bank liabilities, debentures, IPOs.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: So, the reason why we brought in this opportunity is that we want to discourage Nigerians from Ponzi Schemes.
Text_ortho: So, why we bring dis opportunity be sey we wan carry Nigeria comot from Ponzi Scheme.

Text_en: What is a Ponzi Scheme?
Text_ortho: Wetin be Ponzi Scheme?

Text_en: A Ponzi Scheme is when you invest one naira and by next week, you get paid twenty naira.
Text_ortho: Ponzi Scheme na you put one naira, by next week, you dey collect twenty naira.

Text_en: Who did you work for?
Text_ortho: Who you work for?

Text_en: How did the money multiply?
Text_ortho: How di money take grow?

Text_en: Then, you dont know that that system relies on people in order to grow.
Text_ortho: Den, you no know sey dat system dey rely on people for am to grow.

Text_en: They didnt create the money from nowhere.
Text_ortho: De no create di money anywhere.

Text_en: If they get money, it would crash.
Text_ortho: If de get money, e go crash.

Text_en: Some of them dont even last for two weeks now.
Text_ortho: Some of dem no dey even last two weeks now.

Text_en: Now, why do you need those kinds of opportunities so that if you invest something, you would say okay?
Text_ortho: Now, why you need dose kind of opportunity so dat if you invest something, you go say okay?

Text_en: Uhuh, this particular money which I invested now, is for my family's upkeep.
Text_ortho: Ehen dis particular money wey I invest now, na for my family feeding.

Text_en: I dont get to run around.
Text_ortho: I no get to dey run around.

Text_en: This one brings in five percent every Friday.
Text_ortho: Sey okay dis one dey bring five percent every Friday.

Text_en: Every Monday, they can withdraw it... they can...
Text_ortho: Every Monday, dey fit withdraw am dey fit.

Text_en: Then, you will know that the next batch of money which is on the way, there is another investment but I will not mention its name on air.
Text_ortho: Den you go know sey di next money wey e dey come, e got anoda investment now wey I no go call di name for radio.

Text_en: But this investment is a huge one which can pay you up to twenty thousand dollars on an investment as low as one thousand dollars in the next seven to eight months when it will be fully launched all over the whole world.
Text_ortho: But dis investment na huge investment wey be sey e fit pay you up to twenty thousand dollars with di little investment as low as one thousand dollars in di next seven months to eight months wen de go launch fully for di whole world.

Text_en: Another one... you will learn more about it.
Text_ortho: Anoder one, you go find out about am.

Text_en: The third most important thing (outside all these investments I'm talking about)... I am into what they call financial and business mentorship.
Text_ortho: Di number three most important thing (outside all dese investment wey I dey talk about), I dey run wetin de dey call financial, and business mentorship.

Text_en: I will teach you how to run a business.
Text_ortho: I go teach una how to position business.

Text_en: You dont need to open a shop to start a business.
Text_ortho: You no need to open shop to open business o.

Text_en: You can work from your living room or your bedroom.
Text_ortho: You just need to dey inside your parlour, inside your bedroom open business.

Text_en: Let me give you an example.
Text_ortho: Mah I give una instance.

Text_en: When we were growing up, we knew all those kinds of people which they call uh... ma-firewood (meaning that they sell firewood), uh... ma-akara (meaning that they fry akara), uh... mama tailor (meaning that the woman is a tailor).
Text_ortho: When we dey grow up, we know of all dose kind wey de dey call ehn ma-firewood (mean sey de dey sell firewood), ehn ma-akara (mean sey de dey fry akara), ehn mama tailor (mean sey di woman na tailor).

Text_en: As soon as Shell and NNPC started opening up in Nigeria, all those people dumped their machines in a room, packed their firewood to the side, and they went in search of white collar jobs.
Text_ortho: As soon as all dose Shell and NNPC start to enter Nigeria, all dose people carry deir machine put inside packing room, carry deir firewood put di oda side, go find white collar job.

Text_en: So theyve gone back to basics, brought it out, cleaned it.
Text_ortho: Oya now, now de don go middle of ocean, go bring am out, clean am.

Text_en: Let's start from where we left off.
Text_ortho: Mey we start from where we stop.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: When you go to some countries like... (I dont want to mention names so you dont think I'm comparing Nigeria to other countries), you would discover that...
Text_ortho: When you go some countries like (I no wan call names meh you no come tink sey I dey compare Nigeria to oda countries), you go discover sey...

Text_en: In fact, let me mention one, China.
Text_ortho: Infact, mah I call one name, China.

Text_en: You go to China.
Text_ortho: You enter China.

Text_en: How did China work out their own revolution?
Text_ortho: How China take cause deir own revolution?

Text_en: They locked their borders for almost twelve, or ten years.
Text_ortho: De lock deir borders for almost twelve, or ten years.

Text_en: No one travelled.
Text_ortho: Nobody travel.

Text_en: They picked people and said "You, travel, go learn and come back."
Text_ortho: Na dem pick people say you travel go learn come back!

Text_en: There are things that you...
Text_ortho: E get things wey you...

Text_en: In fact, the Facebook we use here, you know that China doesn't use it.
Text_ortho: Infact, Facebook wey we dey use, you know sey China no dey use am.

Text_en: China didnt allow it.
Text_ortho: China no gree.

Text_en: They said they must use their own app, that the Westerners should develop apps for their own use, and Africans too.
Text_ortho: De say de must use deir own app, sey make Oyinbo dem do deir own app for demself, and Africa.

Text_en: You cannot be here and get across to someone in China, for instance on Facebook.
Text_ortho: You no fit dey here and get person wey dey China say if you dey Facebook.

Text_en: It's not possible.
Text_ortho: E no possible.

Text_en: That is how developed they are.
Text_ortho: Na so de don develop reach.

Text_en: Look at this guy now (uh... what is his name?), the one who owns Alibaba dot com, that guy is the one who made online marketing popular.
Text_ortho: See dis guy now (eh wetin be im name) wey get Alibaba dot com, dat guy, na im make online market go popular.

Text_en: Because these guys, they think outside the box.
Text_ortho: Because dese guys, dem look widin.

Text_en: If you go to China, on the whole street, what will every family be selling?
Text_ortho: You go go China, one full street, every family wetin de sell?

Text_en: It's light, light, light, light, light, light, and it's consistency.
Text_ortho: Na light, light, light, light, light, light, and na consistency.

Text_en: You would go to another street, even these uh... crypto, crypto which they are talking about, China made it popular.
Text_ortho: You go anoda street, even dese eh crypto, crypto wey de dey talk, na China make am popular.

Text_en: Hm... they are the ones who started doing it.
Text_ortho: Hm na dem start to dey do am.

Text_en: Almost everything.
Text_ortho: Almost everything.

Text_en: Then, come to Nigeria.
Text_ortho: Den you come Nigeria.

Text_en: Where is the China of Nigeria?
Text_ortho: Where is di China of Nigeria?

Text_en: Haba!
Text_ortho: Haba!

Text_en: They even produce their own things, and tag it 'Made in Turkey'.
Text_ortho: De go even produce deir own things, still put on top made in Turkey.

Text_en: What's your problem?
Text_ortho: Wetin dey worry you?

Text_en: Is it an inferiority complex, or what?
Text_ortho: Na inferiority complex be dat, or wetin?

Text_en: So what I've been trying to say in essence is that this Sunday, eleventh of June, two thousand and seventeen, by two p.m., as soon as we finish church, dont go for the second service!
Text_ortho: So wetin I bin try talk in essence be sey, dis Sunday, eleventh of June, two thousand and seventeen, by two p.m. gbangain, as we dey close from church, no enter second service o!

Text_en: Take an excuse this Saturday, which is today, with your two legs, walk in through the Stadium Road.
Text_ortho: Take excuse dis Saturday wey be today, carry your two leg waka Byfollow, enter Stadium Road.

Text_en: As soon as you get to the Airforce Junction, stop at Aztech Event Hall.
Text_ortho: As you stop for Airforce Junction, tell dem sey drop me for Aztech Event Hall!

Text_en: Beside Aztech, you will see a hotel which has a big name, Swiss and Spirit... Swiss Spirit Hotel.
Text_ortho: By Aztech, you go see one hotel wey get big name, Swiss and Spirit, Swiss Spirit Hotel.

Text_en: Just walk inside, into the hall.
Text_ortho: Just enter inside come di hall.

Text_en: This seat is waiting for you there.
Text_ortho: Dis seat dey wait for you dere.

Text_en: Normally, you know that my seminar goes for twenty five or twenty thousand naira, but for Porico's sake, they have really criticized me, saying that I dont want to help people with the returns I make; that's why I've made the seminar... the last four seminars of... this last one which I do, free.
Text_ortho: Normally, you know sey my seminar na twenty five, twenty thousand naira, but because of Porico dey don too criticise me say I no dey wan help people with di ones wey I don make, na I come make di seminar free for di last four seminars of dis last one wey I don do.

Text_en: Last week's was free, this one is free.
Text_ortho: Last week own na free, dis one na free.

Text_en: There are still... there are still two or three more, then we'll go back to charging fees.
Text_ortho: Remain, remaining two three more, we go con go back to di money.

Text_en: Now, dont miss this opportunity!
Text_ortho: Now, no miss dis opportunity!

Text_en: Even, someone paid for this airtime I'm talking with.
Text_ortho: Even dis airtime wey I take dey talk somebody pay for am.

Text_en: Dont think that opportunities are just flying around.
Text_ortho: No think sey opportunity just dey fly for wind!

Text_en: Some people make the senseless statement that "opportunities will always come."
Text_ortho: E dey people wey dey make statement wey no make sense sey opportunity will always come.

Text_en: Opportunities will always come, but maybe not for you.
Text_ortho: Opportunity will always come, but may be not for you.

Text_en: Now that the one meant for you has come, take the one meant for you!
Text_ortho: Now wey di one wey dey for you don come, take dis one wey be for you!

Text_en: Opportunities will always come!
Text_ortho: Opportunity will always come!

Text_en: You are twenty years old now, in that time, you will be forty.
Text_ortho: You dey twenty years now, dat time you go dey forty.

Text_en: And you can't do what you would do when you were twenty.
Text_ortho: And you can't do what you will do when you were twenty.

Text_en: Do you understand?
Text_ortho: You understand?

Text_en: Some people are listening to me now.
Text_ortho: Some people body dey listen to me now.

Text_en: "Hey, this boy has talent."
Text_ortho: Hey dis boy dey talented.

Text_en: "I want to be like him."
Text_ortho: I wan be like am.

Text_en: My brother, there was a time you had the opportunity, you did not make use of it.
Text_ortho: My broder, e get time wey you be get di opportunity, you no move o.

Text_en: Laziness, thats what destroyed you.
Text_ortho: Laziness, na im scatter you.

Text_en: So what I'm saying now is that you will pick up your phone, and you will send me a text message containing your name, and the word "reserve."
Text_ortho: So wetin I dey talk now be sey you go pick your phone, and you go send me di text message containing your name, and di word reserve.
